author: {'steamid': '76561198045090186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1689461374}
review:
Everything cool In THIEF is done worse here. Here's what you're up against:

-No button to lower yourself from a ledge, just walk around or jump and try to catch the edge...or fall to your death, more likely.

-All enemies 1-2 shot you.

-They introduce enemies (Roabies) where sneaking isn't enough (!), so they added an even slower sneaking option!

-Having fun figuring out ways to kill your enemies undetected? Well, they'll rip that fun away from you, too, by introducing armored enemies that can only be killed by acid traps (if you have the iron) or environmental traps (IF there's one nearby AND the AI hasn't decided to ignore it).

-Be prepared if you set off an alarm but find a hiding place to sit and wait...and wait...and wait. Waiting's fun right? Right!?!?!

-Mission 6, choose your gear and let's go! Took the Akenash dagger, cleared the area around Arlock, and then killed Arlock...only to be told that I failed because there was no body left for evidence...because of the acid dagger I chose to equip...which would have been nice to know...before I finished the whole level!!!!! AGHHHHHHH! So, yeah, no switching equipment mid level except for one place in the whole game.

-And the final boss? Yeah, a one shot kill AND when you die you go back, NOT to the beginning of the fight, but back to the cut-scene BEFORE the beginning of the fight. Srsly!

Save yourself the trouble and go buy THIEF, that's a fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044406233', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1975, 'last_played': 1657325244}
review:
I love the Styx franchise and their take on the infiltration genre. If you're a completionist, I recommend it, but I'd suggest starting with Styx: Master of Shadows so you can understand the story. I will say that the jump in quality, in terms of the graphics, was very pleasing and it made the game much more enjoyable.

In terms of story, I do think that it was much more cohesive than it was in Master of Shadows. Instead of just a sort of slideshow of faces with a voiceover and then some random dialogue throughout your gameplay, the slideshow and voiceover were replaced with in-game cutscenes that really allowed us to connect the voices to their respective characters. All in all, I think it was much more immersive. There was an odd retcon regarding the elves though... In Master of Shadows, elves could sense the amber in Styx's body, making them difficult to maneuver around, but in Shards of Darkness, that detail was instead applied to a new type of enemy. I won't spoil anything, but I found that change interesting.

As for the gameplay, it was interesting to see which aspects were altered. Some things, like how amber vision functions and some button remapping, took a bit of getting used to, but after I got past it, I couldn't imagine it any other way.

I think this was a great sequel to Master of Shadows and, with the ending that we were given in this game, I hope for a continuation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198377946949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1654539877}
review:
This should be the perfect game for me. It has the perfect mechanics that I prefer - I like the elements of chance combined with skill. It has a rich backstory and 3-dimensional characters. It's a point-and-click adventure with a large degree of autonomy. You are able to choose your own motivation, and play your character the way you'd like to. There is real humor, and you can choose how far to take the humor. You can choose to waste your time reading small minutia, or skip through it. Your character feels like a real person, with real struggles, and real decisions to make. Add to that a mystery in a science-fiction setting, and, in theory, I should be writing a rave review right now.

Here's my problem - it's very, very emotionally dark, to the point where it's affecting my mindset. At 16.3 hours, I'm about 25% through my first playthrough. I've had about 3 or 4 sessions of play - every time I stop playing for the day, I just feel empty and lonely. And, to an extent, I think much of the darkness is necessary for the subject matter - the mystery you try to solve just serves as a backdrop for the psychological landscape of struggling with addiction, amnesia, and discovering who your character is and who he wants to become. There are certainly bright spots - the humor, and crossing things off your task list. But everything - every mystery, every thought, every interaction - is anchored in the fact your character is a very broken man in a very broken world.

Now, I'm a highly empathetic person, fighting my own battles with depression to begin with. In all likelihood, and based on the raving reviews, I'm an outlier. It would probably help if I didn't keep playing for an hour longer than I intend to each time just trying to find a bit of sunshine for my character, and accept that I might just need to be patient and play through to the end. However, I think the strength of the game is the downfall here - I'm making decisions on when to tackle tasks, therefore the developer couldn't add bright spots to help with pacing. And pacing seems to be the main criticism of many of the other reviews. Maybe the emotional darkness would be easier to handle if the artwork was a little less gritty, but again, that kind of goes with the subject matter.

I really, really wish I could love this game. I really tried to love this game. I will likely try in the future to love this game. But right now, if only to warn someone else fighting their own battles that right now may not be the time to play this game, I cannot recommend it.

review:
Безумно влюблен в первую часть (хотя если перепроходить оказывается что она довольно коротенькая сюжетно но простор локаций и путей их прохождения 10/10 , плюс ко всему лор довольно интересный  и конечно же харизматичный главный герой). Вторую часть только начал проходить (на момент написания 11% прогресс в игре ) если в двух словах то: 
из плюсов 
- больше локаций (и они все такие же проработанные) 
- старый главный герой ( но тут вкусовщина, мне доставляет так что закинул в плюсы)
- больше бэкграунда и лора 
- появился выбор снаряжения в хабе ( хочешь коршить всех берешь кинжал и одежу заточенную под убийства и т.д., мелочь а приятно)
из минусов
- появился крафт (теперь хилки и другие флаконы, отмычки и т.д. нужно крафтить а что бы их крафтить нужно по ходу миссии собирать ресурсы, короче довольно сомнительное нововведение) 
- усложнили прокачку ( не в плане сижу не знаю что прокачать а в том плане что в начале игры урезаны вообще все возможности, если в первой части почти сразу открывается большинство возможностей то во второй части за каждую мелочь нужно заплатить очками миссии в древе прокачки, такое себе как по мне) 
- "интеллект" у противников хуже чем в первой части ( не сильно, но заметно сразу) играю на сложном уровне (так как на максимальном при смерти персонажа локацию нужно проходить заново а т.к. локации нифига не маленькие то это дрочь как по мне) и прохожу без убийств и без тревог чтоб хоть какой то челлендж
вот пока что все что пришло на ум если не докапываться до каждой мелочи, по итогу если сомневаетесь пройдите первую часть на пиратке, там уже сразу станет ясно для вас эта игра или нет ( я сам прошел на пиратке потом спустя пару лет нахлынула ностальгия и я купил и первую и вторую часть в стиме, правда по какой то сумасшедшей скидке но это НЕВАЖНО, главное что меня игра зацепила и я ее перепрошел и еще наверно перепройду (в первой части еще не все монетки собраны, кто знает тот поймет) такой вот обзор получился, всем кто дочитал респект)).

author: {'steamid': '76561198074290237', 'num_games_owned': 1176, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1694, 'last_played': 1651417717}
review:
[i]Styx: Shards of Darkness[/i] is a second instalment in the third-person stealth game series about a snarky, murderous goblin who uses his assassin skills as well as mysterious powers to move through shadows, eliminate unsuspecting enemies, and find answers to a turn of events that threaten his forsaken kind.

[b]THE GOOD[/b][list]
[*] The game does best what it should – the combination of numerous mechanics it serves prioritises stealth as its main focus, at the same time allowing for enough flexibility to avoid monotony of doing the same thing over and over again. Detection is split into three tiers, which lets you adjust the balance between patiently moving through shadows and running for it like your butt is on fire. Enemies, depending on their type and rank, have various detection patterns and reactions to the sight of yours truly, and that diversifies encounters, depending on locations of escape routes, items at hand, and so on. Distraction methods add a lot to the possibilities of manipulating your surroundings accordingly to your  purposes. Killing in open combat (but who cares about that, you’re an assassin) is an outlier here, and avoiding it is synonymous to avoiding frustration from awful camera angles – fortunately there’s multiple ways to escape a fight and go back to the shadows (ominous music here).
[*] About the enemy diversity: while being subpar in comparison to the first game, it still adds to the tactical aspect. Some of them you can kill in any manner, some you can only rid of through deception, and some are just too heavily armoured for you to handle. There’s those that can smell you from afar, and those that hear your footsteps better than the others. There’s multiple approaches to stealth you’ll eventually have to take up and that’s healthy for the sake of keeping you interested.
[*] Skill trees are yet again another thing that allows you to pick a more personalised approach to the game, based on the aspects they focus on. Stealth tree grants you extra mobility, making it harder for enemies to hear or see you and expands on your ability to become invisible. Kill tree gives you more effective and showy opportunities to dispose of your enemies. Cloning tree is fully dedicated to another of your abilities (that’s cloning, who would’ve thought?) and granting it additional purposes. Perception tree sharpens Styx’s senses and Alchemy tree allows him to craft more inventive stuff. But the best thing in skills is that they don’t make the game too easy (at least outright) and there’s no mandatory build you simply need. Just pick your own style, supplement it with skills from other trees, and back to the shadows with you (more ominous music here).
[*] The inventory. One-use items come with varying degree of usefulness, but the ability to both find and craft them always gives you an extra thing to play around just in case. Outfits and daggers, while scarce, serve more purpose than just of glorified reskins, giving you the possibility to change the gameplay in a certain way, like gaining easier silent kills, but without the ability to parry, being able to carry more items for the cost of being louder, and so on. It’s an interesting use of a modest equipment system that actually is a bank of double-edged game modifiers.
[*] Areas look good and are more diverse than in the first game. Their design is cleaner, there is more variety in terms of possible routes to take and, generally speaking, are quite pretty.
[*] You get extra skill points for finishing a mission in a certain time frame, limiting yourself to a set number of kills, not alerting enemies of your presence and finding hidden tokens in the area. While pretty much impossible to do it all in one run, completionists should be quite happy about the opportunities to replay missions using different styles to get their hands on every achievement and available skill point. And even if that’s not the case, you’re not being punished for playing the game in a certain style, but rather rewarded for using your own.[/list]

[b]THE SO-SO[/b][list]
[*] The story is pretty basic, but still okay. At first the game starts with something completely else, then it sets you up for a surprise and when the main story kicks in, you may feel intrigued. Halfway through, however, it loses momentum, becoming a stretched out shadow of its former self. There’s a bunch of baddies, a shady organisation, a grand scheme of a sort, but you’ve heard it all before. It still serves an alright filler to the more interesting lore aspects.
[*] The game doesn’t really become more challenging the further you go. While new enemy types are added to the roster, and missions where you cannot be spotted at all become a thing, with skill upgrades and mechanics that don’t get more complex than how they first started, the difficulty curve is very mild. If you’re up for a challenge, there are extra settings that give enemies more health, or make you die instantly when hit, but if you’d rather keep one difficulty setting for the whole game, be prepared for an “I’ve done it all already” moment sooner or later.[/list]

[b]THE BAD[/b][list]
[*] Let’s be real, the writing is a gigantic flaw. In no particular order:
- Firstly, the so-called sense of humour and the game’s incessant desire to forcefully shove it down your throat. Styx, once the feisty master of shadows, now became the unfunny master of breaking the fourth wall in the most embarrassing ways possible. The death screen that replaces the usual game over image, is just a travesty of comicality and the jokes that the goblin throws at you are only worth a moment of silence for the time you wasted listening to them.
- Secondly, the dialogues implying that the game’s world is filled with psychopaths. From the dingiest corner of Thoben to the grandest quarter of Korrangar, everyone’s favourite pastime is killing, and sharing details from their most recent murderous foray to their equally bloodthirsty friends is the only thing than can put a smile on their lips. Every syllable spat out by friends and foes alike drips with excessive amounts of unnecessary darkness. Maybe I don’t know how to properly write these myself – but after playing [i]Shards of Darkness[/i] I definitely know how to not. Dialogues are just outrageously bad (voice acting isn’t much better, too).
- And thirdly, if it weren’t for constantly overhearing NPCs randomly talking about exactly what we need to know to proceed, Styx would never be able to get anywhere. Most of the story progresses because the goblin assassin found himself in the right place in the right time, and not because of his own knowledge or connections. This aspect of storytelling is quite a failure.
[*] The last stage and everything that happens from there is a big, stinking mystery. There is an event that makes absolutely no sense, the game turns on its stealth origins to become an action title instead, and the ending only leaves you with a lot of question marks. The last cutscene ends so abruptly I initially thought my game was lacking some files to process it properly, but no. This would be even too much as a foreshadowing of an extra story DLC (that never came to be) since not only one of the biggest questions that followed you through the game doesn’t get answered in the end, but the game literally ends during the most important encounter in the story.[/list]

[b]OVERALL[/b]

[i]Shards of Darkness improves[/i] upon its predecessor – slightly, but on multiple levels. Stealth mechanics are upgraded, visuals and animations are slicker, skill and inventory systems are better, Styx is greener (actually not true). Yes, the writing is a tad awful and areas still repeat, though to lesser extent, but overall the game is very enjoyable from the mechanical standpoint. If you enjoyed the previous game, you’ll most probably enjoy this one too. If you like stealth titles and/or fantasy games with charismatic protagonists, that’s a recommendation as well.

review: Fantastic pure stealth game with excellent soundtrack and world design. Large, detailed levels provide the player with a plethora of options when it comes to approaching their objectives. Exploration is greatly rewarded. Sneaking around and climbing are very satisfying, as is clearing levels without being spotted or killing anyone. The boss battles didn't really fit, but at least they were both fairly easy to get through. However there were also a number of bugs that I experienced, all of which affected the AI, which in one occassion prevented me from completing a level undetected. Also there were a couple of frustrating missions. But these are minor complaints. Overall I really enjoyed my time with this game (especially after discovering the setting that disabled Styx's post-mortem commentary).

爽快的盗贼+杀人犯哥布林，1代我杀人多，像个狂战士，2代基本都是0杀金牌过，潜行水平提高了。

author: {'steamid': '76561198053624818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1655952948}
review:
It’s a red flag when a stealth game is built around invisibility and x-ray vision. 

Styx: Shards of Darkness tries to recreate classic stealth games. However, the devs also copied the godawful platforming and glitchy, arbitrary AI of retro games. Hiding in darkness isn’t reliable, and the insta-fail missions are pretty freaking lame. 

Though it’s better than modern AAA stealth games, that bar is set pretty low. I wouldn’t recommend this to non-stealth fans. And the fact is, Styx isn’t nearly as refined as Thief: Deadly Shadows, which used dynamic lighting and sound cues better than any game to date, and has more realistic AI. If you really want dark fantasy with a wise-cracking stealth protagonist, play Deadly Shadows.

Note: there’s a key-rebinding bug where you might need to edit the ini file.

author: {'steamid': '76561199116803315', 'num_games_owned': 19, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2142, 'last_played': 1678399879}
review:
I finished the game righ NOW.
And OH. MY. STYX!
It has been a difficult game for someone that is not a pro gamer. But even if, I'm sure you would have difficulties as well. 
The levels are one more difficult than the other, especially the boss battle, even if they are a few.
As in Styx style you're going to see some places again but you'll not going to find the same enemies in the same place as the time before. More you go on, more is goint to be difficult hide from this people that, and you really feel it during some parts, are way stronger than you. 
Being put in this unadvantage situation, in a permanent way, could be seen as a defect, instead it gives you the wish to play again and better. 
When you die Styx is ready, waiting to tell you how much you sucked and proposing to exchange place, always in that sarcastic way I adore!
It's not a heavy thing, and when you're pissed you can always skip his monologues. 
Being a pure stealth game you have to hide and kill in silence, or hide the bodies. But i can assure you that the action is always behind the corner and just because you do not use a big sword to defeat an army you have a lot of fun. Especially the anxiety, ohhh, you're gonna feel sooo much of that. Everytime you give the wrong comand, or you miss a jump, or you notice the invisibility is over you will sweat. 
I played other games but even if I died a lot I HAD FUN!
SOO MUCH FUN!
And at the end, this is the most important thing in a videogame. 
I highly counsil this and most of all, I hope it's gonne came out soon another game or some books or comic books, because I NEED TO KNOW WHAT HAPPENED NEXT! 
Maybe a game that continues to the original adventure of the first game, I miss the magical duo as I already miss our favourite piece of shif of a goblin.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198158938940', 'num_games_owned': 2643, 'num_reviews': 694, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1654012755}
review:
I love stealth games and Styx has been in my inventory for years. Last time I played was in 2019 but let it pass. I gave it another try.

This game is a hardcore stealth game. Styx is vulnerable to any damages regardless of what armor he wears, any negligence can easily lead to an alarm following an instant death. Player needs to 1) Design a pathway well; 2)Be patience; and 3) Control precisely. Game offers no map, it does have an instinct mode to see nearby enemies and objects to interact with - you can use environment kill, hide bodies or yourself, but it is like a prototype of the Hitman games, Styx is a goblin so no clothes would fit, 90% of the time Styx has to remain hidden. Without a map it is difficult to foresee some danger, I proceed with caution, leaving some side missions undone, rooms unexplored and collectibles behind.

One of the highlights is the path building. Styx can hide in pipelines, walk through small paths, walk on beams, hang at the edges, climb on walls... those stealth elements are decent, finding a great path is fun and satisfying. However, the jump and rope swings are horrible, you cannot change direction in mid air, the jump feels floppy, too. The graphic looks great.. Though some maps are repeated with different goal, the map is big and rich enough to appreciate.

I also like the humour (and the coarse language) - some may find it offensive, but hearing "Can't tell whether Styx is standing or clawing" made me laugh. This game gives a clear waypoint, most time I do not lose the leads, some levels acquires player to trace blood or follow the trolley tracks to find destination, and in a cave of labyrinth it can take several wrong turns before escaping it, it brings some creativity, and the 6 trials are well designed. There is no real fight within the bosses, rather, Styx does damage through indirect way like breaking the connections of the Quartze power.

I set the game to the easiest difficulty but still find it is hard. Even harder in later games when Styx can't do any damage to an armored enemy, even within clone ability and being invisible for a short period, I still retried several times because of instant death like fall damage and spikes. What keeps me going is the story, the interesting maps and wanting to see how it ends. 

Styx is definitely not for everyone, it is painful yet rewarding. I finished the game in 8 hours, story is okay but it does not end. If there will be any sequel, I will try only if the devs make it easier.

review: Une réussite malgré quelques rares passages que je n'ai pas aimé. Les niveaux sont aussi inspirés qu'ils sont agréables à l'oeil et possèdent beaucoup de passages alternatifs, ce qui fera la part belle à l'infiltration, il y aura même des manières secondaires de réaliser des objectifs principaux, parfois assez drôles d'ailleurs. l'histoire est plaisante à suivre, propose des rebondissements inattendus le tout servi par un doubleur aussi impliqué que sur le premier épisode, même les 'game over' sont originaux. Le gameplay lui aussi s'est amélioré et globalement je n'ai que très rarement pesté contre un saut raté, on est très loin des approximations de Styx 1. Au moment de cette évaluation je ne suis qu'à 55% du jeu, et je dois avouer que j'y retourne à chaque fois avec plaisir, ce petit gobelin irrévérencieux en deviendrait presque attachant.

author: {'steamid': '76561198934055529', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 13, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1712332000}
review:
J'ai finis le jeu en 11h (15h de jeu actuellement car j'ai fais quelques missions avec un ami) en difficulté gobelin, grossomodo Styx: shards of darkness est un bon jeu d'infiltration qui comparé à son opus précédent, apporte de nouvelles mécaniques tel que; joué en coopération (en ligne uniquement), un système de craft qui amène encore plus à l'exploration des niveaux et laisse imaginer de nouvelles stratégies, un arbre de compétences bien plus évolué et évidemment, des graphismes ainsi qu'un gameplay et game design bien plus poussé.
En clair, la durée de vie du jeu est très réduite si comme moi vous avez fait le premier opus juste avant de commencer shards of darkness (puisque l'approche des niveaux reste la même) sinon je pense que la durée de vie du jeu est doublé (20h environ) malgré ceci, le fait d'avoir joué au premier opus rend le deuxieme d'autant plus apprécié puisqu'on y voit alors toute l'amélioration et les clins d'oeil par rapport à Styx: master of shadows.
En conclusion, si vous cherchez un jeu d'infiltration dans des niveaux ouverts qui vous pousse à l'exploration et à l'ingéniosité de votre approche, je vous conseille Styx (le premier et deuxieme opus).

author: {'steamid': '76561199224559114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1060, 'last_played': 1653990952}
review:
[h1]Adoro[/h1]
Fantastico. Sgattaiolare nell'ombra senza essere notati, risolvere enigmi, superare prove e vivere avventure nei panni di Styx è sempre emozionante. La storia è molto bella, le cutscenes sono bellissime e la personalità di Styx rende il gioco ancora più divertente. 
La grafica è pulita così come lo sono le animazioni. Una colonna sonora che ben si accosta alla tipologia stealth del titolo e che incornicia alla perfezione le vicende del protagonista. 
Un finale molto aperto che lascia ben sperare in un nuovo capitolo della saga (ci spero tantissimo perché adoro Styx). 
La rigiocabilità è quasi infinita per via dei modi con cui approcciare ogni missione (anche se la storia è sempre la stessa) dando un sapore diverso ad ogni playthrough.
La difficoltà massima del gioco richiede un impegno particolare (a volte sembra impossibile) per cui vi consiglio il magico tasto "f5" per il salvataggio rapido da spammare ogni volta che supererete un ostacolo.
Quasi dimenticavo.. le mini cutscenes che partiranno ogni volta che morirete sono una vera chicca.
Per quella che è stata la mia esperienza di gioco, posso dirmi soddisfattissimo dell'acquisto e curioso di scoprire quali meraviglie porterà il prossimo capitolo della saga di Styx.
Voto finale: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198106327229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1673, 'last_played': 1653988679}
review:
较第一部画质、游戏性、趣味性和操控性均有进一步提升，每个任务均有超过三种完成办法，活用手头的碎瓶子、沙子、地图中的各种装置可以轻松在不开启隐身的情况下不被发现的溜遍全图。
主角是个哥布林，因此只有偷袭才有优势，正面战斗弱的多，总体来说是个动脑多过动手的潜行类游戏，相对可能硬核了一点，期待第三部。
技能树很灵活，如果点出的技能不理想可以无消耗取消去尝试新的技能。克隆体是最有意思的地方，刚开始基本没用，随着技能的升级，克隆体可以当活动炸弹、诱饵甚至即时存档来使用，升满级的哥布林才是真正的暗影大师，无声无息抹掉全图活物的存在。

author: {'steamid': '76561198075326661', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1153, 'last_played': 1652724802}
review: The game itself is good, but there are a few flaws, and while I generally recommend this game, you have to be ready for a few things. For once, the enemies gonna bug, a bit too many times, especially if they notice you and alarm, but even if they doesnt, in full-stealth its rarely noticeable (tho ofc it can happen that an enemy bugs at the door you want to get thru), and if you plan to play it in co-op, you will face some bugs as well (like if all of you die and load the last save, all of the collectables are back for the non-host player. And sometimes the jumping mechanic is a bit weird/non-working (jumping or falling into your death just because you didnt catch something, while your face was like 10 cm away from it), but apart from those the game itself is great, the maps are beautiful and really big ones, doing everything in stealth is really a good feeling, and as the game advances the game gonna give you more and more tools for it, and while the story itself is not really the star of the game, styx's personality is pretty good imo, I like him at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561199080301723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1677141472}
review:
Not too bad, a little short but fun for what it is. Yes Master of Shadows was more story driven and done that part better but i knew what was happening and what the overall mission was. It's not like you have no idea what Styx is trying to accomplish. If they cut corners on the story/cut scenes to focus more on the gameplay side of things, so be it.
You do return to some of the same areas at different times for different reasons, diving deeper/further into them each time which i didnt mind at all. Most of the time, it was a new area within the area so to speak.
If your PC can handle high settings, it looks pretty damn good. I had to drop to weak on all with only textures on medium and even then, it STILL looked amazing.

Worth a play through, i personally didnt find much/if any replay value after one run through tho.

author: {'steamid': '76561198362117159', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 819, 'last_played': 1652264949}
review:
汉化往下看↓
[h1] 哥布林杀手 [/h1]
       同前作一样，你扮演的仍然是一个脆皮哥布林（[url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198362117159/recommended/242640/] 前作评测 [/url]）
       本作主角从人类变成了精灵，虽然加入了一些新种族与敌人 ，但大部分关卡都是精灵关卡，值得一提的是，前作精灵的琥珀感知能力没有了（被矮人的鼻子取代了），[spoiler] 精灵头头有这个能力，可惜最后也没跟他打 [/spoiler]。
       时隔三年，游戏画面有了不小的进步，[strike] 其实我感觉差不多 [/strike]，但是剧情以及游戏机制都没前作打磨的好，像前作每一个技能都有用武之地，而这部从头到尾，有些技能我都没用过几次，剧情上好坏参半吧，很多坑没填就算了，最后cg草草了事，[spoiler] 扎拉克那么会算计一个人结果突然就死了 [/spoiler]，抛开这些不好的，其他的剧情还行，当然剧情有很多还是续接了第一部，比如地精灾难啊，后面的琥珀机器等等。
[h1] 地图设计 [/h1]
       本作取消了地图，实际上我觉得地图是前作非常好的一个设计，可惜取消了，取消了地图之后，地图的设计就十分重要了，只能说我玩的时候感觉很难受
[h1] 游戏机制 [/h1]
       较前作新增了一些道具以及制作功能，虽然玩法变多了，但是实用性挺小的，同时还加入了合作模式，可能当时想吃联机红利？对于这个合作模式，仁者见仁智者见智吧。新增了换装选项，以及很多支线和徽章，感觉有些支线是强加的，很难受，还不如前作的收集品，徽章就是正常那些徽章，[strike] 鄙视仁慈徽章 [/strike]，建议别仁慈，剧情后面会刀你，再说了不杀人叫刺客吗
[h1] 汉化补丁 [/h1]
       汉化补丁教程感谢名叫凤翼的大佬，补丁选择3dm的3.0补丁，删除原来的存档（我是第一次玩的时候就安装了），关闭云存档，然后打补丁，进游戏储存一下，退出来打开云存档就行了，[url=https://dl.3dmgame.com/patch/99177.html] 补丁链接 [/url]
[h1] 推荐 [/h1]
       较为推荐，玩了前作想接续作的可以在打折时候入手。
[h1] 结语 [/h1]
       每个人在玩的时候的感受不一样，没有评测可以取代你自己，所有评测都是参考，不要陷进评测里！

author: {'steamid': '76561198010177324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1652085223}
review:
A little of that Eurojank, but still a really solid stealth centric game. I still wish the amber usage was a bit less stingy so styx could feel a bit more powerful, but the constant reminder that a kill was diminishing my skill points at the end made me understand that to get very powerful i'd need to play ghost for most of it.
The game is a pretty solid AA game and I think a next one could make this series a lot more fun if they work on letting styx use his powers more often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056068208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1654563222}
review:
Only a few hours in but it is clear they really upped their game from the previous Styx Master of Shadows, Visuals look way better with a nice graphical upgrade. Styx controls way smoother; they cleaned up ledge grabbing and ledge dropping, and Styx climbs over and onto obstacles way faster. The skill tree is more robust. UI is more snappy and informative; you'll get updates on your progress as it happens, for example if you are going for speed runs you'll get 'Gold' 'Silver' and 'Bronze' pop up indications on screen in real time, same applies if you are spotted, or when you find treasure.
The only thing I might find myself being annoyed at is they really kicked up Styx's quips with frequent 4th-wall-breaking, pop culture and movie references...it's a big immersion breaking but a minor complaint.

Great upgrade from the previous entry, stealth fans should be pleased. And again here is hoping Arkail stops being neglected and gets his solo game too.

review:
Игра не то, чтобы не удалась, но после первой части серии ощущения полностью испорчены. Первая часть хоть и на один раз, но там чувствовалась атмосфера, было +- интересно играть, а тут даже этого "вполне интересно" просто нету.

review:
Fortemente consigliato a tutti quelli che amano i giochi stealth, ma sono stufi dei soliti Assassin's Creed e simili. Per tutti gli amanti del fantasy e dei protagonisti anticonvenzionali e antieroi. Paesaggi mozzafiato, acrobazie e fughe rocambolesche, omicidi e furti in pieno stile goblin. Più bello del capitolo precedente ( Styx Master Of Shadows) ti prende e ti porta ad intraprendere sfide che ti lasciano col fiato sospeso facendoti analizzare con occhio critico tutto l'ambiente circostante per sfruttarlo a tuo vantaggio. E poi Styx è troppo simaptico, fa un sacco di citazioni nerd, rompe la 4 barriera ed interagisce direttamente con te ed è impossibile non amarlo! Secondo me un titolo da non perdere, aspetto con ansia un sequel.

PS: Sono gia due volte che lo finisco, e mi sono divertito anche più della prima!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043903494', 'num_games_owned': 1086, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1649605156}
review:
Despite being a smooth stealth platformer game, it's one of the worst stealth games I ever played.

Pros:
+ Great graphics
+ Runs and feels smooth moving around
+ Gets very cheap on sales

Cons:
- No way to non-lethally knock down enemies, making stealth cancer to go through if you aiming for no detection run
- very limited tools to use and the few items you can use aren't always useful especially if you don't want to lose the "no-kill" medal of each level
- enemies can see you even if your are hiding in shadows
- enemies can see you from far away
- combat is pretty much useless
- the game nature is extremely trial-and-error, and it punishes you for not being perfectionist

Splinter Cell, Dishonored, MGS, and Hitman are far better games than this

author: {'steamid': '76561198231656648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1648785364}
review:
First and foremost I enjoyed the game over all. While I didn't strictly understand where the story was going to start with, it was fairly decent. Over all any complaints I have boil down to the game not being as good as the first. The maps weren't as interesting, and I didn't feel the darkness was as well utilized. Levels just seemed to be more brightly lit in ways you couldn't extinguish, and I found sticking to the shadows didn't serve me as well as simply hiding behind things. Didn't like the Mercy and Swiftness Insignias at the end of missions, but that's mostly a "me" thing. Swiftness is just because I don't like to feel rushed; prefering to take my time, watch patrol patterns, pick my moment, that sort of thing. Mercy I don't mind as a concept, but as it has no real lore or mechanical benefit besides a few more Skill Points it just feels like self-imposed additional difficulty. As always I appreciated the verticality of the levels, the ability to get from point A to B by going high or low, crawling along ledges and hiding under tables. Always been one of my favourite parts of both games. Abilities worked well and were very useful, some more so than I'd realized until after post game achievement replays. Game isn't overtly long (which I appreciate), but has good replay value. Didn't get to try the co-op. Music was nice, but not as good as the first game. 

My two most major gripes are as follows. One was the 4th wall breaking references and banter. I don't mind them, and enjoyed them plenty in the previous game. There was just a LOT of them this time. Too many. In a lot of ways the game felt like the developers misunderstood what made Master of Shadows a good game, and wound up focusing on the wrong things. The other major complaint are boss battles, particularly the final boss battles. Both in Master of Shadows and Shards of Darkness, the final boss battle is awful. Just an over all terrible experience that is stressful not because the boss is hard or exciting, but because it's mechanically bad. The boss in Shards of Darkness did get better after the opening bit, but still largely consisted not of needing to be stealthy of tricky, but running around hoping you'd be behind cover in time or die instantly. Which just isn't fun. (This said I do understand boss battles in Stealth games are notoriously difficulty to get right.).

Over all I enjoyed the game. About a 7/10. 8 if I'm being generous. Master of Shadows was a 9. Rating based less on the quality and more on my enjoyment of the games. Which really, how much you enjoy yourself is what matters with these things. 

Short version: Fun game. Worth Playing. Hope we one day see a third entry in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198198467937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1648237674}
review:
Sinceramente, encuentro que la primera entrega tenía una narrativa mucho más interesante. No obstante, esta entrega pule muchos de los aspectos que hacían al título anterior sentirse más propio de la pasada generación.

Destacan los movimientos más fluidos y las nuevas opciones para distraer a enemigos. Realmente hace uso de las mecánicas de sigilos y el árbol de habilidades es mucho más amplio que el anterior. Los "bosses" la incorporación de los tesoros como objetos jugables son un toque a agradecer, aunque creo que podrían haber incorporado mecánicas no tan vistas. Con todo, todo cuanto ha hecho el equipo de desarrollo lo ha ejecutado notablemente y aprecio mucho el esfuerzo. 

Cualquier crítica que pueda vertir es "peccata minuta". Un título de sigilo y fantasía oscura... qué más se puede pedir. 100% recomendable y más la precio de la tienda (prácticamente regalado)... ¡y spoiler free!.

Sinceramente me he enamorado del trago y quisiera verlo regresar  con muchas más de sus aventuras y desventuras.  ¡Que Akenash esté con vosotros!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013875223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2020, 'last_played': 1648228902}
review:
The previous game, "Styx: Master of Shadows", had a little clunky mechanics (you'd often fail to grab on to ledges, and fall to your death), but the story was great and Styx's voice actor was simply amazing. The game was a real hidden gem. In this follow-up, "Shards of Darkness", the amazing voice actor returns and the game mechanics feel more polished (fewer failed ledge grabs), but unfortunately the story itself falls completely flat. Enemy placement is also a bit less enjoyable.

The Good:
[list]
    [*]A great assassin/sneak-around-and-murder game
    [*]Fewer failed jumps than in the predecessor
    [*]Good voice acting
[/list]

The Bad:
[list]
    [*]The story. Quick spoiler: [spoiler] The game ends abruptly, with basically all threads of the story hanging loose. A sudden fade to black, and the credits roll. My guess is that they ran out of money and had to scrap the last part of the game. Or they planned for a sequel, which never came. [/spoiler]
    [*]The character of Styx. In the prequel he felt like a more complex character, and you really felt for him. In this game greed and revenge (which doesn't feel believable) is all that motivates him. He feels stupid.
    [*]Though levels can look pretty spectacular, the layouts of the different areas don't really feel logical/believable. They're basically mazes built to be cool to sneak and climb around in, but the placement of houses/rooms feel pretty random.
    [*]There are so many heavily armoured guards (that can't easily be killed) in this game compared to the predecessor, that 100%-ing the levels by killing everything no longer feel fun or even possible. Eventually I just grew tired and chose to try and finish the levels as quickly as possible instead.
[/list]

Conclusion:
If you have not yet played "Master of Shadows", go play it instead. If you have played it and just want more Styx, sure go ahead, but only if you don't care much about story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198411273988', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1076, 'last_played': 1647285355}
review:
Alles in Allem ein sehr schön gestaltetes Spiel, jedoch ist die Kürze ein wenig enttäuschend. Ich habe es jetzt in 17,4 Stunden mit einem Freund im Koop (großes Danke an der Stelle, alleine wäre nur halb so lustig gewesen) durchgespielt. Wir sind roundabout zwar 100 mal verreckt, hatten aber trotzdem viel Spaß. Es ist ein super Stealth-Meuchel-Game mit vielen lustigen Anspielungen, Stichwort: I´ll be back. Ich hätte mich über noch ein oder zwei andere Leveldesigns und auch noch drei bis vier Kapitel gefreut. 

Abschließend ist zu sagen, dass das Spiel seine 20 Euro wert ist. 
Für knifflige Abende voller Spaß und mit reichlich Humor, eignet es sich perfekt.
(Man sollte allerdings einige Pausen einlegen, da es sehr anstrengend ist.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198017676789', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1647255985}
review:
Easily recommended if you like stealth games on a sale. It's not amazing, but when it comes to stealth games, you don't really much choice, and this game is easily worth the discounted price. 

I bought the game for 4€ and finished the game on the third hardest setting with no alarms and no kills, not counting the side objectives which the game doesn't count either.
The game's level design is the best part, it's pretty diverse from the rundown shanty town to the underground city. There's lots of different ways to reach your objective, same as in the first Styx game. 
While the movement and more importantly the jumping does feel better, it's not perfect, I've had a few instances where Styx didn't really jump where I wanted him to, or bumped into some kind of invisible wall and I had to reload.
The skills system is very boring as far as non-lethal stealth goes. There's the clone rebirth skill which is essential to finish the game, and the perception tree allows you to see the collectibles through walls, although I didn't bother going out of my way to collect them.
The story and the characters are complete garbage, but that's not really why I play these games in the first place. 
The repeating levels are a thing, but maybe because I went through the game relatively quickly it didn't really bother me. It was nice to see the levels in a different light.

review:
Fun stealth game. When you use your skill points, there is no penalty for resetting them. To get all the skill points, you need to do 2 runs through each mission. One where you can kill everything and explore and find all the tokens. For this run I would use all skill points on the various assassination and similar skills. The second run is to get the time achievement and a few more skill points. For this run, I would use all the amber and invisibility skills.

I didn't like that the final ultimate skill is unlocked when you finish the final mission so there is no use for it at all. You unlock it when you have finished the game every which way and are done with the replay value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998920982', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 921, 'last_played': 1646803024}
review:
A fun yet flawed stealth game about being a sneaky evil goblin. There are minor improvements over the previous Styx title (Master of Shadows), such as smoother movement and interfaces. Like its predecessor, the later levels feature the same maps as the first levels in reverse. It is a shorter game, so the repetitive levels don't outstay their welcome, although the game overall feels incomplete.

Shards of Darkness is also easier. Stealth sections have few guards to avoid. Character upgrades can be maxed out quickly, and resource management is trivial because the maps are littered with raw crafting materials.

Pros:
+ Goblin protagonist. Styx is rude, crude, and entertaining.
+ The upgrade tree allows experimentation with different ability combinations. The clone teleportation powers reward the player for planning their routes in advance, and the crafting system rewards exploration. 
+ Large, nonlinear levels that allow for many routes. Enemies have distinct abilities (sight, sound, proximity, even smell) that add variety to stealth gameplay.

Cons:
- The story is messy and unfinished, as if cut during development or the writers simply gave up. Events and character motives are inconsistent. Some missions offer choices like betrayal or revenge, but no consequences or follow-up. The game's ending is sudden and gives no closure nor indication of a sequel.
- Non sequitur boss fights that seem out of place for a stealth game. 
- The new rope-swinging mechanic is fiddly and annoying to control. Most of these ropes can be avoided by taking other paths.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023845002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1646017858}
review:
Shards of Darkness, like it's predecessor (Master of Shadows) is a competent 3rd person stealth game, perhaps best likened to the Hitman series crossed with the Prince of Persia reboots.  The challenge is slowly ramped up during the campaign, adding enemies who cannot be subdued, enemies who can hear you even in the normal 'stealth' movement mode, and even foes who can smell you if you're nearby.
Impressively, despite a relatively challenging start as the player gets into this, the difficulty ramp is not too aggressive, and you won't find the steps too punishing.
However, 2 boss fights in the game, both which focus on the platforming element, are considerably more brutal, these require most of the action to be completed without death, and the games platforming, particularly while under fire, doesn't fit well with that.

Music and sound effects are good throughout, with a particularly great soundtrack. Speech however is a mixed bag.  Styx himself is a fourth-wall breaking smart-arse, who will regularly muse to the player about what he sees (or downright call them out when he dies), but most of the other dialogue, unfortunately particularly during the story cut-scenes, are terribly delivered, with the actors sounding like they can have never seen the words in front of them before.
That's a shame, because the story itself is remarkably compelling.   It's hardly deep, but it has some nice touches, although oddly for an Assassin turned Thief, Styx is bizarrely trusting of people who have no reason not to betray him.   That said, he is just as willing to forget about characters entirely without comment.

Fortunately the gameplay and artwork make up for these mis-steps.  the character models, level art and cutscene quality are all incredible, and the level design is open, with multiple routes to most destinations.  What's more the game openly encourages both exploration and replayability.   Several levels are reused, as the second half of the game retreads the same areas as the first half, but new objectives, collectables and enemy types mean this is more like an alternate take on the level, rather than a simple retreading.

Overall the game feels like a B movie, the budget wasn't huge, but the end result is surprisingly competent.   The rough corners (dialogue and some odd story beats) are more than made up for by the excellent art and well executed gameplay.  Even where the game struggles, it mostly does so by trying to push its own boundaries, and it can be forgiven for attempting to mix up the dynamic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141039643', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1652757456}
review: Styx: SoD is a fantasy through and through, yet it has a weirdly unique feel compared to the multitudes of samey-feeling fantasy games. The game presents you with a lot of fascinating settings and ideas that you don't really get to explore due to the overall nonchalance of the main character, Styx, so I'd say the game screams for a spinoff or sequel. Styx is a filthy little goblin with an endearing, if profane, personality who gives humor to an otherwise grim universe. In terms of gameplay, Styx is definitely worth a look if you're a fiend for stealth games. Styx provides you with a massive skill tree and the ability to acquire and use crafting resources during levels to make tools of murder, distraction, and otherwise. With magic/amber capabilities as well, Styx gives you a wide arsenal of stealth tools that provide for a number of playstyles. My main complaint is that some of the animations and textures aren't that great, but when you play through the game you realize that's because they likely overextended. Each level feels huge with tons of collectables, side-objectives, and maybe secrets. Also, Styx offers a genuinely good coop mode, so consider getting with a friend. I'd give it a 7 or 8 out of 10, and I'd love to see more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006841071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4612, 'last_played': 1708949056}
review:
Like Styx: Master of Shadows I really enjoyed this game. In the beginning, it can be a little harsh, but after a short while you will have gotten used to what you can do and what you can't do without being seen or being detected or getting caught and it will be tons of fun. I got all the achivements and I really liked it.

In one single mission there is a point, where there should be an automatic save, but there isn't. You won't really notice this, unless you play on the highest difficulty, where all other saves except for autosaves are disabled.
Other than that the game is bug free as far as I can remember.

Potential spoiler warning:
The story was cool, but the way it ended really surprised me and was kind of weird and unexpected.
It felt really off.


I really enjoyed it and would buy another Styx game anytime.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991103051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 252, 'playtime_forever': 3030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3030, 'last_played': 1644776859}
review:
Despite its flaws, I was still going to recommend this game to stealth fans. However, the ending is just such a kick in the mouth that I cant in good faith recommend an unfinished game.

The game mechanics and level design or both fantastic and really give this game the variable it needed to stand out among other stealth games. That being said, there are a number of issues which lead to Styx being an underwhelming experience. I have listed this issues below in no particular order:

1- The RPG elements of the skill tree make no sense to me. I think this game would be far better if they placed the usable items in the levels instead of crafting materials to make those items. It seems like they just put it in to be able to say their game has crafting elements even though they dont actually contribute to the game and actually takes away from the fun and engagement the game has to offer. There also isnt a whole lot of choice here as youll quickly end up getting every skill you would deem even remotely usable.

2- Characters are lifeless and seem to be pulled straight out of a mediocre ps2 game. You will not like any of these characters because they have no development or character to like. They may as well have been cardboard cut outs.

3- Stealth vs killing. The game encourages you to not kill people and to complete each mission without being seen. Makes sense in a stealth game and an aspect that I liked a lot. That being said, everything else about this game is just trying to get you to be a murder hobo. Why bother playing this game as a stealth game when you can just go in guns a blazing? There is a "killing" skill tree yet every other skill try is half full of skills improving your killing capabilities. Why bother having a skill tree dedicated to killing -especially knowing you are encouraging people to not kill- then fill up half of the remaining skill trees with kill skills??? Why not give me skill trees that give me more abilities to be a stealth character??

4- The levels are well designed and engaging until half way through the game when they make you replay the 5 levels you just played for "story reasons". What a kick in the mouth from lazy game devs.

5- speaking of lazy game devs, the story is dogshit. Probably the worst story I have seen in a game like this which is a real shame because theres so much potential with the characters and setting. To illustrate what I mean all I need to do is tell you the story is left on a cliffhanger with character allegiances changing for no reasons and everything youve done or worked up to till the end is just dropped without a care in the world. I would have still recommended this game if it wasnt for this ending. Seriously, fuck these devs. As a matter of fact because of this, not only will I not recommend this game, I will never be purchasing or recommending anything by Cyanide Studio. Go fuck yourselves you lazy lazy lazy pieces of trash. 

Theres more issues with this game but any left are pretty minor compared to the issues I had above. Such a disappointment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062467087', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1773, 'last_played': 1644514838}
review:
J'étais partie pour lui mettre une évaluation négative, à chaud après y avoir joué. Je déteste ne pas apprécier une œuvre, souvent je lui trouve des excuses, je me dis que c'était juste pas mon jeu. Mais quand le jeu est truffé de bugs à chaque mission ça commence à peser. Pourtant j'ai pris le temps de le 100% et j'y ai en grande majorité pris du plaisir... De la persévérance ou de la débilité, qui sait.

Donc vous l'aurez compris, le gros problème de ce jeu sont les bugs. Partout. Je sais pas si je suis la seule personne au monde à en avoir eu en solo (parce qu'en coop apparemment c'était pas la folie mais en solo ça allait), mais là c'était vraiment insupportable. Les ennemis étaient alertés... Alors que je n'étais pas là ? Et non ce n'était pas à cause d'un cadavre puisque toutes les missions je les faisais dès le début en clémence (0 ennemi tué) et en discrétion (0 alerte donnée). Dans une mission, il y a des petites altercations entre les ennemis. Donc on les voit être alertés, même si ça ne nous concerne pas. Alors une fois je suis sortie de ma cachette puisque l'alerte n'était pas de moi, lorsque tout à coup je vois l'elfe se détourner de sa cible pour venir me voir... Et pourtant il y avait toujours 0 alerte dans les statistiques. Et j'ai été tué.

J'ai eu aussi pas mal de bugs sur le trajet des ennemis, notamment autour des quartz. Je devais en prendre un, et l'ennemi restait devant à prier, sans jamais bouger. J'ai regardé une vidéo pour voir si c'était normal, non ça ne l'était pas. Un autre quartz, tous les ennemis se mettent à faire leur promenade habituel, et y en a un, qui fait deux pas, se tourne bizarrement, deux pas, fait un 360, recule, deux pas, tout ça autour du quartz dont j'ai besoin. Un autre, la personne prie, puis fait du surplace, comme bloquée, mais sans aucun obstacle. Recharger la partie ou relancer le jeu ne changeait rien. Merci les clones, pas merci les dévs', le jeu a bientôt cinq ans, mais j'imagine que maintenant c'est trop tard pour en avoir quelque chose à faire. Les quartz ont dû être ajouté à la dernière minute, c'est pas possible autrement.

Alors ouais ce sont des quêtes secondaires, mais comme pour la coop, c'est pas parce que c'est optionnel qu'il faut que ça soit fait avec le cul.

Et ça me déprime parce que le jeu en lui-même est vraiment bien, l'infiltration est bien faite en dehors des bugs, difficile sans être insurmontable, il faut être attentif et patient. Il est meilleur que le premier au niveau du game design et des maps, et même au niveau des dialogues. J'aurais vraiment aimé mettre un avis positif pleinement assumé, mais j'attire les bugs et je les subis vraiment lorsqu'ils sont aussi importants. C'est uniquement parce que les jeux Styx sont uniques que je décide de mettre une évaluation positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027077441', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 952, 'last_played': 1644286354}
review:
[h1]Alright, but Likely Not Worth Your Time[/h1]

I just want to preface - this game is [b]good, just not fantastic[/b]. And in a gaming world saturated with content, I just don't personally think one is worth the time.

Let's start on a high note: [b]the good[/b]. This game knows what it is. It's a stealth game and plays like a stealth game. Face-to-face combat is impossible, but that's okay because you shouldn't be getting caught anyway. Each level is pretty sprawling and has some cleverly designed areas to explore. You're almost always given a direct route through enemies, but you're also encouraged to find some other way to get to your destination. Exploring and successfully routing around enemy paths is satisfying, and there are even some unique rewards you can get for finding and completing side quests while exploring some levels, although it's rare. The in-game graphics are surprisingly pretty, and there's even a good sense of aesthetic and world-building in this gritty little adventure. Styx as a character is a witty, nihilistic, fourth-wall-breaking ball of charm which really added to the flavor of the game.

My biggest complaint of Styx is that [b]the game is plagued with tedium & repetition.[/b] You'll find yourself pretty amazed in the first few levels, only to discover [b]you'll repeat those same levels for the rest of the game[/b]. They only really circumvent this by opening up different areas, changing around objectives, etc., but it wasn't enough for me, and I quickly found myself bored with the repeated designs. Even when they would introduce a new level, the general objective was always the same: go point A to point B to point C and leave the level. Ultimately, this is why I have to draw the line - [b]it just wasn't worth the time & money for me[/b]. There are much better and more expansive games out there in the genre.

The repetition was by far my biggest complaint, but not my only one. The game does try to add some spice via RPG elements - crafting, leveling, and customization. These were nice to have, but I would've liked to see some more clever or impacting items. See also: lackluster voice acting (aside from Styx), [i]terrible[/i] cutscenes & animations, tedious & out-of-place boss designs, little feeling of progression, convoluted and abruptly ending story.

I think I'll be keeping watch for any subsequent games in the series, but I'll also be looking for vast improvements in the areas I just mentioned before I would consider buying it. As for this one, I wouldn't personally bother, but if it's cheap you may find it worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095263665', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 407, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1643906440}
review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness is the sequel to Styx: Master of Shadows, and like its predecessor, it's a third-person stealth game where combat is discouraged, using the same parrying system as before. Most of Styx's abilities and items stay the same, making players of the first game feel familiar already. However, there are new features that made the game feel more fresh, like crafting, alternate costumes and some new features to powers. In many ways, it is better than the first game, which was just "okay" for me and annoying quite often. And it's not just the graphics that made the world and characters look amazing.

First of all, what makes this game a lot better is the stealth gameplay. It is a lot easier than the first game. There's considerably less enemies, and they are less perceptive as well, making a no-kill, no-detection run easy and fun, whereas in the first game it's very difficult, even on the lowest difficulty. The paths to the objectives also have more alternate options, like other good stealth games do. There's still no option to knockout enemies, but with the easier stealth approach it's not really needed. One might argue it adds a bit of challenge without making it exhausting.

The second is the level design. The levels look beautiful and more fantasy-esque, we explore different areas such as a shantytown and a cliffside fortress inhabited by elves, a great step from the boring "generic fantasy castles" in the first game. It still suffers from the same problem as the first game, where some of the levels are just reusing previous levels with different objectives, but it turned that weakness into strength. The objectives in the revisited areas are different, making us explore parts of the map usually unexplored or inaccessible during the first visit, and giving us a bit of a head start with familiarity to some parts of the map. There are also boss fights, and no way around those. Worry not, they are fought by moving around and interacting with items and not one-on-one combat. The first boss is interesting, however the 2nd one is annoying and basically just "rush to the end" kind of level. 

The third are characters. Other than Styx, who is still funny and makes meta references, there are more important humans, elves, and dwarves, with each their own unique design and personality, making the game feel more colorful and fantasy-like. Sadly, some of these characters are not developed enough and only appeared briefly, which is a shame because they could be better allies or enemies and adds more importance to the game's story and world. Because of this the story feels bland, and the abrupt, cliffhanger ending doesn't help.

S:SoD still has the skill tree feature and a home base to replay missions, as well as insignias for the levels, but it's more forgiving because it acts more like a gold medal. You can still get the "undetected" medal if you were detected several times, but it will be silver or bronze, and you receive less skill points. Same goes will the other medals. No-kill and undetected medals are the easiest ones to get, and is the way to play the game, so consider getting gold on those.

My main issue with this gameplay is the lack of map. While it's no big deal since the maps are useless in the first game and there are quest markers, it would be useful when you're doing a collectible hunt. Another minor, pet peeve issue of mine is how the achievements look. So generic, similar, and boring. The first game does this better by making each achievement having a unique look.

Styx: Shards of Darkness is a great stealth game, and although it's not an immersive sim like Dishonored or Thief, it's still a decent game. If you played the first one and wondering if you should buy the sequel, buy it, as it's a lot better than the first and a bit longer as well, with improved stealth that made it fun. However I do recommend playing Styx: Master of Shadows first, as the events there are referred to here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198398679068', 'num_games_owned': 733, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1642282994}
review:
La suite des aventures de Styx, avec pas mal de nouveautés et de rebondissements. On y trouve des environnements plutôt variés mais malheureusement toujours des allés et venus dans ces mêmes zones... Un panel d'ennemis plus variés et cohérents, des musiques toujours aussi bonnes, un scénario globalement d'aussi bonne qualité que le premier opus mais malheureusement une fin aussi décevante que pour son prédécesseur... Il y a aussi plusieurs nouvelles de nouvelles mécaniques comme le craft, la personnalisation de l'équipement, de nouvelles capacités pour Styx, de nouveaux gadgets,... 
Pour faire simple, c'est le même que le premier opus mais avec un nouveau scénario, de nouveaux environnements et un paquet de nouveauté et améliorations. Et c'est tout ce qu'on lui demande, pourquoi changer une formule qui fonctionne très bien. 

Si vous avez aimé le premier ou que vous aimez les jeux d'infiltrations, foncez sur cette suite.

author: {'steamid': '76561198247855922', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1641568245}
review:
В сравнении с первой частью, Стикс стал лучше. Но, как говорится, всё относительно. 

Прокачка скиллов стала обширнее и ветвистее, однако, если присмотреться, то по итогу мы имеем лишь парочку новых умений. Большая часть из них это те же, что и были, только раздробленные на большее количество. Разве что появилась ветка алхимии и простенькая система крафта. В плане геймплея вообще ничего не поменялось. Я не строил никаких ожиданий, покупая вторую часть Стикса, но, тем не менее, всю игру меня не покидало ощущение, что я просто поставил моды на первую. Графика очень радует глаз, работа художников, дизайнеров персонажей и левел-дизайнеров очень радует, за что им респект. Но вот синематики с сюжетными диалогами... ну, скажем, топорные и корявенькие. Касаемо сюжета - есть ощущение, что он здесь для галочки. Мне очень понравился концпет первой части, поэтому и в этой я старался вникать, читать все диалоги и описания во время загрузок. Но по итогу сюжет меня, скажем, не очень порадовал. У игр подобного рода, "атракционных" игр,  есть определённая формула - это не скайрим или фалаут, в которых бегай куда хочешь и делай квесты в любом порядке, это не платформер или файтинг, где сюжет не имеет значения, это линейная игра, где продвижение в игре и смысл твоих действий вертятся вокруг сюжета, твой персонаж имеет цель. Как говорится, имеет какую-то тактику и ты её придерживаешься. И исходя из этого, хорошо бы для такого рода игры иметь затягивающий и хорошо поданный сюжет. Здесь он подаётся как-то очень торопливо и резко что-ли. Всегда есть ощущение, будто бы что-то забыли рассказать, будто бы между "я хочу убить этого эльфа" и "я помогаю ему освободить его народ" не хватает хотя бы парочки диалогов. И так всю игру, взаимоотношения и мотивацию персонажей оставляют за кулисами, как будто бы очень торопятся куда-то. При этом сама сюжетная структура хороша, здесь есть интересные твисты, интриги, конфликты, отсылки на предыдущую часть и даже иногда мотивация героев :)  Однако чаще всего я просто сидел с покерфейсом и не понимал, когда сюжет успел так лихо перевернуться исполнив тройную сальтуху. Концовка так и вообще грянула так внезапно, что я сначала даже не поверил. По ощущениям ещё пол игры было впереди. Тут уже не важно, в чём именно проблема - в плохо сделанных CGI сценах, или в сюжетных дырах, или в поджимающих сроках и финансах, или неправильным расположением звёзд на небе... главное, что по итогу это оставляет впечатление "проходняковой" игры. 
Справедливости ради, свою дозу удовольствия от игры я получил. Большие нелинейные локации, красивые пейзажи и всё тот же харизматичный, ворчливый и эгоистичный му**к Стикс. Однако кроме графики и более разговорчивого ракаша ничего нового эта игра не привнесла, как в жанр, так и во франшизу. Интересный, но непонятный и рваный сюжет, ничего нового в сравнении со старой игрой в плане геймплея. Красивые локации, но несколько из них нужно будет тупо проходить в обратном направлении. И всё это счастье стоит 700 РОССИЙСКИХ ДОЛЛАРОВ!!!1! Покупал по очень большой скидке обе игры сразу, по обычной цене игра своих денег не стоит. Рекомендую её тем, кто уже знаком со Стиксом и, возможно, играл в первую часть. На любимого персонажа посмотреть всегда приятно. Тем, кто не знаком с ворчливым гоблином-шутником рекомендую, как игру на пару вечеров, но больших ожиданий строить не стоит.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156300190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2711, 'last_played': 1689654062}
review: I played Styx: Master of Shadows due to a longing for another stealth game experience beyond the Dishonored series (Which I have played obsessively) and the Assassin's Creed series (Which I was becoming bored of). After playing through it I fell in love with not just the character Styx but the playstyle and the entire concept of playing against people in a whole different weightclass. I then bought Styx: Shards of Darkness, and it was even more fun; larger skill tree, the ability to change dagger and outfit, and several new items, playing through the game several times easily avoids being repetitive simply by changing shirts. I prefer the plot and general character energy of the first game, but this one certainly is funnier. 13/10, Cyanide Studios please let me come up with items and equipment for Styx 3.

review: Хорошая игра, намного лучше первой части, по геймдизайну и распределению+расстановке уровней вообще вопросов нет, Стикс как всегда харизматичный, и здесь раскрыт еще больше, постоянно стeбeтся, ломает четвертую стену, фишка с смертями круто обыграна. Но главная проблема игры в супер конченных багах, и самое плохое в этих багах что они не безобидные, вы просто не сможете пройти игру дальше, и рестарт локации не помогает, только удача что все сложится по другому сценарию, и это не единичный случай в игре. 2022 год, баги остались.

review:
I really enjoyed Shards of Darkness, so much so that I'm seemingly one of the few people to have finished the game. 

I hadn't played a pure stealth game like Styx before, and it took a while to understand that you make progress by not getting seen. So there's a lot of observation, timing, and quick-saving involved as you sneak around in the shadows. If you're looking for a no-combat, pure stealth game, give Styx a try!

review:
Coming from games like Dishonored, Splinter Cell, Deus Ex, and Hitman, this game really exceed my expectation.
I think this game was made for Controller, but hey M+K works very well too.

Interesting Characters, Funny convos, Amazing stealth and gameplay mechanics, wonderful skills, and WOW surroundings,
I enjoyed every moment of this game.
Oh wait, I kinda hate that cave full of bugs though.

I finished the game for fun so I killed when I wanted/needed to kill and it was a worth it experience.

Thinking of buying the Master of Shadow and waiting for the sequel. And please make the sequel low-end laptop friendly as well.
The performance and optimization of this game is also top notch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009156904', 'num_games_owned': 756, 'num_reviews': 278, 'playtime_forever': 1234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1234, 'last_played': 1639834017}
review:
[h1]ถ้าชอบ Styx แรกก็ควรเล่น ถ้าไม่ชอบ Styx แรกเพราะเกมเก้งๆกังๆก็น่าจะลองเล่นดูเพราะเกมปรับปรุงดีขึ้น[/h1]

Styx: Shards of Darkness ยังคงเป็นเกมเดิมจากภาคแรก เกมแนว Stealth ในโลกแฟนตาซี รับบทเป็น Goblin ที่สู้ใครไม่ได้คอยย่องผ่านอัศวินใส่เกราะปามีดโคตรแม่นกัน การควบคุมเดิมๆคือปีนป่ายแบบ Freeform ไม่มีบังคับ และระบบเดิมๆกับการทำภารกิจหลัก, ภารกิจรอง, ภารกิจโบนัส (Speedrun, ไม่ฆ่าใคร, ไม่ให้ใครเห็นตัว, เก็บ Token) เพื่อรับ SP มาอัพเกรดสกิล (ที่ใส่เข้าหรือถอดออกได้)

สิ่งที่เพิ่มเติมมาในภาคนี้คือปรับปรุงด้าน Quality of Life มีปุ่มบังคับเกาะขอบแล้ว, ปีนเชือกได้แล้ว, โบนัส (Insignia) มีการบอกเลยว่าล้มเหลวหรือยังทำให้ไม่ต้องเดาอีกต่อไป (ซึ่งมีกระทู้ในภาคแรกเยอะมากว่า "แมลงนับเป็นถูกพบตัวหรือนับเป็นฆ่ามั้ย" หรือ "บอสสุดท้ายนับมั้ย")

ระบบใหม่ที่เพิ่มเข้ามาคือการคราฟท์ของ ดังนั้น Amber Vision มีประโยชน์มากขึ้นในการค้นหาวัตถุดิบสำหรับคราฟท์ มีระบบเปลี่ยนอาวุธและชุด และเกมเน้นตลกโปกฮามากกว่าภาคแรก มีมุขล้อเลียนหรือ Break the 4th Wall เรื่อยๆ (โดยเฉพาะตอนตายกับระหว่างเกมบ่นว่าทำไมคนเขียนบทชอบบังเอิญให้ทุกอย่างมาอยู่ที่เดียวกันง่ายจัง)

ก็ตามนั้นแหละ ถ้าชอบ Stealth แต่ไม่ชอบความเก้งกังของภาคแรก แนะนำมาลองเล่นภาคนี้ดู มันปรับปรุงดีขึ้น ก็ไม่ถึงขั้นสมบูรณ์แบบ เพราะบางจุดก็ยังแย่เหมือนเดิม แต่ถือว่าดีขึ้น เช่นเกมยังคงเป็นแนววิ่งเข้าเส้นชัยเหมือนเดิม (แม้กับบอสสุดท้าย) แต่ภารกิจมีความหลากหลายขึ้น (อย่างน้อยก็มีภารกิจฆ่ากับล้วงกระเป๋าเยอะขึ้น) การรีไซเคิลด่านยังมีอยู่ แต่ด่านก็เปิดกว้างกว่าภาคแรกมากและมีการเปลี่ยนแปลงทำให้ไม่ซ้ำซาก (เทียบภาคแรกคือให้วิ่งย้อนกลับ) เนื้อเรื่องไม่ต้องสนใจ มันไม่ต่อกัน อาจจะมีพูดถึงบ้าง แต่ไม่สำคัญถึงขั้นต้องเล่น

อีกหนึ่งอย่างคือเพราะพื้นที่เปิดกว้างขึ้นเกมเลยง่ายขึ้นมาก ภาคแรกเเกมเน้นอยู่ในพื้นที่ปิด ยามเดินกันขวักไขว่มาก เราจึงถูกบีบให้ไปช้าๆ คอยดับคบเพลิงหลบไปตามทาง แต่เพราะภาคนี้พื้นที่เปิดมาก ทำให้แทบไม่ต้องดับคบเพลิงเลย ถ้ามีใครขวางก็หาทางอ้อมไปทางอื่นก็ได้

ปล. ขายถูกกว่าภาคแรกด้วย lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198826049620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4158, 'last_played': 1673655956}
review:
Na taką ładną liczbę godzin wypadałoby napisać recenzję.
Słowem wstępu, Styx: Shards of Darkness jest to gra skradankowa osadzona w świecie dark fanasty. Nasz tytułowy bohater, Styx wystąpił już w dwóch innych grach, Styx: Master of Shadows i Of Orcs And Men, gra jest kontynuacją pierwszego tytułu ale do przejścia gry nie potrzebna jest znajomość fabuły poprzedniej części.
Omówię więc teraz poszczególne części gry:

Świat
Lokacje w jakich dano nam grać nie są za duże a zmierzanie prosto do celu bez zwiedzania albo szukania znajdziek zajmuje kilka minut. Wszędzie można znaleść jakieś tajne przejścia, szparki, dziurki co ma nam pomóc w rozgrywce ale jednak dziwnie to wygląda. Ogólnie modele i całe otoczenie wydają się jakieś brudne, dziwnie ukształtowane, nieregularne ale ma to swój klimat i jednak pokazuje że temu światu raczej bliżej do dystopii (albo po prostu nastąpiły cięcia w budżecie). Udźwiękowienie też uwydatnia cechy tego świata, słyszałam różne opinie na temat soundtracku i raczej to jest kwestia indywidualna ale mi się on szczerze podoba.

Główny bohater
Styx jest małym, sarkastycznym goblinem, kieruje się najczęściej własnymi interesami. W tym przypadku zastosowano koncept antybohatera co także niektórym się podoba a niektórym nie. Patrząc jednak na jego sytuację w grze można go czasem zrozumieć a także ma resztki jakiejś dobrej a czasem marzycielskiej natury np. kilka razy w grze przyznał że lubi podziwiać naturę i widoki.

Fabuła 
Tu też zdania są podzielone, ogólnie historia jest prosta ale jednak zdarzają się plot twisty których łatwo, a czasem trudno się domyślić, nie wciąga tak bardzo jak ta z pierwszej części Styxa ale jednak moim zdaniem potrafi zaciekawić i bardzo liczę na jej rozwinięcie, przede wszystkim po mocno krytykowanym zakończeniu, które po prostu urywa się w połowie akcji. Historia toczy się dość dynamicznie na szczęście rozgrywka trochę spowalnia to tępo.

Gameplay
Bardzo mocne krytykowane jest także sterowanie ale poza tym gra jest dobrze zrobiona możliwość kraftowania przedmiotów a także drzewka umiejętności ciekawie urozmaicają rozgrywkę. Także system insygnii działa ok, motywuje gracza czy do bycia niezauważalnym czy do zwiedzania w poszukiwaniu znajdziek czy do przejścia poziomu w określonym limicie czasowym, dodam że insygnia mają swoje poziomy (złoto, srebro, brąz) co jest lepszym rozwiązaniem niż w części pierwszej gdzie jeden błąd i tracisz insygnie.

Tryb kooperacji
Mało osób poruszyło ten temat a jest warty dyskusji. COOP w tej grze jest broken, przede wszystkim dla klienta, zapisy albo postępy często są odbierane klientowi jak np. wyrzuci go z gry albo coś pominie. Jeśli jednak bardzo zależy ci na zagraniu w tym trybie to niech klient wykonuje wszystkie ważniejsze czynności i misje poboczne. Także ważny jest internet przede wszystkim hosta ponieważ gra może zamienić się w istne piekło.

Jak to ze sprzętem
Gra ogólnie jest dobrze zoptymalizowana i poszła nawet na szkolnym, zapchanym komputerze, więc jeśli twój sprzęcior nie jest ziemniakiem to gra spokojnie powinna na nim pójść. 

Rzeczy o których warto jeszcze wspomnieć
Zapomniałam jeszcze wspomnieć o humorze i dialogach. Gra upodobała sobie czarny humor i czasem wulgarny język co też jest kwestią indywidualną, w tej części jest także wiele smaczków i nawiązań do popkultury albo innych "styxowych" gier, są żarciki wybitne ale także takie, które wepchnięto na siłę. 
Wygląd postaci i cutscenki też nie są najgorsze ale nie są też najlepsze, widać że na początku były one bardziej dopracowane a na końcu trochę tego zaoszczędzili jednak ma to swój urok.

Kończąc mój wywód, Styx Shards of Darkness jest grą ciekawą i jak na produkcję z nie zbyt dużego studia trzyma poziom. Ja jako osoba nie będąca fanatykiem skradanek dobrze się bawiłam na singleplayerze jak i na wadliwym coopie. Czekam na więcej gier ze Styxem, które z każą częścią robią się coraz lepsze.
