author: {'steamid': '76561198199678071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 252, 'playtime_at_review': 1403, 'last_played': 1711997075}
review:
I really want to recommend this game. I really do. I love this franchise and what hey did in Master of Shadows was extraordinary.
But I do not know what happened here. They ruined it. They should have stuck to what they started without experimenting too much.

Pros:
Better graphics than the first one
More reliable climbing mechanic (less buggy, and more variety)
Everything we love about our goblin assassin is in this game too with his personality
Even more gadgets to kill/distract your opponents
Animated cutscenes
Co-op gameplay!!! (You can play your game with a friend or a random person)
Memorable new characters

Cons:
Mediocre story (more of an adventure or spinoff than part of Styx's story)
Voice acting of side characters, NPCs needs improvement
Old reported game-breaking bugs that were never fixed

4th wall breaking: During the game Styx would speak to the player, knowing he is controlled. This is a huge immersion-breaking issue. I know they wanted to try something new but since neither Of Orcs and Men, nor Master of Shadows had this... it was strange and unusual to have this. I recommend not to put this in the next game. Just let Styx explain everything in his monologues as he talks to himself like in the previous games. Please note that now there are death scenes included and I am not talking about that.

Inconsistency: This is the major reason why I cannot recommend this game. It is like it completely forgets what happened in Master of Shadows and what will happen in Of Orcs and Men later. I will not go into detail because I dont want to spoil it but... you will see it if you try it.

During the first gameplay I was only a bit confused but as I repeated the missions and thought about it... I realized it just didnt make any sense and this is why I dont play it anymore.

So yeah. I love the franchise, I like the developers, I adore Styx but... This game? Nah.

Perhaps the next game will be better.

review:
If you love the "Thief" series, you'll love this just as much!

While I (admittedly) haven't played the original STYX game I was turned onto this after I saw it for sale prior to even having heard about it, and I looked at a gameplay video and was absolutely STUNNED!  The visuals are beautiful, the gameplay is EXTREMELY involved, and the AI is top-notch.  This isn't like most games where npc's magically know where you're at.  They actively hunt you down, and try to kill you.
If I had ONE complaint it would be that when you're performing jump maneuvers they don't always go as planned, but C'est LaVie.  Not everything can be perfect, but this is VERY close, and a wonderful addition to the library of anyone that loves a decent stealth game!

review:
The games story feels rushed and quickly put together, which diminishes the rest of the game. Not exactly interesting or unique. The maps are not very complicated and can be easily pushed through. A far cry from the first game. The first Styx had a good story, a goal, a mission, this one just doesn't have any of those things. Gameplay ends up feeling repetitive and boring, and essentially becomes something to just do if you can't decide on anything else.

Play the first game, skip this one. Better graphics is all Shards of Darkness can offer.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197997212491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1561933264}
review:
In less than an hour of play time, I received 6 fatal errors, each causing a crash to desktop. Two were at the start screen before I'd even begun a new game, and 4 were in the opening tutorial level. The last two occurred after trying various supposed "fixes" I found after 20 minutes of forum searching. Apparently it's a known bug that was never patched out. 

If it weren't for the technical issues, I'd say the game showed promise. I love stealth games, and this one seemed right up my alley, even if some of the mechanics were noticeable clunky. But I simply can't recommend something that won't let me play it for more than 10 minutes at a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198288449416', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1660689424}
review: Mit Styx: Shards of Darkness folgt der zweite Teil vom Goblin namens Styx in der Hauptrolle.In einer Welt voller Gewalt, Verrat und Korruption, in der die Goblins verfolgt werden, muss sich Styx als Auftragskiller und professioneller Dieb beweisen. Man kann das Spiel entweder alleine oder zusammen mit anderen Spielern zocken, die sowohl zufällig ausgewählt oder deine zum Spielen eingeladenen Freunde sein können. Anzumerken ist aber, dass das Spiel mit zunehmender Spieleranzahl schwieriger gestaltet wird. So kann man bei zwei Spielern beispielsweise nicht mehr die Schläge der Gegner parieren, sprich: Das Spiel wird dadurch vielmehr zu einem "Sneaky Game". Man muss die Gegner taktisch und mit Absprache mit dem Kollegen ausschalten, da jeder Spieler nur ein Leben hat und man sofort vom Gegner gepackt und getötet wird, wenn er einen sieht. Man durchläuft die Story in graphisch hervorragend gestalteten Leveln, die es auch schonmal in sich haben können. Man darf also nicht verzweifeln, wenn ein Level auch mal länger dauert, es zu schaffen. Mit einem breit gefächerten Skill-Baum bietet das Spiel dem Spieler auch verschiedene Spielmöglichkeiten, wie man vorgehen möchte. Insgesamt ist das Spiel mit einer Mischung aus Assassins Creed und Thief ein sehr schönes Spiel für diejenigen die dieses Spielprinzip lieben, auch mal nicht einfach reinzurennen, sondern es zum Teil auch taktisch anzugehen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075563306', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 1935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1935, 'last_played': 1561666537}
review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness traz elementos que, ao serem explorados corretamente, transformam jogos simples em verdadeiros diferenciais. O foco no humor negro, cru e sarcástico. Um protagonista “boca-suja” que não se importa em deixar claro que não existe qualquer um mais importante que ele. E as referências. Ah, as inúmeras referências a filmes, jogos, ícones da cultura nerd…

No mais novo título da Cyanide Studio, distribuído pela Focus Home Interactive, o jogador controla o “carismático” goblin Styx, em seu segundo jogo solo desde Of Orcs and Men (2012). Styx deve se infiltrar na cidade élfica de Korrangar e descobrir os motivos de uma aliança secreta entre os elfos negros e os anões. E nesse ínterim, fazer-se substancialmente mais rico.

Os elementos de jogabilidade fazem deste um título como poucos. Uma mecânica de furtividade extremamente bem elaborada, que comete apenas pequenos deslizes em pontos que não comprometem a diversão, aliada a diálogos criativos, personagens carismáticos e uma história simples, mas que se encaixa perfeitamente à trama, fazem de Styx: Shards of Darkness um jogo perfeito aos amantes da boa e velha ação furtiva.

A história do game não poderia ser mais clichê. Styx é um ladrão. Talvez o melhor em seu ramo. Mas sendo parte de uma raça pouco bem vista em seu mundo, constantemente é alvo de tudo e todos. E frequentemente, até mesmo de seus empregadores.

Não que isso seja um problema para o goblin. Até porque seus inimigos percebem rapidamente que cruzar seu caminho é uma atitude um tanto… corrosiva.

Ao fim de um determinado trabalho, no entanto, Styx recebe a visita da comandante da C.A.R.N.A.G.E., um destacamento especializado para caçar e acabar com orcs. Ela precisa que o ladrão se infiltre em um dirigível, roube um cetro do embaixador e retorne com notícias. Mas, “inesperadamente”, as coisas não saem como esperado.

Reviravoltas acontecem e a missão inicial acaba tomando proporções muito maiores que as previstas, envolvendo todas as espécies do seu mundo. Mas, para variar, cabe a ele resolver o problema, para que os goblins possam ter um futuro.

Com esse pano de fundo, o jogador é lançado dentro de uma rede de intrigas, acordos políticos e traições. Nada que já não seja previsível. E o mais engraçado é exatamente isso. Styx, a todo momento, faz comentários caricatos sobre sua total consciência de que está em um jogo, e o roteirista não ser nada original. Quase um Deadpool em pele verde.

Outros personagens também dão seu tom ao contexto. Mas no fim, o foco geral é sempre o protagonista. Em outros jogos, como já visto aqui, isso poderia ser um problema. Contudo, a história é muito bem elaborada, e essa convergência, ao contrário, faz com que tudo fique mais divertido.

Styx não é um mero ladrão. Ele busca ser o melhor no que faz e isso inclui falsificação de documentos, mortes “acidentais”, roubo de informações, entre outros. E os elementos do jogo ressaltam sempre todas essas habilidades. Seu tamanho diminuto o auxilia

Tudo no jogo é desenhado para fazer uso das inúmeras habilidades de Styx. Como exemplo, cita-se os objetivos do jogo. Para cada um deles, opcionais ou de história, existem diversas abordagens. Tais abordagens instigam o jogador a sempre achar aquele melhor caminho para executar as tarefas necessárias.

O level design foi inteligentemente desenhado para tal. Sombras e luz fazem um jogo sagaz. Esconderijos e armadilhas estão lá para serem utilizados, caso desejar. Mas o jogador pode preferir ignorar todos estes elementos e simplesmente se esgueirar pelas linhas inimigas, como um rato na escuridão.

E a verdade seja dita. Tais elementos provocam uma tensão verdadeira. Caminhar a passos curtos, esgueirando-se por frestas nas paredes, apenas observando inimigos, suas rotas e possíveis pontos de fuga. Nesses momentos, ao analisar as estratégias disponíveis, o jogador se sente verdadeiramente imerso dentro do game.

Neste quesito, alguns pontos não se encaixam com a proposta. Por exemplo: a bainha da adaga de Styx é um indicador do quão oculto ele está. Quanto mais na escuridão, mais ela brilha. (o que nos leva a crer que algo errado não está certo). Outro exemplo são as diversas portas do jogo: ao serem abertas, elas não podem ser fechadas.

Tais situações podem não representar um problema. Até o momento em que um guarda passa em frente à porta que acaba de ser aberta, e observa aquela pequena criatura verde tentando se esgueirar, acabando com toda a estratégia implementada.

Tais pontos não chegam a comprometer seriamente a experiência, mas ainda assim demonstra certo “desleixo” neste aspecto específico, dentre tantos outros bem trabalhados.

E por falar em estratégia, existem incentivos para que o jogador busque ser sempre o melhor “mestre das sombras”. Cada fase possui medalhas, com desafios específicos (terminar no menor tempo, não ser visto, não matar inimigos e achar todas as medalhas). E, claro, apenas os melhores conseguirão desbloquear todas.

A jogabilidade de Shards of Darkness é exatamente o que se espera de um jogo do gênero. Furtividade é a palavra chave: entrar em combate é pedir para ser morto sem muito esforço. Tanto que, nas dificuldades mais elevadas, o combate direto é completamente abolido. Ou os inimigos são eliminados furtivamente, ou Styx é eliminado com alarde.

Assim, fazer uso desse elemento é essencial para se manter vivo, quanto mais para avançar no jogo. Sombras, esconderijos (mesas, vasos, baús, armários, etc), eliminações silenciosas. Tudo gira em torno da furtividade. As habilidades de Styx, inclusive, são bastante focadas neste aspecto.


Nota:8.5

review: I love goblins. I love stealth. I love co-op. The first thing I will say, is controls wise there will be a learning curve, but after a while you'll have a mastery of the traversal and stealth mechanics that pay off with some great stealth moments.  A great mechanic that's offered is the quick-save (right on the d-pad for those playing with controller). So before you do something really stupid the save button is a must. However, even if you do forget to quick-save, the times I've reloaded and found a new or different path or tactic to deal with the same situation makes replaying the same sections very bearable, and sometimes even a treat. Only major downside, is no one is playing this game anymore, so finding even a random to play coop with will be hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014698888', 'num_games_owned': 924, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1560983174}
review:
A decent stealth game for players like me who aren't so great at stealth.  There is ample opportunity to complete every level without being seen and without killing anyone, but the game is also decently forgiving if you make mistakes.

This Styx game allows you to play co-op.  You lose the ability to parry guard attacks, so only stealth kills are permitted and you instantly die in frontal assaults.  Seems like a worthy trade off to me to be able to play this game with a friend.

The final mission is complete garbage.  Other than that, I enjoyed every level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031627138', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1553110668}
review:
НИ РЫБА, НИ МЯСО

Средний стелс с упором на тактику в открытых (некоридорных) локациях и то, что герой должен быть абсолютно невидим. 

Есть интересные решения вроде клонов самого героя и различные обманки, но в целом играется тоскливо. Авторы местами жестят с расположением врагов, сами враги ходят группами, визуал локаций местами становится чересчур заезженным (особенно город тёмных эльфов).

Если объективно: всё самое лучшее в игре будет вплоть до пропуска в древний город. И первые пару улиц в городе. Всё что дальше -- это скука и самоповтор. Впрочем, можно попытаться осилить игру ради сюжета.

Если бы в Стиме была нейтральная оценка, то я поставил бы именно её. А так... лучше пройдите Dishonored или Thief.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056739666', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1560434330}
review:
[h1][b]SUBJECTIVE NOTE AND FAIR WARNING[/b][/h1]

I am writing this review straight after I finished the game because I can not, for the life in me, let anyone else touch this piece of crap without heeding them that this game is a  t o t a l  mess. As a quick introduction, under no circumstance should you buy it unless you are a masochist or have too much time or money on your hands and want to buy this instead of throwing it in the trash. Spoiler alert: throwing your money in the trash is better than buying this. I got the game for free at a giveaway and I still feel robbed. 

Ok then, now that I could express these feelings, it is time to get into the actual review, the part where I explain objectively why it is a bad game.

[h1][b]STORY AND CHARACTERS[/b][/h1]

So, Styx is a century-old goblin assassin and thief who takes a job that turns up getting him involved in a hot mess regarding elves, dwarves and amber. Amber is a substance that he uses to fuel his powers like invisibility and cloning, presented as a sort of drug due to the addiction it gives its users. I don't want to spoil the story but I will say that it is awfully mediocre. The classic fantasy tropes are used without much imaginative change. The only thing that was alright was the idea of a goblin plague and of an organization named C.A.R.N.A.G.E that trained humans and dwarves alike to become goblin-killers. The side characters are bland and unmemorable, and because I do not want to repeat myself in the sections to come: [b] this whole game is characterized by mediocrity [/b].

When is comes to Styx, the protagonist, things get cringe worthy. He has a humor that I can describe only as trying to copy DeadPool but missing every fun aspect. Since every time you die he appears in the game over screen and starts talking to you, apparently the developers believe that breaking the 4th wall in any chance they get is exciting, amazes the audience and makes them laugh their asses off. I have absolutely not rolled my eyes every time he came to my screen with a line like "Is that your controller in your pocket or are you just pleased to see me?" or "I'll have you know that the jump button is not between your ass cheeks!". Sarcasm aside, his jokes are anything but funny to anyone that's past 12 years old. Because he has a different line depending on the cause of your game over, if the lines were actually well written, it would have been quite an interesting element. It can be seen from a mile away that he is an utterly failed attempt at a bombastic, badass and comical character that would have stolen people's hearts. The only thing that was not that bad about Styx was his voice acting.

[h1][b]GAMEPLAY[/b][/h1]

I must say, the tutorial level really had me liking the mechanics, albeit them being the classic stealth gameplay with little twists here and there. It actually seemed like a game with a lot of potential. Sure, there were some bugs here and there, but it would get better (that is the lie I have told myself over and over until mission 6 when I would have quit if I weren't so far into the game). You have your everyday crouch, detection bars, floors that make quieter or louder sounds, stealth kills, invisibility power, a skill tree, a crafting table, etc. (none of them out of the ordinary stuff you usually find in a stealth game). Stealth kills were somewhat impressing since they are split into two: tap the button to perform a kill that is faster but the nearby enemies will hear you, or hold the button for a slower kill, but you muffle the enemy while doing it. Kind of like in Hitman where you can snap someone's neck with the fiber wire or just choke them to unconsciousness with it, except in this game you have literally 0 methods that are non-lethal, and the funny thing is you even have a medal in every mission for not killing anyone, but that didn't bother me since I saw it as a welcome challenge. 

Well, it would have been a welcome challenge if the rest of the mechanics were actually well implemented. Good idea, poor execution. The thing that stands out the most for me, since I always tried taking the high routes, is the "parkour" mechanics, which are devastatingly clunky and horrifyingly buggy. 90% of the times I ended up dying because Styx would just randomly decide to woosh off a ledge, drop without grabbing anything or fall through/next to the ledge I was trying to grab next. Since the jumps don't auto-lock to the closest thing near you that you can jump on, it ends up giving off the feeling of a 3D platformer that was never meant to be a 3D platformer, and so players trying to take any route involving the low way or the high way are automatiaclly discouraged.

The A.I is quite unbalanced due to the bugs it is experiencing. One mission the enemies will have no clue you are there if you are standing 10 meters in front of them in a fully lit hallway, and another mission the same type of enemy will look towards you when you throw a distraction item instead of where the item was thrown, instantly blowing your cover (no, that is not a feature, I know some stealth game A.I does that on purpose but here it's not the case). And the same type of enemy will see you if you are 20 meters away from them, on a rooftop in broad daylight, just by looking in your general direction. Since the game has a smell mechanic (you can see the smell trail left by enemies if you activate your amber vision) and dwarves are the only enemies that can smell your presence, that is the only challenge I have found in the otherwise dumb enemies.

[h1][b]OTHER THINGS TO TAKE NOTE OF[/b][/h1]

Checkpoints. Checkpoints are at fault for 80% of this game's problems. Of course other issues wouldn't be so evident if you had a different checkpoint system, but when the last auto-save pulls you back 30 minutes across the level, you start noticing the things I mentioned above as well. 

Let me explain. There are 2 situations of checkpoints I have found in this game, where you can't manual save mid-level:

a) A checkpoint every 2 or 3 objectives: you are in a city of goblin hunters with enemies that insta-kill you if they catch you. You have to find 3 bombs. You find a warehouse with the first bomb.[b]Auto-save[/b]. You have to follow footprints. You get to the source of the footprints (note that they take you through half the map of the level). You have to follow the another set that stems from the source. You find a warehouse with a closed gate to the second bomb. A locked door guarded by a dwarf is the only point of entry. Let's say you try something, he detects you, and you die here. Look back to when the game last saved. It took you a good 15 minutes (or more depending on your playstyle) to follow those footsteps and get to the second bomb, and now you're back there. Fail 2 more times and roughly 45 minutes of your day are down the drain due to horrible game design.

b) 2 checkpoints... on the same objective? : "Saved successfully" will sometimes appear in the corner of your screen two times after a random objective that was usually easy to get to. Maybe it is a visual bug.

Also, the level design is sometimes good, but "good" is the maximum it reaches. There are 2 boss fights as well, with the last one being there just for the sake of making the game longer. I won't talk about the graphics since they are not relevant by the time of this review and you're probably not playing it for its beauty anyway.

[h1][b]CONCLUSION[/b][/h1]

All the bad elements combined make this game a definite no-go. The bugs, the horrible controls, the mediocre story, the bland characters, the humor that is trying too hard and the simple, unimpressive dialogue make this game shine by absolutely nothing. It gets really frustrating at times, albeit being quite short, and doesn't really give you any reason to buy it except if you are a fan of Styx because you played the previous games. 

[h1][b]SCORE: 2/10[/b][/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198007623275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 3334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3334, 'last_played': 1559249899}
review:
Axé sur l'infiltration, la discrétion, la recherche du parcours le moins voyant, Styx est un jeu vraiment prenant et très bien réalisé. Les décors, souvent sombres, sont bien dessinés et comprennent nombre de pièges mais aussi de passages.
L'aspect le plus original et irrésistible, c'est le personnage qui vous engueule copieusement quand vous osez le faire mourir, ce qui arrive fréquemment.
En revanche, les deux inconvénients principaux sont : 1) les dialogues ne sont pas consultables a posteriori, alors qu'ils révèlent des pistes pour en sortir 2) pendant les deux scènes les plus difficiles, où il faut détruire deux monstres implacables avec une méthode à mettre au point à l'expérience, les sauvegardes ne sont pas possibles, ce qui oblige à tout recommencer et s'avère vraiment fastidieux pour ceux comme moi qui ne sont pas des as du réflexe ni de la précision de saut.
Pour autant, Styx est très agréable et je le recommande à tous les amateurs du genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018892742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 2065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2065, 'last_played': 1559117678}
review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness is pretty, the gameplay's good, and it ran well on my budget system. Some of the zones are quite large, and the urban ones feel organic and lived-in.


However:
Styx's enemies are annoying.
Styx's allies are annoying.
Styx himself is extremely annoying.

Most of the "jokes" are forced. The characterization feels like something out of a b-movie from the nineteen-eighties.

About a third of the cut-scenes go something like this:
Styx: I'm a badass! No one tells me what to do! TURDS!
NPC: Do this, this, and this.
Styx: OK.

Seriously, the characters, and the characters [i]alone[/i], made me think about uninstalling more than once before I was finished. Oddly enough, the incidental dialogue you hear from NPCs while you're sneaking around sounds good. It's the important characters I found grating.


The crafting mechanic is here because this game came out in 2017, and crafting mechanics are now obligatory. They'll be adding one to minesweeper, next. Two of the craftable items only seem to be there just so you can complete achievements.


One thing that made a great impression on me was the ability to manually select a button scheme for button prompts if you're using a controller. I find a PlayStation style controller to be easier on my arthritis, and most PC publishers treat XBox controllers like the Alpha and Omega of input options. Some games will try to auto-detect, but more games need to put this in the player's hands, so-to-speak.


If you like stealth games, you're probably going to like Styx: Shards of Darkness. If you hate cut-scenes that verge on so-bad-it's-bad territory, you can skip 'em, or wait for the game to go on sale, and then skip 'em anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091558361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1558903660}
review:
When making a game, first and for-most, your engine must be refined. Without this, gameplay feels jarring and unresponsive. Styx: Shards of Darkness could not be described in a better way. Maybe it's just me but I cannot attempt to play a game if the base mechanics are flawed. It doesn't matter how good the story is or how good the graphics are, if the game doesn't play well, then I might as well just watch a movie. Not to mention, this almost feels like a step down from the second game in the series and that game was already garbage.

Don't waste your money, Styx: Shards of Darkness is not worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031506172', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1944, 'last_played': 1558819702}
review:
Salut, allé un bon 16, bien mérité. SoD est donc la suite direct de MoS. Styx réplique quelques clin d’œil à l'épisode précédent et aussi ua monde cinématographique, ce qui est cool!

Le jeu est toujours de l'infiltration pure, mais cette fois les niveaux sont plus ouvert et il est donc sympa de choisir ses objectifs dans l'ordre que l'on veut.
Toujours du loot et maintenant du kraft! J'ai eu peur que cela soit lourd, et bien non!

Coté jeu, c'est pareil, mais en mieux:
+ d'espace.
+ de objets.
+ de pouvoirs
Meilleurs graphismes.
Meilleurs animations.
Meilleurs level design.
Meilleurs qualité!
Avec cela un scénario sympa et une durée de vie conséquente, env. 30H comme son prédécesseur!

Bon, tout n'est pas rose, mais cela reste pardonnable:

(-) Toujours quelques ratés d'accrochage, de sauts ou de kills.
(-) Le changement de moteur a été bénéfique, mais il ont changé les touches et Entrée n'est plus utilisable......
(-) Plus facile que le précédent et finalement le Kraft, on l'utilise peu!
(-) Tout comme le précédent, quelques maps sont recyclés.

Bref, Styx SoD est une fois de plus une bonne affaire, grisante et humoristique, qui vaut le détour !
Cocorico !

author: {'steamid': '76561198010077003', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 1465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1465, 'last_played': 1558473055}
review:
4/5
Buon gioco stealth, ai pari del primo titolo della serie. In questo si ha finalmente modo di ampliare l'ambientazione dark fantasy, rendendo ben più presenti gli elfi oscuri e introducendo anche i nani. La trama ha meno colpi di scena del primo, ma è più vivace e, forse perché più corto del primo, non mi ha stancato fino alla fine. Peccato solo che sia lasciata un po' in sospeso con la sorte di tutti i personaggi principali ignota. La grafica è decisamente migliorata con i filmati di intermezzo fluidi e movimentati come il gioco. La difficoltà mi è sembrata invece più bassa, restando piuttosto facile anche al livello più difficile con i nemici che ti uccidono con un colpo e contro cui non si può duellare.
Tutto sommato è un buon gioco, anche se forse il prezzo è un tantino esagerato. Consigliato sicuramente se è piaciuto il primo, magari meglio se scontato.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110533185', 'num_games_owned': 730, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1565, 'last_played': 1557864080}
review:
ゴブリンが主役のステルスアクションゲー
前作もレビューしたのでがっつり比べながらレビュー
あんなボロカスに書いたのになぜ次回作に手を付けてしまったのか
日本語化は字幕のみだが公式でついた

なんか申し訳程度にco-opで進めることもできるようになったがあんまり…期待はしないほうがいい

[h1]前作から良くなったところ[/h1]
キャラクター性を全面にだしてくるようになって物語への入り込み安さが良くなった、ちょっと愛嬌もあったりしてキャラクターを好きになれる工夫がなされた。特に死ぬたびにStyxがプレイヤーに文句言ってきたりするのは本当に良かったしプレイ中も一言多い感じが面白い

操作性は…一応縁に捕まる操作等が足され若干良くなったとは思うものの壁に張り付くボタンと同じだったりでまだ思い通りに動かしやすいとは言えない、壁の掴める掴めないなんかもわかりにくい。足は若干速くなった気がする

一応前作からの続きということで透明化やクローン等のStyxが前作で得たアクティブスキルは最初から使えるようになった、ゲームの特色部分なのでこれは大事

消費アイテムなどを一部クラフトできるようになった…あんま意味ない気がするがゴソゴソアイテム拾いする楽しみは増えた…か…？素材の位置は固定ですけども。

進行不能等の致命的なバグは無くなった、そうしてくれなきゃ困る。でもクラッシュ自体は3回ほどあった、あとラスボスが消えてしまう再現性のあるバグを見つけたがそれくらい。

[h1]ストーリー[/h1]
続き物で説明不足な面がちょいちょいあると思う、アンバーってなんだとかこのキャラ知り合いみたいだけど誰なのとかそういうのはちょっとだけある、でもまぁ今作からでも気にならないかも

なんかストーリー面で不評みたいだけど個人的には別にどうでもよかった。強いて言えばエンディングは「次回に続く」的な感じだったので消化不良なのはあるかもしれない

[h1]あのさぁ…[/h1]
「縛りプレイと成長要素をくっつけたらあかん」っておじさんゆーたよねぇ！？これやったらイライラしちゃうって！あぁっ！？

前作と同じく未発覚、タイムアタック、小さいもの集め、不殺をこなしてステージクリアするとスキルポイントがもらえる、点数は減点方式みたいな感じで「タイムが○○秒過ぎました」という丁寧なお知らせとともにわざわざイライラさせてくれる。これやったらあかんねんって…ほんまやらされてる感出るんだってば…リトライ地獄で攻略に創造の余地がないしプレイヤーの気分をとにかくマイナスにするこの成長システムをなぜ引き継いでしまったのか小一時間問い詰めたい

あのね、不殺とかが後々影響してくるゲームとかってのは他にもあるけどもそういうのはプレイヤーが自分で選択しないと意味ないの、Dishonoredを見習え。このゲームは敵を倒すと純粋にデメリットしかないのが本当に駄目

そして縛りプレイを乗り越えてスキルをゲットするも意味のあるスキルがほとんどない、今回マジでない。アイテムの近くに行くと「ふ～む」と唸るスキルとか誰が使うねん！戦闘すると点数下がるから戦闘スキルは全部いらんしスキルを取る楽しみがない。アイディアが浮かばないならいっそのことスキルなんて無くてよかったとすら思う

相変わらず敵＝即死の罠みたいな感じで不殺より倒すほうが時間もかかり点数も下がるという二重苦。ステルスゲーだから戦闘面で不利とかは普通なんだがそれどころかやるだけ無駄でプレイヤーが取る最善の選択肢は「敵に発見されたらデータのロード」だから萎える

てかボスがいるのはいいけどラスボス戦で「小さいもの集め」さすな！どこに需要あんねん

[h1]総評[/h1]
なんべんも言うがこの成長システム絶対いらん、これでは攻略の方針をゲーム側に決められるので不自由感が出てしまっている。せめてスキルや成長システムを入れたかったら加点方式にしてやるべきなんだ、各々自分のやり方でスキルポイント貰えればみんな納得するし重ねて遊ぶ楽しみもあるというのに

ステージの作りや敵、それらのダメさ加減も前作からほとんど変わっていない。

ステージは広いし進入路も多いがあろうことかただでさえ見づらかったマップを削除でプレイヤーは道を目で見て覚える必要がある、そして使い回しも相変わらずで9つほどステージがあるが実質半分

敵も一緒で相変わらずのアホメ○ラツ○ボ、思考は同じところをぐるぐると歩いて巡回してるだけなのでパターン一回見たら新鮮味はなくなる

もうやりたくないという気持ちにさせる工夫がいろんなところになされている、まぁ実績のために消化していくときは楽だがそれだとほんとにタンパクに感じてしまう

個人的にゲームのタイムアタック自体は好きだけどゲーム側からやらされるとほんとにうざい、やりたいと思ってやるものなんだよタイムアタックってのは

パワーアップしてるところもあるが欠点のせいでどうしてもトータル49点くらいになってしまう、今回Styxのキャラクター自体はすごい立ってるのにもったいない…Styxは好き、でもこのゲームは嫌いって感想

一応今回致命的なバグがないのでクリアまでプレイしてる人はけっこういるもよう、しかしそれでも13％しかやってない。たったの9ステージを13％だ

今回もやっぱり買うならバンドル狙いが妥当、オススメはしかねる。とかなんとか言いつつ実績は終わらせたけど…

author: {'steamid': '76561197971569035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 362, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1557152325}
review: Un seguito degno del precedente, che è uno spinoff di un altro gioco molto bello ma sconosciuto ai più (Of Orcs and Men). Il genere stealth è scomparso oggigiorno e quasi tutti i giochi che si definiscono tali molto spesso offrono soluzioni facili e violente alle missioni proposte. Styx SoD come il precedente non offre queste alternative e al giusto livello di difficoltà sarete impossibilitati a combattere fisicamente dovendo agire in perfetta stealth per evitare una brusca fine. I livelli sono particolareggiati anche qui da una preferenza allo sviluppo verticale e ci sono sempre molteplici modi per arrivare in un certo punto o affrontare una certa sfida. Tutto sommato è un ottimo gioco e forse l'unico ormai rimasto di puro stealth game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001659612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1620918452}
review: Kinda like Hitman except it's Hitgoblin lol. only real drawback is you have to be stealthy at all times, as in you cant exactly go toe to toe with anybody like in Hitman its all sneaking around stabbing people in the back or shooting them with a dart from a distance. DLC was a huge help the knife does an auto acid melt of dead bodies so you don't have to hide em just stab and go lol. other than that the graphics are nice, game play gets a bit repetitive and its 100% been designed for console first and ported over to PC so controls are slightly clunky at times but if you like controllers hook up an xbox controller. have to say the dialog is funny as f***k, the death cut scenes if you die are side splitting funny. As for price I got mine from EB games for $10 then bought the DLC for $3 so cant complain about the price either. I give it a 8 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030504424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1556990347}
review:
[h1] 50% of this game was great![/h1]  

But I could not bring my self to power the ending as it became very tedious. 

Good points
- Great co-op multiplayer 
- Awesome above ground levels/ map design 
- Great comments when you die and 4th wall breaking 
- Interesting skill tree  
- Generally good mechanics 

Bad points 
- So many cave levels  (normal cave, elf cave, elf trail cave etc.) 
- Backtracking through cave levels  
- Gimcky missions within caves (cant be detected, trolling bugs) 
- Not enough ability to stock up on craftable items (intentional by devs?) 

I honestly felt the game was blast for every above ground level in the beginning (and one later) but slowly just became a chore as the gameplay became more about solving puzzles and dealing with unstoppable enemies in less visually appealing levels that force you to play a certain way. I might just hate caves more than the average gamer so in the end I would say its worth buying but beware of the points above.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968161397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1762, 'last_played': 1556347613}
review:
Frequently stunningly beautiful. Incredible level designs. Top notch voice acting for main characters and great writing. Overall great story that flows well. Funny main character. Imo, a game made with passion. Fantastic movement complexity which was fun to master. I absolutely recommend this game for people who like stealth, exploration, being on the edge of danger and charming fantasy worlds. 

The bad: (spoiler, minor stuff) Limit of 10 savegames for some reason (although you can replay a level from your hideout). Had to redo hotkeys after cutting out 10 savegames files to add more room, ugh.  It has the most annoying hotkey re-assignment menu i've ever used, even worse than Arma 2. I'd ask the devs to attempt to move your ASWD to SDEF for the purpose of surrounding your hand with more keys and set up some MMO mouse keys, even Styx was fucking annoyed with it. Try to assign basic action to mouse 1, hide/drop to mouse 2, takedown to MMO thumb button, roll to MMO thumb button....have fun. The worst thing is not allowing it to override a key which already has a hotkey in place. Instead I think it would be better to create a list of unset hotkeys on the right and also remind the player if they continue to leave them unset for a period of time. "Whos the mofo that thought this would be a good idea?" -Styx :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198016097561', 'num_games_owned': 1094, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1566724756}
review:
"Styx: Shards of Darkness" ist der Nachfolger des 2014 erschienenen "Styx - Master of Shadows" - ein Stealth-Game allererster Güte, dass sich vor einem Assassins Creed absolut nicht verstecken muss. Wer dazu noch ein Fable für bissigen Humor hat, ist hier gut aufgehoben.

[b][u]Bewertung[/u][/b]

	[b]+[/b] Grafik detailreich und atmosphärisch
	[b]+[/b] Dezenter Sound, nicht zu überladen
	[b]+[/b] Bissiger Humor
	[b]+[/b] Fesselnde Storyline
	[b]+ / -[/b] Nur englische Sprachausgabe


[b][u]Handlung + Gameplay[/u][/b]

"Mein kleiner grüner Goblin, steht draussen am Balkon, holleri, hollera, hollero..." - Das kam mir zu allererst in den Sinn, als ich Styx das erste mal sah. Er sieht zwar durchaus "böse" aus, aber er war mir direkt sympathisch. Irgendwie kam ein bisschen "Robin-Hood"-Feeling auf. Der Kämpfer gegen die Unterjochung der Goblins durch die Menschheit... mit einem ziemlich losen Mundwerk. 
Von einem Ganoven dazu beauftragt, die Soldkasse der menschlichen Wachmanschaft zu mopsen, schleicht man sich von Schatten zu Schatten, hüpft über Dächer, nicht ohne den ein oder anderen Kommentar ("Ich klettere zwar gerne über Dächer, aber du wirst mich niemals in einem verdammten weißen Hoodie sehen!") , bis man die Truhen klimpernder Münzen schließlich in Händen hält - Doch dann geht das Abenteuer erst richtig los! Styx wird in eine Verschwörung verstrickt, die sich gewaschen hat. 
Das Gameplay geht locker von der Hand, auch dank der Unreal Engine 4 ist die Steuerung schnell verinnerlicht. Ducken, springen, Meuchelmorden - Alles nicht zu kompliziert aufgebaut, so dass man doch recht schnell ins Spiel findet. Aber was wäre ein Dieb ohne Hilfsmittel: Wir haben die Möglichkeit, diverse Utensilien herzustellen,  kleine, gemeine Wurfpfeile, Lebenselixiere und vieles mehr. Dies geschieht an im jeweiligen Bereich verteilten Werkbänken der Menschen, doch sind diese nicht wie Unkraut gesät, was wiederum dazu anhält, mit seinem Equipment zu haushalten. 
Ebenfalls haben wir die Möglichkeit, mittels der Einnahme von Goldharz, einem völlig legalen Elixier... ähm... nennen wir es "Hustensaft", die Fähigkeiten unseres kleinen Freundes (nein, nicht das was ihr schon wieder denkt) zu steigern. Durch das Goldharz werden bspw. Objekte mit denen wir interagieren können farblich hervorgehoben, wir können uns unsichtbar machen oder einen Klon von Styx "hervorbringen", was an manchen Stellen durchaus hilfreich sein kann (aber nicht zwingend notwendig ist).


[b][u]Grafik + Sound[/u][/b]

Die Grafik entspricht durchaus aktueller Technik, Hintergründe und Szenerien sind stimmig umgesetzt und passen einfach zusammen. Das merkt man unter anderem daran, dass viel Wert auf Kleinigkeiten gelegt wurde, die das Umfeld einfach "abrunden", hier und da dezent aber treffend platzierte Dekorationen, die Welt wirkt einfach solide und griffig. Gegner als auch Styx selbst sind nicht einfach "ins Spiel geworfen" sondern mit Auge fürs Detail entwickelt. Das Wappen auf dem Brustpanzer der Wachen, der Trank der manchmal hinten am Gürtel baumelt, die kleinen Animationen in Spielpausen (die immer wieder auftreten, da man die Gegner ja beobachten sollte), das alles hebt die Immersion ungemein an.

Der Sound ist eher dezent gehalten, aber durchaus stimmig in den jeweiligen Szenerien / Alarmsituationen. Die Sprachausgabe gibt es zwar nur auf Englisch, aber das ist auch gut so. Die Untertitel machen es auch jenen, die der Englischen Sprache nicht mächtig sind, möglich, das Spiel zu verstehen, allerdings würde bei einer z.B. deutschen Vertonung einiges des bissigen Humors und der teils "aggressiven" Sprechweise flöten gehen. Und gerade das trägt zum Charme dieses Spiels ungemein bei.

[b][u]Fazit[/u][/b]

Ich habe die Styx-Reihe mit Shards of Darkness begonnen - und mir direkt den 1. Teil (Styx - Master of Shadows) auf die Wishlist gesetzt. Das Spiel hat mich vom ersten Moment an gefesselt und in seinen Bann gezogen, eine schöne Alternative zu AC und in meinen Augen absolut gleichwertig! Wer mit bissigem, teils schwarzem Humor klar kommt, auch gerne mal den "guten bösen" spielt und ein Fable für Stealth-Games hat, der sollte an diesem Titel auf keinen Fall vorbeigehen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198255184601', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1407, 'last_played': 1556030104}
review:
2年ぶりにまたプレイしてまたクリアしてみて、あらためて「いいな」と感じました。広すぎないマップ、好きな道を選べる自由度、リプレイ性の高さ、いつでも中断できる利便性、ゴブリンという主人公の特性を活かした多彩なアクション。ステルスアクションゲームとしての良い部分がしっかり揃っています。じっくりまったりステルスを遊ぶなら、という方におすすめしたくなる手堅い作品です。ステルスゲームに慣れてない方でもかなり遊ぶやすいと思います。

もちろん悪い点もいくつかあります。全9章からなるゲームですが、前半クリアしたマップを後半また挑む事になり、これはちょっと息切れ感あるな？　それと、敵に一瞬で近づき暗殺する！ 複数の敵を一瞬で消滅させる！という戦闘向けスキルがあるんですが、このゲームはノーキルこそGOODであり、殺せば殺すほどステージクリア時に得られる経験値が減るという仕様でして、戦闘向けスキルを用意しといてそれはおかしくない？と感じましたね。あとは巨大ボス戦があるんですが、それはもうステルスじゃないやんというカンジでした。

とはいえ全体的にはかなり良い作品になっていると思います。高いレベルのステルスアクションゲームでちゃんとした日本語ローカライズ完備となったらそりゃもうアナタ！セールでお安い時とかにいかがですか！？

author: {'steamid': '76561198022980827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 1522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1309, 'last_played': 1556287456}
review:
Styx, the foul mothed protagonist from Of Orcs and Men (2012) and Styx: Master of Shadows (2014) returns in the latest stealth offering from cyanide studios and was released in 2017. If you are a fan of stealth based games, where combat plays a secondary role to exploring the stages and trying to avoid the guards and traps then I would recommend Styx: shards of Darkness. It boasts a much improved stage design and layout, boss fights, changeable skill tree, slight character customization, though the AI is still very limited and co-op seems to only be playable if you are both in the same country or area.

Set nearly 70 years after Master of Shadows the goblin plague is now starting to decimate human, dark elf and dwarf towns. [spoiler] On the way to steal an artifact for a large quantity of amber (the source of which you destroyed in the last game and have seemingly become addicted to) Styx uncovers a plot to distribute new weapons that easily stop goblins, as well as a request to send all live captured goblins to the dark elf city for unknown purposes. When it all goes wrong, Styx swears revenge, and basically instigates a war between the races so he can cause as much mischief and problems to compensate his loss of payment and kill the shapeshifter who caused you all this trouble. [/spoiler]

The game does a good job of fleshing out the world that the previous two games have built. Playing Master of Shadows isn’t really necessary, but you would be missing a fair bit of backstory as not much of the previous events are explained. You would also miss the small cameos (Arkail and Barimen) and references to the other games that are littered throughout the game. [spoiler] Master of Shadows ended with the ambiguous ending of weather Styx survived the plunge into Amber or if it was an amber clone that was wearing his cape. Seems the Styx from the previous game is gone, and you are controlling an amber clone Styx, one that has some of his memories and some of his skills but most of his instincts and snarky attitude. Quartz is the new power up required to unlock Styx’s full potential (replacing amber), with Styx being a creature of Amber is makes sense. The darks elves knowing where he is also makes sense as they share the same amber hive mind that the elves of the previous game did, though they can’t communicate with him directly this time [/spoiler]

The games stages have improved quite a lot from Master of Shadows, with many of them being quite large and open, and having multiple ways to progress through them. Each stage is broken into 2 parts now, so if you use all your items for the first stage then there is a good possibility you will find the second part much harder (running out of amber for invisibility sucks). There are quite a lot of environments you sneak through, from dungeons, flying airships, multiple towns and cities. Some of the stages are re-cycled with changes, which might sound lazy but actually opens up the paths you can take through and shows you paths you likely missed the first time through. Some of the stages have you weaponless, and others are an instant game over if you are caught. Each stage has optional quests, which grant extra skill points if completed. There are also large parts that are pure platforming, though that could be the routes I took. The hit detection for breakable objects is also more finely tuned, as Master of Shadows suffered from objects being detected as hit when you were quite a distance away. 

The stages graphics and enemy design look more polished, and having different enemies that detect you in different manners forces you to change your gameplay style, with some being un-killable by sneak attacks to mess up your plans even more. The stages textures look a lot nicer this time around, less blocky and better placed. The game isn’t as dark as the first game, but I still found I had to turn the brightness up as some areas are impossible to see in otherwise.

The skill tree upgrades compliment Styx, instead of making him a more ruthless fighter or item hunter it all about stealth and item usage. Fighting is a quick way to getting yourself killed, as even trying to parry on the easiest setting is mostly pointless. Clones can be used for good effect, either to distract or kill enemies, and can be used to resurrect you on harder difficulties once unlocked. Amber vision highlights all objects now and doesn’t cost amber to use, through you do have to keep tuning it on as moving cancels it.

The challenges from the previous game return, and they are all quite doable with a little bit of knowledge of the stages and enemy patrol paths, though they will likely require a few runs. Each stage has plenty of raw materials for you to pickup which you can turn into items at a work bench. Skill points can be redistributed at any skill workbench you come across, though clothing equipment can only be changed at your hideout. This made the game far more enjoyable, and even though there isn’t much equipment it can change your playstyle considerably. Dying isn’t as bad now, as there are plenty of funny scripts that Styx runs through very similar to the batman games. There is plenty of good dialogue from Styx throughout the game, with the other main characters also putting in a good performance however, the standard enemies aren’t really noteworthy.

The game isn’t without its problems through. I found the hanging and ledge climbing had improved quite a bit, and were much easier to perform this time around, though the game does forget to advise you how to do it in the prologue. I did see a few instances where the AI knocked an object and since I didn’t touch it, it basically moved and created a roadblock for the AI to move past. I also encountered instances where the AI was stuck in a bridge (instead of on it, it was as if it spawned too low). The AI is also very inconsistent. Some guards won’t notice you if you quickly move past next to them, while others will spot you from a long distance away. I’m not sure what their field of view is, but it seems to be very narrow. Dwarves will hunt for you if you are near them, and any noise attracts all guards. Guards wont investigate a “natural death” like poisoned food or broken chandelier dropping on them. 

Co-op multiplayer is a great idea in theory, the second player takes control of a “perfect” clone (with their current powers) for the cost of ½ of the hosts life, and the setting disables being able to fight and parry guards, meaning if you are seen you are killed instantly if you are caught. You should be able to take down guards in tandem and work towards goals together or separately. If either person is killed, you can respawn at the other for the same cost in life. All the above is great if you get a game where both players have very low latency. In reality my co-op partner had such high latency I would see them skid across the floor right into guards and get killed before they knew what was happening. It made the mode useless to play, but I hurt a rib laughing so much from the absurd ways my partner goblin was caught and killed in front of me. The boss fights are a new addition and stand out, as they are very different to how you play the rest of the game 

I wouldn’t recommend the DLC for the game- I don’t own it but the game is easy enough to get through and the different cloaks and dagger you unlock naturally are more than enough.

If you are chasing 100% achievements then this game is easier to complete than Master of Shadows. You will need to play each stage a few times, but when both parts of each mission can be done within 15-20 mins it’s not too difficult. There is a skill which you can select to find all tokens, and the other runs are easy enough to do if you take your time. The rest of the achievements should either come naturally or can be easily gotten.

For more reviews please visit https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31327216/

author: {'steamid': '76561197996899722', 'num_games_owned': 1440, 'num_reviews': 266, 'playtime_forever': 2367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2328, 'last_played': 1555122855}
review:
Being a long time fan of the original Thief series, I love a really good sneak-em-up.   I heard mixed reviews about Styx, so was curious to see whether I liked it or not.

The plot is really quite engaging, although somewhat difficult to follow in places.   It's centred around a thiefly character who's caught between warring sides in a time of unrest and race warfare.  While most Goblins are mindless drones, good for almost nothing. Styx is blessed with the ability to think, talk and even plot strategies. Coupled with his baser Goblin instincts, this leads him to a life of crime.  As backstories go, it's pretty good.

As the game opens, he's just picking his way around the ruins of an old town, keeping out of sight of the humans who are trying to exterminate the goblins, considering them 'vermin'.    Then, he gets involved in politics, three different racial groups, the dark elves, the dwarves and the humans are all vying for supremacy, treating the goblins like slaves or worse.

The plot continues strongly with Styx making strange allies, and starting to unravel some of the political intrigue that's shaping his life for the worse.  Always one to make a buck, he takes the missions but demands payment.

The levels that the game plays through are very well put together, with huge amounts of parkour, climbing, swinging and exploration.  The only criticism I'd make is that some of the levels just don't feel very 'likely'.  Houses on stilts in the clouds and all that jazz.   The towns don't seem to have any logical layout, perfect for sneaking about, but you can't really see people living there.    If you like immersion, like you used to get in Thief, the illogical layouts may detract somewhat.

Completing a mission usually involves getting from A to B, killing someone, stealing something, or planting some evidence.  Occasionally a mix of the three.   Because all the levels are twisty-turny, navigating your way through can be  a real chore.    In the fishing village level you can tell that the designers went out of their way to add a variety of routes through the map, giving great chances for emergent gameplay.

Styx himself is delightfull unlikeable.  Potty-mouthed, ascerbic, rudely curt, and voiced by an excellent actor, he's the protagonist you'll love to hate.     The NPCs are similarly well voiced, with a variety of amusing comments at certain triggers.

Dotted about the maps are a pleasing number of mini-tasks, usually in the form of scarab-beetle-shaped golden trinkets to collect, or shards of 'quartz', which take some time to dig out, requiring some misdirection to keep the coast clear long enough.

As well as sneaking, Styx has the ability to use clones, which he barfs up.  The clones can be sent in like canaries to check for traps, can achieve certain mission goals, or can act as a backup body in case you die.

If you play the sneaky route through the game the clones don't have much use, nor do any of the fighting skills.  It's only if you choose to take a more aggressive path that most of the skills come into play.

I'd actually say that where Thief tries to push you down the sneaking route, Styx seems to want you to take a stabbier route.   In thief the NPCs were well-placed, and mostly few and far between.  It was their excellent placement that made them memorable.   In Styx there are NPCs everywhere.  It's really hard to walk anywhere without being spotted, because the levels are all so bright.  In some levels there are almost no shadows at all, which is funny considering the name of the game.

As Styx is rubbish in a head-on fight, he has to kill silently, like an assassin.  If you do choose to become stabby, the game is really enjoyable.  Lots of targets to kill, and their bodies to throw over ledges or stuff in boxes.  The AI is pretty good, so if you leave bodies lying around, they'll come looking for you.  Some enemies can hear, and some can even smell you.

By and large combat is done well, considering Styx is a short assassin.  Sadly, taking the stealthy approach can be a real excercise in frustration, loading and re-loading saves over and over to get the timing just right to sneak past a guard.  I know the devs wanted you to feel cool when you snuck past them, but there's so much light about, that it becomes a case of dying over and over, while learning the specific movement you need to do to get past the guards...

The game is just about the right length, perhaps 1 mission short, considering that you only get some of the more awesome loot and skills in the very last level (currently).       

I wish there was a profanity filter though, because I was unable to play this when my kids are around.  Far too many F-bombs dropped.

All in all, I'd give the game a good thumbs-up.    Everything about it is really well made.  The only downside is that on mid-to-high difficulty, the number of NPCs, their walk patterns and so on could do with some more tweaking to make the gameplay less frustrating, and more fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198304379829', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 993, 'last_played': 1554837732}
review:
Минусы:
-Противники. Это глухие и слепые трамвайчики-клоны, которые, если игрок их специально заагрит, ваншотят, регулярно в лейтгейм. Интересно ли учить маршруты кучи одинаковых мобов? Мне нет.
-Бой. Его тут нет, есть парирование, которое работает только для небольшой части противников, при этом, при удачном парировании персонажу не дается неуязвимость, отсюда - если противников больше 1 - игра не даст выиграть такой бой. Есть, кончено, оружие дальнего боя, всякие ловушки-мины, но на их крафт чаще не хватает ресурсов. Короче, игра строит правила так, что открытый бой более чем с 1 противником победой не закончишь.
-Стелс. Что это?...Не привлекая внимания, дойти из А в Б, при этом, по пути сделав С. Можно - тут и явные коридоры в маршрутах мобов, обходные пути, даже на короткое время можно стать невидимым! И это единственный вариант... В открытый бой нельзя, а стелс наскучивает из-за условностей: ИИ мобов - рельсы, однообразие игрового мира - за ним не хочется наблюдать, настолько он...синтетический и скучный.
-Прыжки. Их много, это самая важная механика игры и...она работает рандомно. Падать в обрывы здесь - как умирать в DS, это норма, но меня бесит...
-Сюжет. Он есть, но он набит условностями еще больше, чем механика игры. И чем дальше его смотришь, тем скучнее становится.
-Графика. Для части объектов тени есть - для части нет. Оружие в ножнах у мобов проходит сквозь текстуры, ловушки - каменные плиты, выдвигающиеся из потолка, тоже вылезают прямо из текстур. Несмотря на симпатичные скрины игры, в самой игре халтура по графике чувствуется сильно и угнетает без того не радужное впечатление...
Плюсы:
-Главный герой. Ломает 4 стену, на общем сказочном фоне выделяется прагматизмом 1 половину игры, здорово озвучен и приятно нарисован.

ИТОГ: не брать ни в коем случае!

author: {'steamid': '76561198096872548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2630, 'last_played': 1554150385}
review:
Ich fands im Großen und Ganzen klasse. Schade ist, dass man die Levels im Lauf der Story alle zweimal durchspielt -- das wirkt etwas unkreativ/ unbeholfen. Aber gut, wie Styx auch im Spiel gelegentlich drauf hinweist: Alles eine Budgetfrage ;)
Den bekannten Kritikpunkten kann ich mich anschließen: Die Sprungmechanik ist bei Weitem noch nicht ausgereift. Manchmal weiß man einfach nicht, ob Styx einen Sprung schaffen wird oder nicht, und manchmal ist nicht mal seine Sprungrichtung ganz vorhersagbar. Da wäre mehr Feinschliff wünschenswert gewesen. Auch der Skillbaum ist nicht allzu motivierend, obwohl ein paar nette Ideen dabei sind. Da ist noch (kreative) Luft noch oben.

Die genannten Punkte sind im Angesicht des Preises aber wirklich Kritik auf hohem Niveau.
Für Fans von Stealth Games ist Styx 2 ein unbedingtes MUSS!

review:
[h1][i]Intense continuation begins in Styx: Shards of Darkness from the previous, Master of Shadows![/i][/h1]

Despite being a fan of these type of stealth games, Styx series sure has good challenging level designs after each mission. The combat has seemingly improved. Story was fine, average gameplay hours can be pretty short unless you're one hardcore achievement hunter. Cleared missions can be replayed as much as you'd like. There is co-op feature but personally played solo so I have no idea if there's any flaw within. And I like how Styx approaches the screen to express his anger, comments and even [b][i]r o a s t[/i][/b] each time he dies because of the player. [spoiler][strike]Goddammit Styx you're wea-[/strike] JK I'm sorry for being so horrible that you had to die a lotta times, Styx. But hey please come back again for the sequel! (sincerely and hopefully)[/spoiler]

The only cons in this game I can think of for now was, it can be a bit buggy in most random times. And as usual the AIs are pretty dumb, though not all. Had fun gettin' them bamboozled and disposing those bodies from up high.



Definitely worth the time to experience and recommended for people who loves stealth games with decent amount of challenges.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998568769', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 828, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1553468168}
review:
6.5/10

I debated quite a while on whether I actually wanted to play this game. Although I loved the co-op modes in Splinter Cell: Conviction and Aragami, I knew that Styx was more of a "serious" stealth game. Additionally, neither Styx game reviewed particularly well. However, a friend of mine already owned the title from a bundle, so I snagged a copy and we got to work. Now, having played it, I've debated quite a while on whether to recommend it. 

One of the first things you notice about Styx is that you won't get a lot of platforming help. Whereas in some game series like Assassin's Creed, you'll find your character gravitating to handholds, etc., in Styx you'll need to bring a certain level of precision. Often, you'll need to change Styx's orientation while he's in the air to be facing whatever hold you'd like him to grab. This often feels finicky and my co-op partner and I missed many jumps, but there are a few occasions where this loose platforming structure allows you to take routes that don't necessarily seem intended by the game. You might be able to air-control around a barrier to grab a ledge on the other side. It feels good to create your own route through a level.

Luckily, the game offers many opportunities for this, at least at the beginning. I liked the environmental design of many of the game's levels, and found them enjoyable to move through. However, the game reuses many environments to get the most mileage out of these carefully-designed spaces.  The environments themselves are very vertical, and there is often more than one route to a given destination.

Unfortunately, the joy of creating your own route through a level is a feeling than becomes less and less frequent as the game goes on. I had the most fun in the game when I was able to pay attention to enemy patrol routes and take them down one at a time, out of sight. The game becomes more and more interested in being a hardcore stealth experience as it continues, however, soon introducing armored enemies that cannot be stabbed and armored enemies that you smell you from a considerable distance away and alert other enemies in the vicinity. In addition, levels begin to feature only one route to and from objectives. Lastly, certain levels remove your weapons and ability to kill enemies for a time.

Although it's understandable that a game would want to increase the challenge level as you progress, in practice Styx just became less and less fun for me. However, the time we'd invested, some of the more interesting puzzles, and the boss encounters helped us to stick with it.

The co-op feature was both a boon and a hindrance at times. For many of the levels, we could "leap frog" through difficult sections. Perhaps I'd be nearing an objective, and I'd hear my co-op partner die a ways behind me. Ten seconds later, I could spit him out at my location. Perhaps he would then be successful at getting through the next section, while I'm impaled by a nearby guard. Ten seconds later, I'm with him. This dance kept the game moving at an engaging clip, although it still likely took us longer than most to finish the game.

This feature was a hindrance, however, during the missions that require you to move through undetected. On these occasions, it's twice as likely that you'll be spotted, with two of you tromping around instead of just one. In addition, enemies seem to have a preternatural ability to locate your partner when you're spotted, and vice versa, even if you were out of line-of-sight.

We enjoyed the design of the skill tree, although the tree dedicated to the clone was extraneous while playing in co-op. Additionally, there were only one or two top-tier skills that I was particularly interested in getting, and there were many, many opportunities to get quartz (a quartz is necessary for each top-tier upgrade) in the missions. After taking the top-tier skills I wanted, I felt no desire to pursue side missions to acquire more quartz, as they were often quite difficult.

Finally, the game wasn't without it's share of glitchiness. I got stuck under a staircase on one occasion, my co-op partner got stuck under a roof overhang, and the final boss was actually invisible to us at the beginning of the final mission if we loaded or restarted from a checkpoint rather than re-loading the entire mission.

I remain very lukewarm about the whole experience. If you want some stealthy co-op and haven't played Aragami or Splinter Cell (Conviction or Blacklist), I'd likely recommend those instead. I'd also likely recommend Hacktag or Clandestine before Styx, even though only one of you plays as a stealth agent. However, there aren't a lot of co-op stealth experiences, so Styx was a welcome diversion. Heck, if you're a stealth purist, you might love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198428524313', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1553421701}
review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness è un gioco per gli appassionati dello stealth, e anche per chi vorrebbe approcciarsi a questo genere. Il pregio più grande di questo titolo è il suo Level Design, che ci permette di raggiungere un punto da praticamente qualsiasi posizione. Molto bella la grafica (anche se a Ultra è mal ottimizzata), l'ambientazione è buona, audio e caratterizzazione del protagonista idem. Peccato per la trama e i personaggi, entrambi molto piatti e semplici, e si sente molto l'assenza di un vero antagonista del gioco. Un altro punto a sfavore sono i dialoghi decisamente mediocri. SSOD comunque basa tutto sul gameplay, e questo è veramente ben fatto. Titolo obbligatorio per gli amanti degli assassini.

VOTO: 8.1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993436635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1553376879}
review:
Great game.  It is what the trailer shows.  Entertaining.
However... if you play with a mouse on a pc you NEED to do the following...

In your game saved folder (wich must be somewhere like C:\Users\YOUR_ACCOUNT\AppData\Local\Styx2\Saved\Config\WindowsNoEditor) you will find a file named Game.ini.

Add these lines to the file to get the mouse movement 5x faster.

[/script/styx2.styx2playercontroller]
MouseTurnRatio=1.0f

MouseTurnRatio is used to divide the movement of the mouse and is 5 by default, the lower you'll set it the faster the cursor will move. You must restart the game to get the changes effective in game (this will be accessible from the option UI in our future games).

/!\ don't set it to 0 as it will break the universe (dividing by 0 may crash your game)

The mouse sensitivity can then be a more appropriate level and you can fully enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993723984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1249, 'last_played': 1553283086}
review:
Another good Styx game! I love that there is a difficulty setting to turn off your melee (can still stealth kill) and parrying and make all enemies kill you in one hit. Played as a pure stealth game like that, I found it incredibly fun. 

The vertical layout of levels was just as nice as in the first game. The boss fights were just as annoying and out of place as in the first game. Occasionally Styx failed to grab on to ledges, sending me to my death, but not often enough to be a real problem. Overall the stealth gameplay is very solid, the graphics and music are good, the dialogue is fun, and the story is decent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041887851', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1552934186}
review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness est la suite directe de Styx : Master of Shadows, et se déroule quelques mois après le premier. Il s'agit d'un jeu d'infiltration/action sur fond de fantasy.

Le jeu reprend tous les bons éléments du premier opus en les bonifiant : les arbres de talents sont plus complets et on ressent une réelle progression du personnage. Le level design est bien foutu, permettant plusieurs voies d'accès à chaque objectif. Pour ajouter à l'immersion, en écoutant les conversations des PNJ sur la carte, on peut découvrir l'existence d'objectifs secondaires. 
Mais le point que je retiendrais le plus, c'est le personnage de Styx lui même, par son cynisme à tout épreuve, et sa conscience d'être un personnage de jeu vidéo (spécialement quand vous mourrez), donnant lieu à des remarques bien placés de sa part. 

Un très bon jeu en somme, dans lequel vous retrouverez le stress de vous faire découvrir tout en riant des commentaires du personnage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023154119', 'num_games_owned': 5242, 'num_reviews': 316, 'playtime_forever': 1062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1062, 'last_played': 1551718445}
review:
Podobały mi się poprzednie gry ze Styxem, choć były dalekie od ideału. Of Orcs and Men nie było do końca przemyślane pod kątem gameplayu, a mimo to wciągnęło mnie i z czasem bawiło coraz bardziej. W Master of Shadows ork Arkail poszedł w odstawkę i dostaliśmy niezłą, choć zabugowaną skradankę z ciekawą historią. Shards of Darkness z kolei... nie jest grą złą, ale według mnie najmniej ciekawą z całej trójki.

Może gdyby skupiono się po prostu na zrobieniu sequela, poprawie słabostek poprzedniczki, byłoby super. To nadal dobra skradanka. Ma niezłe mapy, które dają wiele możliwości na wykonanie zadań i dostanie się z punktu A do B. Wielkich zmian tu nie ma. Najciekawszą jest nowa zdolność do odblokowania, pozwalająca zamienić się miejscem z klonem. Reszta się aż tak nie wyróżnia - może poza craftingiem, bo jest dla niego osobne drzewko rozwoju i pozwala montować różne pułapki. Problem w tym, że większość to rzeczy przydatne tylko dla zabójców, a ja lubię w skradankach... skradanie. I staram się nie zabijać, więc nowe zabawki testowałem z ciekawości na innym zapisie i już do nich nie wracałem. Z różnic na plus - krasnoludy w późniejszych misjach nie są tak wkurzające, jak elfy w MoS.

Jeśli chodzi o wady - mam wrażenie, że nic się nie zmieniło od poprzedniczki. Powtarzanie tych samych map w paru misjach, rozmaite błędy, bezsensowne z punktu widzenia architekta haki na ścianach. Człowiek liczy, że kolejne gry będą lepsze, a tu nie dość, że nie ma poprawy, to jeszcze można twórców posądzić o regres. Pamiętam, że bardzo nie pasowała mi końcówka starszego Styxa, która zmuszała do walki. Tu nie ma czegoś takiego, ale dowalono nam dwóch "bossów". Choć w sumie pasują do reszty bardziej, bo polegają na przekradaniu się między ścianami, są zwyczajnie kiepskie. Fabuła też mnie za bardzo nie interesowała, a w pozostałych grach z serii była mocnym punktem.

Mam wrażenie, że ten ostatni minus spowodowany jest nowością w postaci co-opa. Może uznano, że historia nie jest tak ważna, jak gra się w dwójkę? No dobra, przebolałbym, w końcu najważniejsza jest grywalność. Niestety, jest pewien problem. Tryb ten jest trochę niedorobiony. Mój kompan narzekał, że czasem nie pokazują mu się cele misji, co skutecznie utrudniało grę. Nie dostawał też osiągnięć. Ale najgorszy jest system wczytywania. Z jakiegoś powodu gra zapisuje jedynie pozycję hosta. Śmierć działa tu tak, że po paru sekundach można się odrodzić obok kompana - to jest w porządku. Jednak po wczytaniu zapisu (a w tego typu grach save & load jest na porządku dziennym) partner znika. I musi zaczynać grę obok mnie. Myślisz sobie, że można się rozdzielić podczas przeszukiwania miasta? Jeden błąd i jeden z was będzie musiał pokonywać drogę na nowo. Fatalny pomysł.

Moje odczucia związane z grą najlepiej podsumowałaby ocena "mieszane". W sumie bawiłem się nieźle, zwłaszcza w trybie współpracy, jednak nie podoba mi się fakt, że stare bolączki nadal tu są, a do tego mamy nowe. Jeśli powstanie kolejna gra w tym świecie, oby była lepsza.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076161790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1178, 'last_played': 1548501279}
review:
No spoilers in this review. I have not played the first one in the series.

I really enjoyed this game and I would recommend it to anyone who likes stealth games. The story is interesting and exciting (even though the ending is a bit weak) and Styx is one of the funniest main characters I've "met". His comments are hilarious and it really added to my enjoyment of the game. The game mechanics are mostly smooth and easy to understand, but sometimes I'd fall down a ledge instead of him holding on to it :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198170400501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1531495400}
review:
Honestly, I like the first one more. The story is always my go to when judging whether or not I liked a game and I can tell you that the ending of this game left a lot to be desired. This sequel felt more action oriented compared to its predecessor instead of the more stealth oriented progression. I'm talking about boss fights, there's two that stand out in my mind that honestly took me right out of the immersion by being loud, obnoxious and too damn long.

They're a lot more blatant with their humor this time too, making references to other stealth games like Dishonored, Assassin's Creed and Thief. They're funny easter eggs for people who are familiar with the other franchises, but rely too heavily on other people getting the reference.

The death scenes are fun though, Styx's crass attitude and foul mouth are still hands down my favorite part of the game. But if you're bad at the game or just can't seem to latch onto the platform you so clearly should be able to reach, they get old quick. 

The world looks great, the graphics got an upgrade. The voice acting is great as usual. But the story, especially after Master of Shadows, just falls a little flat. The ending left me feeling frustrated and robbed of a proper conclusion. That alone is enough to make me advise you to wait for a decent sale before getting this game. It's good, but it's not great, and that really is a damn shame.

review:
Would be a really great game if it weren't for all the bugs. I was having a lot of fun up until a certain point.

Throughout the entire game I found myself constantly failing to grab ledges despite impacting directly upon them, guards seeing and reaching through solid material, aerial kills functioning perhaps a third of the time. 

The part where I gave up was during a mission where the game would not progress despite the objective very clearly being completed. This is also hardly a new issue, having been brought up March 17th, which the developers had acknowledged.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992764918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 428, 'playtime_forever': 1453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1361, 'last_played': 1551814849}
review:
If you've played the first Styx, know that the actual gameplay and stealth kill actions are completely copy and pasted. The enemy AI is the same (broken). Example: Turn off light a room above where actual guard is stationed or patrolled, will be alerted. The platforming is broken, visually bugs and is unresponsive at times. I've also had issues with fps drops when using amber vision randomly. But there's co-op. The story and voice acting is pretty good and with co-op ALOT of good laughs can be had, just because of how broken the game is. If you are looking for a stealth fix, this will be right up your alley. But if you are looking for a stealth masterpiece, you'll be disappointed.

I do hope in the future if they continue this series they polish the gameplay, add more assassination techniques/animations, more interactive environments, and double team animations for co-op. Maybe also custom maps for those that want to continue playing once they complete the game, especially with a friend or friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087244858', 'num_games_owned': 708, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2135, 'last_played': 1551457377}
review:
遊戲的時間軸接續前作，在主角來到某海上保壘定居，過著偷拐搶騙(?)的悠閒生活
這一次的場景設計，相較於上一代立體了許多，也沒有地圖可以看了，相對的探索起來也複雜了一些

主線解法也從一條路走到底，變成多了很多「B計畫」，可以避免單調的處理主線
遊戲中也混雜了許多支線，支線大多要從npc的口述之中獲得線索，才能去執行，如果不小心略過線索就會錯過了

操作上相較於前作，多了一些攀爬擺盪繩索，以及在岩縫中移動方式，操控感比前作好一些
能使用的道具也更多了，雖然需要點技能後才能製作，還要蒐集素材以及堆疊數有點少，不過也大幅度的增加了遊戲性

不過遊戲BUG也不少，前作遇到NPC的AI卡住的時候，重新讀檔可以馬上解決，而本作沒辦法靠讀檔解決，甚至在讀檔後還會有讀檔前的慣性在
物理慣性有點讓我失望，前作的屍體「很滑」，很容易從邊緣或樓梯上滑下去
原本以為虛幻4引擎會更擬真一點，但是屍體放在邊緣的時候會像黏住一樣，雖然放在更外圍一點還是會往下掉，但是可能連自己都一起往下掉

相較於前作遊戲性提升了不少，劇情很可惜沒有什麼太大轉折，一路順遂的就玩完了
不過結局讓我覺得有點突然，我以為後面還要一點收尾，結果就開始人員名單了

author: {'steamid': '76561198025802185', 'num_games_owned': 2180, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 914, 'last_played': 1544273729}
review:
[h1]Tu en as un joli gobelin... Viens je vais t'en montrer un vrai.[/h1]

Il y a des suites de jeux qui, bien que ne changeants pratiquement pas leurs formules, arrivent à être surprenamment bien plus intéressantes qu'on ne pourrait le croire... Et c'est bien évidemment le cas de Styx Shards of Dark Darkness qui, par rapport à Master of Shadows, ne solutionne que la moitié de ses défauts tout en ne touchant pas d'un chouïa la formule du précédent épisode.

Après un premier épisode qui faisait office de jeu de rôle et un second qui propulsait Cyanide dans le genre de l'infiltration, Styx Shards of Darkness est l'occasion de retrouver pour la troisième fois notre très cher gobelin... Mais en VO uniquement, ce qui est dommage quand on sait que le personnage était plutôt bien doublé dans Of Orcs and Men ; Et qui l'est encore plus quand Styx balance des punchlines en pleine phase d'infiltration : ce qui fait qu'on a très souvent tendance à zapper certains dialogues pourtant assez drôles.
Pour continuer avec les défauts qui n'ont pas du tout étaient corrigés avec ce nouvel opus, on se retrouve encore une fois à devoir refaire des niveaux déjà parcourus : ainsi, les missions 6, 7 et 8 sont justes des redites des premiers niveaux du jeu avec un point de départ et des objectifs différents.
Concernant le gameplay, on pourrait noter que tout comme dans Master of Shadows, Styx a toujours un peu de mal pour s’accrocher à certaines surfaces.
Enfin, on se retrouve encore une fois à devoir affronter des boss pas forcément bien intéressants bien qu'on s'éloigne tout de même de la séquence de fin de Master of Shadows qui pour le coup était quand même assez horrible.

Pour parler de points plus positifs, on notera une grosse amélioration sur la partie graphique du titre, Master of Shadows faisait penser à de la PS3 ; Ici, on se rapproche bien plus des graphismes PS4, pas mal pour un jeu à petit budget.
Dommage cependant que l'antialiasing choisit floute autant les décors, on a uniquement le choix de le régler entre faible, moyen, élevé et ultra sans pour autant pouvoir le désactiver ou en choisir en autre : j'aurais préféré me coltiner du Super Sampling plutôt qu'un truc bien dégueulasse qui ressemble vachement à du TXAA (à savoir le pire antialiasing de l'univers).
Le point sur lequel les développeurs se sont le plus améliorés est sans nul doute sur l'élaboration des niveaux, que ce soit sur leur apparence ou leur level-design, ils sont à la fois plus agréables à parcourir et plus diversifiés que dans Master of Shadows tout en étant construits de manière bien plus intelligentes : s'il y a bien un point sur lequel les développeurs se sont améliorés et qui fait que je retiendrais Styx Shards of Darkness c'est sur celui-là.

Finalement, le seul défaut qui n'était pas présent dans Master of Shadows mais qui l'est dans Shards of Darkness c'est la fin cliffhanger expédiée en une trentaine de secondes et qui nous laisse clairement sur la fin (lol) [spoiler]vu qu'on ne tue même pas le méchant principal.[/spoiler]

En somme, sans pour autant révolutionner la formule, Styx Shards of Darkness est un titre tout aussi sympathique voir plus intéressant que son prédécesseur. Bien que ne renouvelant pas le genre de l'infiltration, le titre arrive sans aucun mal à redonner du souffle à un genre qui actuellement en a bien besoin.

Points positifs :
+ Des niveaux bien plus agréables à parcourir
+ L'humour
+ Graphiquement bien au-dessus de ce que faisait Master of Shadows

Points négatifs :
- La fin un peu trop vite expédiée
- Une partie des défauts non corrigés par rapport à Master of Shadows (allers-retours, absence de doublage, imprécisions dans le gameplay et boss)
