author: {'steamid': '76561198038261322', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 3092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1616185065}
review:
Получил в подарок от очень хорошего человека (Таня, ещё раз спасибо!)

Игра - в духе предыдущей игры серии. По сути, если вы играли в Styx: Master of Shadows - то уже всё поняли и бежите её покупать. По сути дела плюсы и минусы те же - туповатый и не всегда логичный ии, небольшие баги, паршивая боёвка. Но Стикс, всё-таки, не воин, а злобный гоблин-вор.

Сюжет на мой взгляд тут чуть похуже, чем в предыдущей части, но всё равно неплох. Прибавилось вариативности в прохождении, что увеличивает реиграбельность. Из-за гномов играть стало сложнее. Порадовал апгрейд системы крафта.

В общем, если вам понравилась предыдущая часть - покупайте не глядя, особенно по скидке. С нетерпением жду продолжения, а пока постараюсь выполнить все побочные квесты [spoiler] тут появляется недобитый Баримен и его можно будет завалить, ахахахахахаххаа![/spoiler].

review:
Pros:
- Decent graphics
- Hardcore stealth
- intresting protagonist 
- Not too long not too short
- Level design is pretty good

Cons:
- Average story
- Very few abilities and meaningful skills
- Climbing is meh
- Some parts get boring 
- Ending leaves a bit to be desired
- By the final hours you ask "what was my goal again?"

8/10 not because it's "objectively" deserves it but I personally enjoyed it regardless of the issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973911747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1515998285}
review:
After completing my first playthrough, I believe it's time to write a brief review.

First and foremost, this is primarily a stealth game. While you can take a more action-oriented approach, it is not exactly ideal for the tiny, "squishy" Styx. You'll feel vulnerable to attacks, especially at first. However once you level up, several playstyle options open up for those who wish to "ghost" missions, sadistically assassinate any enemies that stand in your way, or perhaps sacrifice a few goblin spawn to the guards for the greater good. So there's some decent gameplay variety to be had.

Since the comparison is inevitable, yep, Shards of Darkness feels rather similar to Thief. The big difference is the main character. Styx is a little, ugly, green goblin with a personality not terribly dissimilar to Deadpool. The character may not be everyone's ideal, especially if you're coming into this game with expectations derived from the old Thief series. I didn't mind the character, in fact on occasion Styx gave me a chuckle.

Another big positive is the map design. For the most part, the maps/missions are large, sprawling areas with a great variety of paths to accomplish your goal. The only down-side is that there is some slight re-use of maps. What this means is, you'll do a mission on a specific map, then a couple missions later, return to the same map for a different mission. I can forgive this because the time of day has changed. Now, that may not sound like a big thing, but doing stealth in broad daylight when the first time you were on the same map was at night provides a much different experience.

The game is not without faults however. I would say the most glaring shortcoming of Shards of Darkness is related to the controls. Controlling Styx feels a bit clunky, certain animations feel a bit clunky, and as a result of this clunkiness, you'll probably die a few times. You could hit the right button, be looking the right direction, yet Styx just doesn't grab that ledge and instead plunges to his death while yelling "F--- YOU!!!" (with doppler effect). One thing to keep in mind is that the Steam controller emulation interferes with the in-game controller support, so you'll want to disable the Steam controller emulation prior to starting the game otherwise there will be reduced functionality.

TL;DR
While the controls can be frustratingly clunky, the excellent level design and fun gameplay reminiscent of the classic Thief games makes Shards of Darkness well worth playing.

review:
I felt greatly conflicted while rating Styx: Shards of Darkness. I actually enjoyed the game very much, and I think it has greatly improved its gameplay both mechanically and directionally upon its predecessor, Master of Shadows. Both are fun games, worth playing because of the strength of the Orcs to Men universe, because of the well-executed in-game mechanics and abilities of Styx, and because of how creative you can be in your approach to levels. Yet while I recommend Master of Shadows, I do not recommend Shards of Darkness. Why this juxtaposition?

First, let's address what's good about the game. Mechanically, Styx himself as a character moves more smoothly through the environment and is more versatile than his previous rendition, and I played this game repeatedly just because I enjoyed playing Styx in different ways and challenging myself. He is a well-designed stealth protagonist, with some of the most innovative powers I have seen in a stealth title. The ability to make a clone allows for unparalleled creativity in how you move about the map. Styx can become invisible, and while giving invisibility to a stealth character seems a bit on the nose, it is still balanced because of its relatively short (ordinary) duration and high amber cost (the resource used to fuel Styx's magical abilities). He has more expendable items and a crafting system that allows him to replenish his stock, customization options for his dagger and outfit, and numerous branching paths for his powers. This is the primary reason that the game is worth playing: it's really fun to be a goblin! Props are owed to the devs for developing such a fun and mechanically well-designed character, and if gameplay was all that mattered I could give SoD a 4/5 for this alone.

The graphics in this game are beautiful, and the physics are fairly tight. Level design continues to be good, although they sprawl a lot more and have less emphasis on vertical space than the previous game. Vertical space is still very well utilized, though, and I think this has always been one of the Styx games' best selling points. Shards of Darkness provides many interesting stealth scenarios, and the world you're put in is thematic and fun to explore.

Now to address the bad: the story is choppy and feels lazy, unpolished, and thrown together. Master of Shadows had a fluid and purpose driven story that gave significance to your actions. Styx's core motivation in this adventure is revenge, which in context seems forced and petty. The cutscenes are animated well enough, but then end abruptly with all of the characters in them having vanished. It's jarring and confusing: when it first happened to me, 
I was in utter disbelief at the fact that they released the game in this condition. Compared to the well-designed and interesting narration of the story from Master of Shadows, this story and its telling are surprisingly weak.

The skill tree can hit a critical mass that breaks the game's back at certain points. For example: a particular combination of items and abilities allows you to remain permanently invisible while leaping from foe to foe, making them invisible and completely silent as they die, and causing their bodies melt without a trace. The "Quartz" upgrade to regenerate amber completely nullifies any need to play conservatively, and you can spam abilities with almost reckless abandon knowing that you can hide in a barrel for a minute and replenish it. When you hit these points, the difficulty can nose dive; I played through the game twice, and I decided that I had to put it on its top difficulty and run with no upgrades outside of the item upgrade tree to feel an enjoyable challenge from the second playthrough. This is how I feel that this game is best experienced: there are so many amazing stealth mechanics that they've implemented in the game that are completely voided by some of Styx's upgrade options. I feel his best designed upgrades are side-grades that give him a reward for skillful play while punishing mistakes. The amber dagger is the best example of this that I've found: a legitimate downside that can't be mitigated with other abilities (taking increased damage) for a unique perk (amber regen on kill).

Some ability upgrades involve unlocking a different type of kill, or use a new item. These upgrades feel like they should be part of the game from the start, as part of its appeal is how versatile you can be when navigating the levels. Limiting that versatility and spoon feeding it throughout the game makes the early levels feel more stagnant and limited. I feel it would be better to have no upgrade system at all and a complete yet versatile character from the start

The AI seems inconsistently oblivious: sometimes they will spot you from far off, and other times you'll be poking around at their elbows and taking things off of tables right in front of them without them batting an eye.

Shards of Darkness sees the return of the abominable parry mechanic from the first game, which will lock you into combat with an opponent who detects you and get you killed because you have to run backwards through the map to try and break it. It is actually easier to play the game on a harder difficulty or while using the tapered dagger because it will disable this mechanic. This target lock needs to at least be toggleable.

There are some bad mechanical changes: you can no longer drop bodies off of cliffs, and enemies will no longer "un-alert" if they kill your clones. Jump distance is now determined Styx's momentum prior to the jump, and you can't really steer him mid-air to change direction; it's much harder to control Styx mid-air than the first game, and you will fall to your death an upsetting amount trying to get to ledges you can't truly grab.

There is a co-op feature, but I have tried several times to make it work and could not find matches at any time of day. Best of luck.

Styx's personality has, in my opinion, devolved. He incessantly mocks other stealth titles, his thoughts and musings are more juvenile, and his dialogue is riddled with sexual references and fourth wall breaks. This really takes you out of what is ordinarily an immersive experience. His gruffness and simplicity in the first game were more than serviceable, as he's a sociopathic goblin assassin: he doesn't need to be like a dirty old man. The writing of this game was truly cringe-worthy at times.

About halfway through the game there are recycled maps used, which is just lazy. There are some new opponents and objectives added in at these points to try and make it different, but it doesn't cut it.

In conclusion, I rate Styx: Shards of Darkness with a 2/5: a below average or niche purchase. Don't get me wrong: this is not a bad or unplayable game. I had fun with it; it falls more into the "niche purchase" category than a truly below average game. But it is a niche style of game to begin with, and the problems I've listed are definitely irritating and will make what is already an odd style of game unpleasant for some. It is better than Master of Shadows in some ways: graphically it is improved, and the gameplay is actually better in most respects. Still, the problems I mentioned lower its quality. I had to purposely handcuff myself to get a more challenging and enjoyable experience, and this was worsened by the weaker AI. The parry system and the release of what should be starting content in the form of upgrades are still as problematic as they were in the first game. Recycled maps and jarring, choppy storytelling make the game feel lazy and rushed, and the significant changes to Styx's personality are a huge risk that didn't pay off in my case. If you are, like me, very fond of the gameplay of Master of Shadows and want to experience an improved form of that, this game is worth buying. Its gameplay is solid. But if you have never played a Styx game before or are looking for a more complete and challenging game, see Master of Shadows.

review:
Entretenido juego de sigilo. Mejora al primero en todo.
PROS: - Styx y su humor.
           - Sigilo puro, olvídate de combatir.
           - Mapas grandes y verticales, con muchas rutas y maneras de afrontar la misión.
           - Objetivos secundarios y retos que te hacen jugarlo al menos dos veces.
           - El guardado rápido, aunque hace el juego más fácil.
CONTRAS: - Gráficamente discreto.
                  - Es normal ver algún enemigo bugeado.
                  - No está doblado al castellano, lo que hace perderte algunos comentarios por estar pendiente de la acción en 
                        pantalla.
                  - Aunque la historia ha mejorado, sigue siendo poco interesante.
                  - No demasiado largo (15 horas con casi todo conseguido).
                  - Los saltos siguen siendo imprecisos.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983545966', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1529188808}
review:
Всё тот же Стикс, что и раньше.

Принципиальных отличий никаких.
Непонравившиеся моменты те же самые - слишком мало способов нелетального устранения врагов, слишком много гоняют туда-сюда по одним и тем же уровням, искусственно увеличивая игровое время.
Из коробки нет совершенно никакой русской локализации (даже субтитров), при этом за игру просят 2000 рублей, как за AAA-проект (но это явно вторичная игра, хоть и крепко сбитая).

Из положительных изменений - навыков стало больше, дизайн уровней стал лучше (значительно больше нелинейности). Художники тоже поработали на славу, некоторые места выглядат ну очень красиво и антуражно.

В целом я остался доволен игрой, так как получил от неё ровно то, чего и ждал. Мне она досталась за 2 Евро (купил как кусок бандла от Humblebundle), этих денег игра явно стоит.

author: {'steamid': '76561198424523804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1544197546}
review:
Нам предлагают отправиться в опасное приключение в поисках сокровищ, где месть и предательство идут рука об руку. С самого начала игры нам предлагают заняться любимым для уникального гоблина делом – воровством, но даже такая забавная мелочь как похищение волшебного скипетра превращается в запутанную историю с глобальным заговором. Игра разделена на девять миссий, каждая из которых заканчивается в убежище, где можно заново пройти старые задания, изготовить предметы и прокачать специальные умения. Сами миссии обычно состоят из нескольких секций, разделенных экраном загрузки.
Styx: Shards of Darkness похожа на первую часть, пытаясь максимально сконцентрироваться на стелс-прохождении. Почти все задания предполагают множество вариантов достижения цели. Вы можете обойти всех патрульных, перемещаясь по скрытым проходам, цепляясь за веревки и выступы на стенах, или, используя укрытия, убивать стражников по одному, постепенно расчищая дорогу. Можно уйти от прямого столкновения, отравляя воду и еду, или заманивая громкими звуками группы противников под люстры. Игру рекомендую ставлю 7 из 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112020555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1529185501}
review:
Bellissimo gioco, puro stealth. Dovete avere un minimo di pazienza e dovete spremere il cervello perche non e un gioco facile.
Le mappe sono gigantiche e offrono tantissime possibilita di completare una zona e la missione.
Ci sono una varieta di nemici, ognuno da approcciare diversamente.
Si hanno degli elementi di crafting e progressione delle skill come un rpg.
Il combattimento diciamo inesistente perche si dovrebbe evitare al 100% di uccidere, alle 2 difficolta piu alte infatti non si ha questa possibilita.
Longevita buona per questo genere, la storia mi e piaciuta grazie a dei colpi di scena e alla comicita del protagonista. Molto rigiocabile e si puo fare anche in co-op online con un amico.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313839700', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1528910310}
review:
No sabía de la existencia de este juego hasta que fue uno que me toco de rebote en un Bundle mensual. De haberlo conocido antes posiblemente lo hbaría comprado individualmente. Me ha gustado mucho.
Eres un trasgo (goblin) experto en robar, pues es muy sigiloso. La historia es bastante simple y las misiones consisten en ir de un sitio a otro sigilosamente robando objetos y asesinando objetivos, ocultándote de humanos, elfos y enanos que matan a todo tarsgo que pillan. Pero el protagonista es muy carismático, y a pesar de su personalidad de trasgo es divertido. Rompe la cuarta pared, haciendo en varias ocasiones referencia a que está dentro de un videojuego, pero las suelta bastante sutilmente. Excepto cuando mueres. Pues lo primero que verás a continuación será a styx golpeando tu pantalla y echándote la bronca de formas muy diferentes a lo largo del juego.
Es un juego simpático que se desarrolla en escenarios bastante bien pensados en los que es dificil perderse a pesar de las pocas indicaciones que se dan para avanzar. Contiene bromas que hacen sonreir y un protagonista lo menos curioso. Así como habilidades de sigilo que se van desarrollando y que junto con la jugabilidad dan una experiencia muy agradable. Yo he terminado el juego pensando como trasgo y, lo que al principio me suponia una hora y varias pilladas, al final me lo he terminado pasando de una sola vez y en menos tiempo.
Una pequeña joya que me he encontrado sin querer.

Edito para añadir que la mayor parte del juego la he jugado desconectado. Terminarlo me habra llevado unas 11 horas y 30 minutos, no las cuatro horas que marca arriba.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202895208', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1101, 'last_played': 1658803438}
review:
Por mais que eu tenha recebido o jogo pelo Humble Bundle, eu ainda sim acho o preço relativamente razoavel. Talvez espere uma promoção para nao machucar muito a conta bancaria. Enfim vamos ao que interessa.

Styx: Shards of Darkness é um jogo em terceira pessoa com um foco quase completo em furtividade, e eu digo quase pois há uma mecânica de combate porém eu explicarei ela mais a frente. Começando pelo enredo: Um tempo após os eventos de Styx: Master of Shadows (que eu nao tive a oportunidade de jogar ainda), Styx se encontra em Thoben, uma região decrépita, corrompida pela gangue local, denominada "A Guilda". Após fazer um trabalho para seu empregador, chamado Ephron, Styx se encontra emboscado pelo pelotão de Helledryn, suposta capitã da facção C.A.R.N.A.G.E, um grupo de caçadores de goblins. Porém, Helledryn revela ter um trabalho para o goblin falante, de roubar o cetro de um embaixador, e é ai que a historia começa a se desenrolar.

Em questão de jogabilidade, ela é, como eu disse anteriormente, focada em furtividade, porém a mecânica de combate no jogo envolve você utilizar do famoso parry para atordoar o seu atacante. Mas styx é muito fragil, o que dificulta o combate com mais de um oponente. Portanto o jogo o influencia a tomar o caminho mais facil de sobreviver, a furtividade.

O personagem Styx tem um fator incrivel de carisma, alguns podem gostar ou nao da sua personalidade estilo "Deadpool", na qual ele faz piadas constantes, muitas delas envolvendo a quebra da quarta parede, como por exemplo nas telas de morte, onde o goblin insulta o jogador pela sua falta de habilidade.

Falando em telas de morte, você provavelmente vai ver muitas delas durante a sua jogatina, pois a dificuldade do jogo é de um grau deveras desafiador, mesmo na dificuldade mais baixa. O jogo faz você pensar em mais de uma estrategia para atravessar o ambiente pois em qualquer momento um erro de calculo pode ser feito, e deve ser consertado antes de comprometer a missão

Visualmente falando, nao há muito que falar. O jogo é bonito, o visual da maioria das fases ajuda na tematica do game.

Em minhas considerações finais eu gostaria de recomendar muito esse jogo a todos os amantes de jogos furtivos, porém a satisfação nao eh estrondosa em questao de tempo de jogo, pois a historia é meio curta, alem de você poder rejogar as fases para conquistar uma pontuação maior.

Portanto esse jogo está recomendado para aqueles que gostam de furtividade e querem um desafio.

Nota final: 9,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198084385268', 'num_games_owned': 4156, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 1628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1390, 'last_played': 1529878900}
review:
Main story can be achieved within 12-14 hours while sticking with only completing the Gold insignia for not being seen per mission. Add about 4-6 hours for both Speedrun and No kills achievements. Last achievement is a bit of a timewaster which is getting specific items per stage which can be easily seen with a skill

The game is strictly a stealh game. Level design still retains the quality from Styx 1. Graphics are improved a lot. Story is a continuation of the first game and some knowledged of it is required to understand some of the current scenario. 

If you liked Styx 1 YOU WILL LIKE THIS. This is a continutation of that game which retains most of the same feel. Level design is again top notch. Styx still use the same skills for most of the time but there are skill trees to further improve them



Pros-
- A Great Stealth game
- Gameplay is nearly identical from the first game which i really liked. Don't change what is not broken
- Achievements are just hard enough to be worth getting EXCEPT for the item collecting BUT they added a skill for that
- Ingame Dialogue is just right But...(see cons)
- Managed to stop my FOrtnite addiction


Cons
- The Humor\Dialogue for Dying is a Hit or Miss
- Overall plot is ok BUT the story can be better specially if they added more character interactions with the people you encounter SPECIALLY doing side quests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079958655', 'num_games_owned': 703, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1528740394}
review:
This game is a bit of a coinflip for me but first off, don't buy this game at full price, it is not worth it.

I am not going to write some comprehensive review of this game, however, before you buy this game keep a few things in mind.

1. The game can be played in a fewn different ways, but if you want to complete the extra objetives, every missions is gonna take you a lot longer, for better or worse.

2. Only play this game if you enjoy the slow and methodical part of stealth, as killing can be rewarding but seems to be dissuaded.

3. Lastly and unfortunately, the ending of the story is complete trash and if you are here for a good story, find another game.

So, if you like the slow pace of stealth games and don't mind a mediocre at best story, you're in for a good time with our witty goblin friend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198394469594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1528619642}
review:
this game down right pissed me off. it is one thing to have a game set up so bad that you die constantly, it is another for the game to make fun of you for it. the game may even have been tolerable if you could turn off the repetitive death screens.

so you have a knife. you can only pull it out when you are targeted, not when you are going to prepare to fight. you can't use the knife to attack. you know, a weapon used for slicing and stabbing? ya, you "perry" with it... sure. if you miss-time the first swing you have to get attacked the second time so you can try to time the next hit. some people kill you in 3 attacks, some with 2. magically some can throw a knife at you from 100 yards away and kill you in one hit. even at full health

croutch walking by a building? yet the 7 people inside are now agro'ing you. window? nope, these people can see through walls. hit an noise making object? nope a mouse must have farted and spooked them. someone agro'ed you? well be prepared to wait 5 minutes for the agro to go away, and sometimes don't even go near you. but if you move and NOT wait he'll be ready to throw a knife at you from accross the stage.

a dead body can rase an alarm, but you can't hide the body. you can drop them off the edge into the water, but your feet are not where your feet are and you now fall to your death. if you don't go RIGHT up to the edge when you drop the corpse you will get their head caught on the floor and they'll hang there.

see that rope, well there is a 50/50 shot it is climable. on the ledge moving right? randomly the camera angle will change, your character is now looking up and you stopped moving. don't worry though, because while you battle trying to continue moving on the ledge a guard will see you and help with his stabby stick.

you can jump from 30 feet high, but 31 will hurt you and 32 will kill you, even if it is a soft roof. somehow you can fall from a rope at 50 feet and be ok. sometimes you will see a rope that you reasonably can jump to, well it is 2 inches to far away and you fall to your death. need to hang to the ledge below you? fall to your death.

upgrade the ability to fight with the knife? apparently not. upgrade the arial attack? well... you can jump infront of the enimy and they can stab you...WINNING. didn't get to upgrade much, but so far they don't seem to work.

this is one of those games where you are fighting a battle, not againct the enimy, but with the game itself. you make so many mistakes trying to understand the limitations of what you can interact with, and when you think you figured it out, you find out this time the rules change, and just before a savepoint. so all that 30+ minutes of work you put in clearing everything, despite the game, well get prepared to do it all over again. this isn't a game where "Get Good" applies. you don't get better at the game, you just learn the mistakes that are still left in the game, and how to adapt to them. not enjoyable.

what really pisses me off is that i wanted to like this game. i really did. it looked really good and the gameplay looked fun. the humor seemed to be right up my ally and i had high hopes. the damn thing is just way to buggy. when i play a game i expect to fight the enimy, not the programmers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024983274', 'num_games_owned': 2676, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1308, 'last_played': 1589300261}
review:
Played on Goblin difficulty, so that once you are busted, you are basically done (no melee, and no parry). This hugely affect the gameplay mechanics, and how you approach the levels (in my opinion, for the better)

All-around good game: decent graphics, really intrincate and huge levels, sound and music.
If you love stealth, this game is a good bet, but I understand that if the genre is not your cup of tea, you may find it a little tedious until you get some of the habilities to make it more fun.

I have found three major features that I really enjoyed: 
First, you have different paths to finish the levels, so replayability is decent, and it is encouraged, because you always go back to your hub, and you can replay any level and keep the progress. 
Second, the game even presents alternative solutions to objectives when you are roaming around. Some of these solutions are quite funny
Third, the AI is vastly improved, and some old tricks do not work anymore. For example, enemies can climb out of windows, into rooftops, and some can also smell you (particularly frustrating)

I have found three issues during my 20 hour run: 
First, re-loading from a specific boss fight brings you back to your hub, so you have to go through 2 different loading screens each time you die. 
Second, the game quick save feature does not reset the world, so you may end up saving in a really bad/glitched situation. Just take a minute to look around before saving (alien:isolation comes to mind)
Third, I don't know why the game takes easily 1 minute to boot into the corporate logos (arkham knight comes to mind)
 
The game includes new elements, while perfecting others, and offering a more open experience than the first instalment (HITMAN comes to mind), while still keeping it raunchy, urgent and very varied. I am ready for the 3rd one, guys. 

Some last minute recommendations: get rid of the intro videos using the pcgamingwiki guide, and go into game settings and disable the taunt after every death. I know it may sound funny/cheesy at first, but after dying for the 100 time, it is torture

7.8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198100592313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2023, 'last_played': 1538242906}
review:
Stealth action sequel about hard (and not very fairly) working goblin. 

Picks up from where Master of Shadows ended, but plot isn't attached any way and it seems Styx suffers from amnesia after his last "dive". But I would like to recomend starting from first game in serie, because developers achieved really good resulsts with extending old ideas and developing new, so trying Master of Shadows after this will have a bit drawback feeling in it.  Also we might expect continuation of sirie witch I look forward.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[i]Variability.[/i] Firstly play style in general. You can get through level without anyone noticing you or with every one noticing but for the last time in their lifes. Then there is large variety of ways that you can chouse from to end someones patrol.
[i]Visual design.[/i] Castles, caves, ports, slums, creepy laboratory everything done in good fantasy style witch is quite easily distinguishable from any other games.
[i]Music.[/i] No accaunting for taste, but it is on decent level. Does not distract, yet few melodies are catchy.
[i]Plot.[/i] Overall doesn't have any breaking ideas but in process quite interesting and with a few dramatic twists.
[i]Humor.[/i] Styx never hesitates to give remark on what is going on in most lucid way. And as for me, idea of death screen is a huge win. (Never before I was told off by my character for perfoming badly)

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[i]Repetitive.[/i] At some point gamer will gain expirience and understanding of game laws witch can lead to using limited strategis that proved most useful. But thats more about personality. Some will find joy in doing mischief for the sake of doing it. The game provides many ways.
[i]Craft System.[/i] In Master of Shadows there was always some amout of consumable items per level so I knew I will find more. Now Styx has to craft them from materials. And if I had a place were I could use projectile I hesitated, because I could not be sure that I will craft it before I get to place where I really need one. So I was kinda thrifty even though I didn't want to be.
[i]Time Consuming.[/i] Stealth games are about knowladge. Where are guards? How they move? Is there some one behind that corner? To figure things out you need to observe. Move slovly and precosious. And some may find it tiresome. It concerns the whole genre, but it something you sould be warned about.

[h1]Recomendation:[/h1]
If you are a fan of genre, I can't name much competitors that share similarity with Styx. So definitly good representative of genre.
If you never played rogue-like games Styx probably is good enough starting point. (I doubt you will wenture to play original Thief serie, though it would be cool)
If you are generic gamer and cons that I named don't seem to bother you Styx is great for next weekend... or for a couple if you go after achievements.

... So move it rakash!

review:
*** Potential Spoilers ***

Have to give it a big thumbs down after repeatedly failing the boss fight in mission 4.  First time, killed the boss with just a sliver of health left, only to die because I didn't know that the corpses would explode if you got too near.  Second time, finished the boss with lots of health left, but a glitch caused me to go under the boss corpse, so I couldn't retrieve the quartz.  Third time, had full health and was crossing on the hanging rope when I got hit by one of the blasts which knocked me from the rope and instantly killed me (thought I was protected behind a column, but apparantly not).  All this time wasted could have been avoided if you were allowed to save your progress during the fight.

The game was wearing thin on me anyway, with all the dieing and reloading throughout every mission.  I really enjoyed deus ex and mafia III and was expecting the same here... what a disappointment :(.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054257940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1622406026}
review:
Styx (and Cynaide Studios, the developer) both seem to have experienced a huge boost in self-esteem! I am still baffled about the positive changes and addition to the already outstanding first game! I expected to play a game with more advanced graphics or something, but man, the developers took ingredients from my other beloved games (Classic Splinter Cell, Thief and Dishonred), added their own flavour and baked me an outstanding cake, named "Styx: SoD". Or just Styx 2.

====I will flat out start with things I liked, mostly in comparison to the first game:====

+ Styx himself - The first game was mostly a broken Rakash that had serious problems, and killing (or sneaking) was a pure requirement for him (story-wise). Here we have our killer goblin doing his job. Styx seemed to be pissed and confused in the first game mostly, here we have a swift and stealthy assassin that knows what he's doing.
+ Graphics: I am not a graphics freak all over, I play still Vanilla DooM (320x200x256 colours), but this game looks great. Not only is the Unreal Engine doing a good job, the developers put in high quality textures and a great mapping skills. They did not just build levels, they seem to have a vision. Not only once I stood at a vintage point and looked into the world. Nice immersion.
+ Darkness: We have no places that are pitch black. The sheath of his dagger glows the more you are in the shadows, and that subtle glow will lighten up the environment then. As for someone who waited in pitch black environemnts in Splinter Cell 3, I felt home immediately.
+ Doors, Doors, Doors!: Now the Thief feel kicks in: There are many smaller compartments in the levels: Many rooms or hoods in the tutorial. One of the things that made SC (Splinter Cell) and Thief great was the feel of "Who and what's behind the next door? Something to steal? Someone to mug?" sort of thing. And in Styx 2, we finally have it. No more huge halls or open walkways. Hearing foodsteps inside a door, peering through the keyhole while a guard is patroulling close to you - this game really has me on the edge sometimes.
+ Loot: We have a little crafting system where we can use up ore, spores and such to craft arrows and poison and such. But these ingredients are found in the levels. So we are not only breaking into rooms or mug people, we also steal from them.
+ Cutscenes: The game uses ingame-rendered cutscenes that, thanks to highly detailed models, look great. But what I liked most is the writing. It's not just conversations, all of the cutscenes so far look so passionately done. Also, the developers really stand behind the game's philosophy: Styx being a mean, foul-mouthed, shadow-loving, drug-addicted killer even in the cutscenes.
+ The enemies: ... are tougher. They can climb up boxes and jump over window sills. No more "I climb one box and run away". Also, they hurt more, depending on who's attacking me, but even on normal, going down after 2 or 3 blows of a standard enemie might happen.
+ The traps and the freedom: With the excessive freedom in the maps, I see many different ways to solve a problem. Often after the 10th attempt, I figure out it could've been done differently. 

For example: Pathfinding
There is a room I want to go into, but I am at low health and two guys are next to it. Now I can: Throw a bottle to distract them elsewhere, whistle to distract them, I can try to find a crawl space to move underneath the guards, I can use darts to simply kill them from safe distance and just walk towards it or my clone. If the door is locked and I have no picklock (they are consumables) I look trough the keyhole to see a hole in the ceiling, where the chandallier is hanging. So I climb out the window, jump my way up on to the roof, walk all over the roof to find an entrace to the attic and drop myself down into said room.

Another example: Combat
When playing on Normal, you are allowed to fight back - and I really recommend you to choose normal; why would you take away one of the funny features of the game? :-)

After being spotted, you have the same parry ritual as before, but only this time, it takes ONE sucessfull parry to make your enemy vulnerable. Apart from that, killing is not a problem for Styx: Manipulating alarm bells so they fall off and crush the guy using it, barrels of acid you can roll into the environment, jump kills, shoving someone off a cliff or a ledge. All this happens now WHILE you fight/are being seen, it feels so dynamic and hectic even (yes, that's my playstyle) I often was laughing or scraeming when I dodge roll to escape the throwing daggers that fly over my head (also when wearing headphoens!) or sword hits while I climb up ropes or pile of boxes to escape.

+ Acrobatics: Styx can now climb ropes, shinny around corners. Many things are now climbable.. In the previous game, you often slid off the environemnt, but here, our goblin can grip to almost everything. Feels a lot like assassins creed often and is great fun, especially since it also "looks and feels" great: A green skinned, small killer goblin making an escape with his acrobatic skills from 8 enemies cursing and shooting at him (of course, if I get hit, I drop and probably break my neck...^^)
+ Partial rewards: In the first (or many other game) it was: All or nothing. In Styx 2, you get partial rewards: I just found 3 posters out of 8 and in the tally screen, I still received 45 AP. That's 15 for each. 
+ Alternatives: You know what I hate? When you get GAME OVER in a game and then it just stops. But what would you do in real life? Also just stopping and everything's fine? No. In Styx 2, if you fail a mission target, you might get an alternate route. I was positively surprised. For example, in the second mission we are on an airship, and we need to change its destination. We can now forge/manipulate the documents in the office nearby the captain. If we are spotted (or we kill the captain . . .), we just take control over it ourselves.
+ Little details: When in a crawl space, we hear now Styx's breathing (trough the nose, calmly, since we are in an ego perspective). If we are in a combat or the panic level of the enemy is high, he breathes heavy and faster (the adrenaline). When you hear them go: "Nothing. Let's get back to work" and you see all the feet of your enemies moving away, Styx also goes back to normal with his breathing. It's these things that give me the game many Kudos!
+ Inventory: We now have a well-known inventory! Radial menu, and access to health and amber potions: Dishonoured and THIEF say hello!
+ Commentary: Styx talks more. "Oops" or "My bad" when shoving down a guy over an edge, "Uh-oh!..." or "Shhit!" when being spotted give our main character even more soul! Thank god! I love both his voice and his attitude. Sometimes the comments are a bit weird, but do you expect anything well-mannered from a goblin?
+ Animations: I still like the killing animations so much. I really have to laugh when he does that one animation where Styx hangs on the back of his enemy, slaps his head with his hand once before killing him, the soundeffect it does and all is hilarious. I saw it in the first game as well when killing an Elf and screamed laughing. 

====Things I think could've been different:====
~ The game is now like 30% faster. It took me 1 hour to get used to the faster movement of him.
~ The HUD (not the menus) is odd: They look like they're from a SciFi shooter or a racing game.
~ Not knowing where Styx can grab to leads to many leap of fates (and deaths)
~ Not a fan of bossfights, but also, why not?
~ Medals: You get medals for "Mercy" (no kills/just a few kills), Thief (stealing treasures), for speed (12 minutes for a level etc.) and how many alarms I triggered. Why would I want to rush? Why would I NOT kill??

====Things I disliked:=====
NOTHING. 

====Things I can not rate:=====
? Music: I turn the music off in EVERY GAME (except for DooM and DooM II)

author: {'steamid': '76561198116930297', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1528315193}
review:
If i enjoyed the former version of Styx. Yet this one, unfortunately, is ridiculously lazy.
The flaws from the previous games are still there, it still is technically below the standards of the generation, the story is still predictable and poorly written.

But in this one, Styx is actually rude, annoying, on the whole unfunny. You see, there are characters made to... ridicule the player. Telling you how much you suck. but there's a way to do it. Handsome Jack is a good example, but Glados truly is the best. Both are marvels of irony and corrosive humor.
Styx... is rude. Flipping the bird, saying duck every 2 minutes, teliing bad jokes i mean, most of the time it just falls flat. And it gets me out of the game.

It's not completly bad tho, but it's too easy, the AI sucks immense penises, the characters are dull, it's short (tbh, i'm glad it was) and worst in my opinion, there's close to no improvement over Styx Master of Shadows, which i actually recommend.
It might seem weird, but please allow me to explain.
When a 6 yo comes with a drawing that actually is impressive for his age, you'd congratulate him.
If that same kid comes, 6 years later, with the same kind of drawing, you'd tell him "eh, you should be doing a lot better by now". And that's my point. It's their 3rd game with Styx. The first one wasnt my cup of tea, but the second one was a lot different and overall better.
This one is lazy. They were so lazy they used most levels twice.....

I wont recommend it. At least not for 40€. Not even for 20. 10 or 5 at most

author: {'steamid': '76561197984361762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1528905739}
review:
This game is player vs controls and bugs in current state.

Pros:
* Graphics
* Stealth game
* Styx and characters in game
* Skill system

Cons:
* Controls
* Bugs

Those two bad things pretty much ruins game. Good controls should be priority #1 in this kind game, because it is very annoying that your characters dies even when you do things right. So sadly, can't recomment this game.

Examples of bad controls in game :
* Game highlights where you end when jumping and shows "press space to jump here" icon. You hit space, character misses that grap spot anyway, drops to floor and dies.
* Game does not notice enemy is in front of you and does not allow you to kill it. Enemy notices you after couple seconds and alerts -> character dies.
* There is no way to tell if button does what it usually does before pressing it. This usually happens while climbing ropes you click button, but instead doing what you expected it, sometimes character just decides to drop/jump other direction and die.

Examples of bugs in game :
* NPC characters get stuck to environment... Good thing is that you can dance around them and they can do nothing. Still really annoying bug that happens a lot.
* You can't take item from right next to you until you move around a bit and game notices that there is item... usually that takes couple seconds, which can be enough to NPCs to notice you and once again character dies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044074129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1196, 'last_played': 1559663926}
review:
Styx : Shards of Darkness est presque mieux que son prédecesseur.

Cependant, il a un immense défaut qui était pourtant la qualité première du premier épisode : Styx lui même. Le goblin acerbe, fourbe et grinçant séduisait autrefois par sa personnalité décalée, et c'est en parodie de lui même qu'il revient dans Shards of Darkness. Les premières blagues méta et autres réferences vous feront sourire lors de vos premiers Game Over, ils deviennent insupportables alors que vous approchez de la fin du jeu.

Car c'est tout ce que vous aurez en terme de narration et d'histoire pour ce jeu : du 4e mur qui saute, des blagues suitant l'ironie et le second degré (et qui marchent pas très souvent), et des réferences. Et c'est tout.

L'histoire est expédiée dans de courtes cinématiques entre chaque mission et n'est qu'un pretexte pour vous emmener d'un niveau à l'autre. 

Certes, ce ne sera pas la première fois que l'on nous sert un scenario-pretexte afin d'offrir un gameplay riche et efficace, mais c'est d'autant plus frustrant dans le cas de Styx : Shards of Darkness que le premier épisode servait une histoire riche en rebondissements et bien mieux integrée aux phases de jeu - tout se passait dans l'Arkenash, et les missions donnait l'impression d'une unité - et que la license s'inscrit dans un univers cohérent et plutôt riche (Of Orcs and men).

Bref, trop de Styx a tué le Styx.

Il ne reste qu'au moins, pour ce qui est du jeu en lui même, ça demeure du très très bon pour le fan d'inflitration. Shards of Darkness n'arrive pas vraiment à corriger le coté très rigide du gameplay de son ainé - qui lui avait été pourtant bien reproché! - mais est techniquement plus correct, moins brouillon, offre plus d'outils, de phases de jeu (divers objectifs secondaires et même des boss! Dans un jeu d'inflitration c'est risqué les boss ça monsieur!), des environnements variés et magnifiques, un level design plus vertical et plus ouvert... Le seul vrai problème reste l'IA des ennemis : elle est certes impardonnable et assez cohérente, mais est souvent d'une idiotie affligeante, quand il s'agit de vous rechercher après une alerte en particulier.
Cela dit, je ne connais quasiment aucun jeu d'infiltration (hors type Commando/Shadow Tactics où elle est de toute façon très simple) où l'Intelligence Artificielle ne soit pas aux fraises.

Styx : Shards of Darkness est au final un bonheur à jouer, il est exigeant mais pour toutes les raisons évoquées plus haut, bien plus frais et moins frustrant que le premier épisode... en tout cas pour le jeu en lui même. Frustrant, il l'est en revanche à cause  de son scenario abyssallement nul. Si vous n'appréciez pas le personnage de Styx, ce n'est pas cet épisode qui va le rendre plus sympathique à vos yeux, bien au contraire...

author: {'steamid': '76561198062830548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1652, 'last_played': 1527021570}
review:
An sich liebe ich das Spiel, es macht unheimlich viel Spaß im Dunkeln zu schleichen und seine Gegner auf viele Arten auszuschalten, oder die Level auf zahlreichen unterschiedlichen Wege zu absolvieren, ABER leider sind dazwischen immer wieder Boßkämpfe geschalten. Und da gibt es keine Alternative, keine unterschiedliche Strategie, lediglich einen Haufen Geduld und schnelle Reaktionszeit, ansonsten hängt man fest und kann nicht mehr weiter. 
So hänge ich noch vor der Mitte des Spiels fest - bei meinen besten Versuchen habe ich gegen die Schabenkönigin 5 von 8 erforderlichen Kristallen zerstört, aber dann erwischt mich unbarmherzig der Säureatem, die Säuregeschoße, die Tentakel oder auch nur der Sturz in die Tiefe. Schade, aber meine Geduld ist endlich, das Spiel wird deinstalliert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053257454', 'num_games_owned': 2270, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 4536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3680, 'last_played': 1504944318}
review:
One of my favourite stealth games. You play as Styx a cunning goblin which only cares for personal interest and manages to get in all kinds of trouble.

The atmosphere is great, controls are consistent and the gameplay, at least on hard, feels like you are playing a goblin(human enemies kill you without a sweat, items are adjusted to human size).
It can be really frustrating and difficult on hard but i do like a challenge, especially in stealth games. Can't really say how the game is in lower difficulties since i haven't tried them.

The co-op is an ok addition and makes the game easier especially if you communicate orally with your partner.

I give the game 8.5/10 and would definitely recommend it to stealth genre fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095588151', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 964, 'last_played': 1562345806}
review:
I could almost copy-paste my Styx: Master of Shadows-review for this but no; that would not be right. 
See, there's quite a few thing this game has improved from the last one; crafting, daggers and armors with different stats, new mechanics... But yet Cyanide Studio makes few of the same old mistakes;

Pros: 
+ Huge open environment with hidden loot
+ AI has improved from the last game, yet is still a bit clunky every now and then
+ Crafting. You dont have to go around and search for that one vial of amber, now you can collect ingredients on your 
 way. You will need to find a crafting table (usually at the very start of the zone) or you can unlock suit that allows you 
 to craft anywhere.
+ New mechanics; throwable clone-eggs, acid  mines, distraction-items, rope-climbing to name a few
+ New types of enemies in almost every new level
+ 2 boss-fights ( which are defeated with usage of stealth and smart use of your abilities)
+ Soundtrack is decent to say atleast
+ Unlockable gear; new daggers and equipment with unique stats

Cons:
- Climbing controls might be a bit frustrating
- Re-using of same maps (I still dont have anything against this, some people just see it as an issue)
- NPCs can get stuck quite often, which can be solved by using a clone
- As I mentioned earlier, AI is a bit stupid at times or might spot you when they should not, which does not happen as 
 much as in previous game


Overall solid stealth experience for those who wish for challenging, yet fun, sneaking game that can be played through in a single weekend. Oh, and I almost forgot, if you keep crying about combat being so bad, you should be ashamed for letting yourself to be spotted and getting into a situation like that. 

I give this game 8.5/10. If I missed anything, please let me know

author: {'steamid': '76561198034644583', 'num_games_owned': 3488, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1525103178}
review:
The game is a little bit clunky whith its stealth mechanics but still quite fun. 

BUT there is a game breaking bug where you have to pick up a letter from some human diplomats where picking up the letter does nothing at all. After trying to solve it by following the instructions on some forum posts I ultimatelly gave up after ~1 hour and thought to myself:

"If the developers care that much about their game that they don't fix a game breaking bug after over 1 year then why should I care."

So yeah... I would have liked to finish the game. It was quite interesting up to this point. But I do not have the time to try to fix a bug the developers know about and are aparrently not able to fix. 

The devs are welcome to tell me when the bug it fixed and I might come back and change the recommendation, but at this point I can not recommend buying or playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044824052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1524919069}
review:
Styx : Shards of Darkness est un jeu à recommander aux fans d'infiltration. 

Suite du premier opus, Master of Shadows, ce deuxième volet permet de retrouver notre rakash préféré et de se balader furtivement dans des niveaux au level design excellement travaillé et à l'identité graphique très agréable. Les mécaniques sont bien trouvées, même si certains contrôles rendent extrêmement salés (ceux qui ont déjà sauté d'une plateforme pour attraper une corde comprendront ce que je veux dire). 

L'ajout des compétences est agréable, et permet de compléter le jeu sans le dénaturer puisqu'il est modulable à souhait. L'ajout également des différents items et tenues donne un aspect personnalisation sympathique au jeu. 

Cependant, deux points négatifs viennent ternir ce petit bijou d'infiltration :

- Les combats de boss : pourquoi ? Juste pourquoi ? On se retrouve à faire du plateforming un peu neuneu et à passer  à  minutes pour finir un boss qui n'est pas difficile, mais simplement long. Quand on joue à Dark Souls à côté (ou n'importe quel jeu de boss fighting), on se rend bien compte que leur propos n'est pas d'être un jeu d'infiltration. Styx n'est pas un jeu de combat, donc il faut laisser à César ce qui est à César et se concentrer sur les phases d'infiltration. Ou alors mettre un boss qui peu one-shot mais que l'on doit contourner PAR l'infiltration et non pas combattre.

- Le scénario est... basique. Il n'est pas révolutionnaire mais tiens bien la baraque même s'il est un peu rapide et caricatural parfois. Seul le personnage de Styx est vraiment bien travaillé, et c'est tant mieux ! 
En revanche, les petits ajouts de scénario dans les niveaux qui font changer la route prise pour découvrir de nouvelles zones ou trésors sont toujours très intéressantes et on se plaît à écouter les conversations de nos adversaires avant de les occir (ou non).

En bref, un excellent jeu, pas trop difficile, qui demande patience et concentration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054869552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 4715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4715, 'last_played': 1522521433}
review:
More Styx, much more Styx

There are no major changes, compared to its predecessor. The game is still a goblin simulator.
Acid Traps are a nice addition to your arsenal, being able to choose between different daggers and clothing is a nice idea, and your clones learned a few new tricks. But the basics did not change, same playstile, same enemies (mostly), same game. That's not a bad thing, since I loved the first game, just to make this clear.

But there are two nice changes:
1. Styx startet breaking the 4th wall. A lot, especially if you die. And it's hilarious.
2. CoOp was introduced. And despite some people expieriencing difficulties, it worked fine for me playing via LAN.

So overall: If you liked the first game, you will probably love this one as well,

author: {'steamid': '76561197983412898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1004, 'last_played': 1522652991}
review:
I bought this game because I really enjoyed Styx: Master of Shadows and was looking for more.  In terms of general gameplay it is exactly that.  You sneak around, do optional objectives, enjoy Styx's wit, and do generally shady things.  The game falls short in two major areas, the plot and the bosses.

The plot makes it clear that this game was made purely as a followon for Master of Shadows.  It isn't anywhere near as inspired and doesn't really have anything interesting to say.  It is mildly better set up than the plot of Doom, but while character depth and motivation are hinted at existing, very little greater effort is spent exploring those depths.

The bosses are annoying.  They're epic, but this is a game where fighting any given random enemy one on one is a bad idea.  The bosses always know where you are.  Unless you use invisibility, you can't hide from them and for a stealth game that is more than a bit silly.  They end up coming off as just parkour challenges that put no stress on your abilities at stealth.  And they're poorly implemented.  The second (and last) one starts with the boss launching massive AoE one-hit kills at you.  They're not terribly difficult to avoid, but the mission starts immediately with these so if you are hit, you have to reload the level (because you can't save in that level before the boss) and skip the cutscene and then get back to the boss fight again.  They're poorly designed and mediocrely implemented.

Overall the game is worth playing if and only if you really enjoyed Styx: Master of Shadows.  On its own merits, it falls flat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960282791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 2080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2080, 'last_played': 1522719893}
review: A solid, enjoyable stealth game with a serious case of potty mouth and a very surly protagonist, Styx was long, had lots of content (even though there was a lot of level re-use) and was generally a very good third person stealth title with more in common with Splinter Cell than, say, Thief or Dishonored. It has two very annoying boss fights, but if I can get by them so can anyone, and otherwise it's a pleasure to play.

review:
It's a stealth game with instant quick save (less than half a second) and very fast quick load (2-5 seconds). That makes it an instant purchase for me.

The levels are big, with many paths to the objectives, and have tons of verticality. In the second half of the game some of the levels are reused but there is so much to discover in all of them that I didn't really care. (I'ts definitely better than having unique levels that are smaller / more linear.)

Animations are a bit janky (just visually, it controls well), and the voiceacting is pretty horrible but I'm having lots of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216614627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1204, 'last_played': 1522337537}
review: Zachęcony pozytywnym opiniami o gierce, sam postanowiłem sprawdzić. Napiszę tak - ujdzie ale jest parę elementów do poprawy. Przede wszystkim design lub pisząc po polsku, zaprojektowanie leveli. Fajnie, że gra ma dużą liczbę opcji wejścia do pomieszczeń i stawia na dużą swobodę. Jest jednak pewne ale, mianowicie cały czas podczas gry miałem wrażenie, że levele są bradzo do siebie podobne. Pierwszy rozdział na statku jest tego idealnym przykładem. Dalej jest znacznie lepiej i uczucie deja vu nie występuje, tylko bardzo brakuje mi w grze tego typu zapadających w pamięci etapów. Arkane studio robi to znakomicie, bo plansze w Dishonored i ostatnim Preyu łatwo przyswoić przez ciekawe zaprojektowanie. A kiedy etapy są interesujące, to chce sie zaglądać w każdy kąt. Tutaj mi tego brakuje i to jest największy minus tej gry. Jakby robili Styxa 3 to chciałbym, żeby właśnie wzięli przykład z gier Arkane lub starych Thiefów i poszli na całość z wyobraźnią. Przydałby sie jeszcze bardziej urozmaicony soundtrack. Cały reszta gry, jak najbardziej spoko i widać perspektywę na naprawdę dobre gry skradankowe od tego studia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980521434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 3772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3771, 'last_played': 1557501001}
review:
Having played the 1st one through and enjoyed it I can't say much bad about this game because it's exactly the same in most respects. Some of the reviews I read before buying it said it breaks immersion when he quips off some line from a movie when he dies like "I'll be back", but honestly those people are taking things way to seriously in my opinion.

Combat is the same as the original and so is the climbing. It's a stealth game with a basic combat system and the option to save at any time. That said you can perfect the level quite easily because you can ground hog day all day long.

Since I loved the first one I can say this is a successful sequel. Loved it and played it non stop until it was done yet again.

Plenty worth the steam sale price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115356520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1521469099}
review:
Styx,ты меня удивил в очередной раз....Редко пишу обзоры,но прошёл игру на одном дыхании с начала до конца.поэтому и всуну тут свои 3 копеи.
Стикс стал намного смешнее,интереснее и красивее(чего стоят заставки когда Стикс погибает!).Среди прочего шлака,он выделился блеском янтарая и прочими красотами локаций.
Но в тоже время есть чувство не законечнности чтоли в этой игре,нет нормального развития персонажа и многие навыки совершенно не нужны и развиваются к концу игры-а зачем мне эти навыки,если игра закончена?
Игра лёгкая,стелс не сложный,есть пару моментов сложных,но если внимательным быть,то быстро понимаешь в чём дело.
Крайне удивила концовка-это намёк на продолжение?
Руда,где блин руда?! Использовать и изготовлять разные предметы очень сложно изза отсуствия руды,котрая слишком редко попадается!
Разрабы,в следущей части(очень надеюсь на это)сделайте получше сюжет и наделите хоть каким то ИИ персонажей,сделайте прокачку скилс эфективнее и разнообразнее,чтобы можно ими было пользоватся а не к концу игры как в этой части!
Игра сделана для отдыха и эстетического удовольствия ,на пару дней,не больше.
Рекомендую однозначно!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971413608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1521400710}
review:
Инди игра продаваемая по цене трипл А. Гаджетов интересных мало, паркур ужасный (пропасти станут вашими друзьями), анимация деревянная. Кооп лагучий, с проваливанием в текстуры. Плюс в коопе ресурсов мало, поэтому многих врагов просто не убить. Каждый уровень надо пройти 2 раза, но с разными условиями (привет Devil May Cry 4). Главный герой правда удался, его шутки разбавляют игру. Если бы за нее не просили 2000 рублей, а в два раза меньше, можно было бы закрыть на что-то глаза. Из-за кризиса жанра можно поиграть, но не более. Обзор скорее нейтральный, но Стим не дает мне такой поставить, так что пусть будет минус.
[b]Оценка: 6.5/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197973860656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1738, 'last_played': 1521307262}
review: I love Styx, The voice actor, the music, the look and feel, all top notch. Yet I can not recomend this one and it breaks my heart to say so. I sat on the idea of writing a review after completing the game to see if my mood on it changed, but it did not. The issue for me is the story line. Which for me is a huge part, if it is not for you then great, get the game. All to often in this game I felt like "Your're kidding, wtf would he do that? this is BS!". With so many ham fisted plots that do not make sense, and no closure on many things except for one created from the first game and wedged in there, for no real apparent reason why. Even the ending. Completely drops you, and to be honest that was the worst part. The feeling of "WTF, why are the credits rolling?!? This is NOT the end! Oh FU" THat feeling has lingered and made me very sad considering how fond of this game I was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006525043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 915, 'last_played': 1521353835}
review:
I've been on board since "Of Orcs and Men." I truely love Styx and flipped my shit when I found out there was another one. That said the game itself felt lacking. Levels felt lazy, over populated, and wound up being more about luck than actual strategy. I don't understand "Mercy," it's the opposite of the character and you're punished for not doing it. Some levels were just poorly designed and didn't make much sense like, why are you doing day light levels in the begining when you're new and night missions at the end when you can basically just run around?

Sadly, one of the worst things was the story writting. One of the things I've stuck with this series forever with. Characters abruptly arrive and dissappear with no explanation, most missions are forced. There's times where Styx breaks into a solid reason why somethings bad only to agree with it. It just felt hokey and forced, the whitty Styx was replaced with Duke Nukem with an inferiority complex with Assassins Creed. It's cool to break the fourth wall and poke fun at other games, but when you're game is lacking as much as this one is it's just poor taste.

I do recommend the game, but grab it on sale. It wasn't finished, felt rushed and the ending is abrupt and will make everything you've been doing feel pointless. My advice, ignore the game the devs built and just run around like Styx would, mess with people, start chaos and have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960478145', 'num_games_owned': 2351, 'num_reviews': 616, 'playtime_forever': 2130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1638208998}
review: I could go on rambling forever about how pushing guards off ledges or use my powers to sneak by never gets old. But I'd like to cut to what sets this apart from most other stealth games: The level design of neigh-infinite possibilities. There are always countless paths, including vertical ones. The general verticality in this game is astonishing and the only way not to find an alernative path is not to look for one. Another huge aspect of the level design are traps. Instead of pushing guards off ledges or stabbing them, you can also poison water skins hanging around, sabotage an alert bell and put a dead guard right next to it or drop said bell onto someone's head. In fact, I spend more time with environment kills than I do with anything else. Hell yeah!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995421497', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1521165755}
review:
[b][u]5 Things You Should Know about [i]Styx: Shards of Darkness[/i][/u][/b]

[b]What Is It?[/b]
The return of everyone's favourite foul-mouthed amber-junkie goblin!  The first Styx game (Master of Shadows) established this franchise as serious stealth for people who like stealth games, and Shards of Darkness continues in the same vein.  Gameplay is largely the same as the first game, with some refinements to the process and the UI.

[b]What's The Best Part?[/b]
Still the stealth, for my money.  As mentioned, the gameplay is largely the same as the first game, and the first game was pretty tight all things considered.  Stealth games are easily one of my favourite genres, and Styx is rapidly climbing to the top of my list for stealth games.  The graphics are also updated (as one would expect,) and the game looks and runs beautifully on my [i]absolutely-not-top-of-the-line[/i] PC with highest settings across the board.  So, well optimized, I'm thinking.

There's a new crafting mechanic which is pretty interesting.  Leaving crafting materials all over the place also introduces new reasons to make a break across a well-lit room, thereby increasing the stealthy aspects of the game.

[b]What's The Worst Part?[/b]
Combat is marginally better than it was in the first game, but it still sucks.  There's a difficulty level (3rd out of 4, I think) called "Goblin," whose only difference from the rank below is "combat literally becomes instant death" and when I read that I shrugged and said to myself: "combat in this game is instant death anyway, near enough."  As I mentioned in my review for Master of Shadows, though, I don't necessarily hold bad combat against stealth games, since I spend most of my time avoiding combat anyway.

What [i]did[/i] sort of annoy me, though, was all the cheesy out-of-universe pop culture references Styx kept making throughout this installment.  He broke the fourth wall at least 3 times, by my count, and each one made me cringe.  I remember Styx being a foul-mouth last time, but I don't recall him being so [i]tryhard[/i] about the jokes.  Some badass assassins crack wise while they kill people, but Styx is better when he just focuses on the killing part.

[b]Will I Like It?[/b]
+ Nice step up in graphics over Master of Shadows (without needing a top-of-the-line PC)
+ Heavy emphasis on sneaking as opposed to fighting
+ Continuation of an interesting franchise/setting

- Trying too hard to be funny at times (esp. fourth wall-breaking stuff)
- Cheesy quips from Styx when you die (can be turned off in settings)

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
If you liked the first game, you will like this one as well.  Full stop.
If you like stealth games where you have to be [i]really careful[/i] about staying hidden, you'll love this game (and the first one, too.)

This has been a 5TYSK review. (#0036)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970600723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1520972192}
review:
[h1]A sequel that improved more than it made worse.[/h1]

▲The few control flaws of the first game have been fixed. There is even less annoying ambiguity.
▲New well-implemented mechanics such as rope-hanging, ziplining and rope-swinging.
▲Added co-op. Didn't try it because I don't know anyone who plays stealth games, but it's a good thing.
▲Levels are more open, letting players take more paths to the objective.
▲Success rating is no longer based on rigid binary achievements. You get half the "thief" points if you manage to steal half, instead of getting nothing for not stealing absolutely everything.
▲More variety in mission objectives. Trailing a target, framing targets with incriminating evidence, forging documents, and even following footprints.
▲A joke that references [i]Thief: The Dark Project.[/i] Another joke that mocks [i]Assassin's Creed.[/i] That's always good.
▲Finally a game where the recommended brightness setting actually makes dark areas pitch black like they should be. -And very dark areas realistically hide you very well. Enemies can pass right by because there's no light that could reveal you.
▲Music that dynamically and seamlessly changes to different versions of a song based on whether you're sneaking indoors or outdoors, or if you are being hunted, or if you're in combat.

►The story of the first game made it so that you don't need to know anything about it to understand this one.
►Some bad translations. Whatever. Reminds me of E.Ψ.Ǝ Divine Cybermancy. It's endearing, not annoying.
►The game is easier than the first one. Probably because of the better level design and fixed mechanics. But also because of the flaws of the crafting system. See below.
►Levels are more colorful and prettier to look at. Akenash was very monochrome in comparison.
►Animations and cinematic direction are noticeably better than the first game.
►NPCs don't repeat the same lines so much anymore.

▼[b]Boss fights in a stealth game.[/b] Even worse, ones where the boss is constantly hyper-aware of you even though they can't possibly know where you are hiding.
▼Still the same issue of reusing the same level twice in the story.
▼Still the same issue of relying on objective markers because the necessary information to accomplish your mission is not conveyed in any other way.
▼Sound propagation wasn't improved from the first game. It's sometimes hard to figure out where an enemy is patrolling because the footstep sounds travel from downstairs through solid rock.
▼Flying monsters with incredible perception. At least shooting them out of the sky doesn't lower your non-lethality rating.
▼Crafting system that diminishes some of the resource conservation of the first game. Ran out of amber? Craft some more using the ingredients in your pockets.
▼The ultimate abilities you can unlock using quartz are mostly garbage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138700608', 'num_games_owned': 1423, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 3744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2620, 'last_played': 1591557871}
review:
Brief: Score: 9.2/10. An amazing stealth game with awesome abilities that allow for some great ninja work.
In my not so humble opinion. 2016 was the best year for stealth games (Dishonored and Hitman). And 2017 would have been a let down in the genre, even with the release of death of the Outsider, if not for Styx: Shards of Darkness. It is shockingly good. It’s almost pure stealth. However, Styx has enough tricks in his bag so that you never feel like the stealth work is a chore. That’s saying something. 

The game has two big bosses. The best part of the bosses are that they are pure stealth challenges. It doesn’t turn into a Dark Souls fight or Doom arena. Instead, you apply multiple stealth skills to defeat the enemy. I enjoyed the fights a great deal. 

One thing that I’m not a huge fan of is Styx after you die. He breaks the 4th wall every single time. Now, listen if you never die that won’t be a problem. Hell, if you die just a little bit it won’t be a problem. He has a few really good jokes. If you die even a moderate number of times, you will get sick of his trolling ways. 

I recommend this game wholeheartedly!

review:
Styx je super stealth hra. Není to AAA titul, takže ji ve slevě můžete koupit za pár babek. Grafika má kouzelnou atmosféru fantasy steampunku. Hlavního hrdinu - goblina Styxe, budete buď milovat nebo nenávidět. Je to antihrdina, který si uvědomuje, že je jen vámi ovládaná fiktivní postava, a velmi často to dává najevo svými vtípky, které sem tam pobaví, ale také dokážou být dost CRINGE. Jestli tuto hru nechcete nenávidět, doporučuji po velmi krátké době VYPNOUT posmrtné cutscény, které vás sice ze začátku pobaví, ale po chvíli vám začnou lézt krkem.

Hru jsem dohrál na těžkou obtížnost, ve které je už opravdu zapotřebí sledovat a využívat prostředí a pohyby nepřátel. V této obtížnosti se už nemůžete bránit nepřátelským útokům a nepřátelé vás okamžitě zabijí, což klade důraz na samotný STEALTH, který by měl u stealth her být prioritou. ZABÍJET DOKÁŽE KAŽDÝ, ale hra vás odměňuje za to, že level projdete co nejrychleji, bez alarmů, bez zabíjení nepovinných cílů, a za plnění vedlejších úkolů. Většina misí se skládá z vícera lokací, takže když si myslíte, že jste už nakonci, nejste nejspíš ještě ani v polovině.

Dohrání hry mi jako průměrnému hráči trvalo cca 15 hodin, takže nevím jestli se vám vyplatí plná cena, ale ve slevě se dá hra koupit za cca 15 euro. A to se VYPLATÍ!!!
