author: {'steamid': '76561197987840757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 1069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1503142406}
review:
While the game is a solid AA title, I still felt the 40 eur price tag is still a little too much, especially after finishing the game. I got it on sale so it was fine for me but 40 eurs... I wouldn't pay that much for this.

Make no mistake, the game is good. Very good. Has it's fair share of problems but the biggest issue is that it lacks content. You can pretty much breeze through the campaign even on highest difficulty, except some parts (boss fights) that on the other hand are pretty messed up. For me, the campaign ended with a feeling somewhat similar to Deus Ex MD. Not that obvious of a cutout but more like a "meh, they ran out of ideas?" one but still, felt shallow.

Detailed version

Visuals
Graphically it looks better than the first title as expected and while certainly not a AAA visual treat, it does the job and puts relatively little strain on your rig. 
The world itself is pretty neat, as a medieval sort of setting the tightly packed towns and the underground facilities all look plausible at first glance. The positioning of guards and their paths on the other hand scream "game". Like when you find guards in underground facilities that have no other doors and as such no other entrances than the near-death climb you just did, or when guards are placed in a small storage room, staring at the wall all day long. Other than that, the world is pretty, nothing jawdropping and while the climb-spots are also annoyingly "well-placed" (drawing a line to your objective) it's okay. The whole thing looks okay I guess.

I would say they didn't have enough time for more believable maps to be created or something but sadly the game lacks maps. While the some maps are fine in size, there are like 4 of them? 2 human town and 2 elven town. Okay, there are some smaller maps but those are nothing like the big ones and you have to revisit the big maps, I guess as a way to boost gameplay time. Since the story takes place with the same characters so it's sort of logical you don't travel the world but instead operate around where they live/operate but still... 

While viusals overall look okay even if not really varied, the lack of HDR was very annoying. While I welcomed the dark areas which many - sadly even stealth - games lack, the idea of the character's eyes not getting used to the darkness made them a chore to navigate through. Basically if there is darkness there, if you go in, you will be blind. In this day and age this is sort of a must, especially in a game with darkness tightly linked with it's core gameplay.

Story
The story is... okay. Feels rushed and shallow, Styx becoming pals with bitter enemies, trusting them even after like exchanging 3 words... And what's best [spoiler] they really don't outright betray him. I was constantly expecting them betraying me/him so it was sort of a twist that there was no twist? It does the job so I guess I shouldn't be picky but the truth is it ended pretty abruptly. Even the cliffhanger at the end is so shallow I'm not sure if it's even a cliffhanger.[/spoiler]

Gameplay
Controls are okay. They are usually responsive and most of the time you know what will happen as a result of your input. Most of the time. The game has some problems with edge detection but nothing others don't. The bigger problems come from spotting. Enemies sometimes spot you from miles away, from a baclony, or even in dark areas like the undercity of the elves while sometimes they can't see you even just because you are like half a meter above ground level or because you are under a table, even if you are staring at each other. It's weird and it's more of a design choice than a bug or glitch but breaks immersion pretty fast.
Similarly, using distraction items, like glass became forgettable very fast as for crashing glass apparently has less impact than you running - seriously, if you run, that sound is noticed from further away (without the noisy outfit, yes). 

The character is upgradable and most likely you won't get every skill on first try but I didn't feel any incentive to go back and do every mission perfectly or find everything as skills don't feel that good. I mean they are borderline essential for some things but anything non-passive can be pretty forgettable as you don't really have an abundance of mana/amber.
[spoiler][rant]You even have invisibility skills which turns all goblins (you and your clones) invisible as long they stay within 2 meters of you. That distance is nothing, not to mention invisibility runs out in 5 seconds or so. What's the point? Or the one that turns the body you carry invisible as well. Lovely. Except you won't really go far in that 5 seconds invisibility so unless the guards breeze by you sprinting you are dead or would have been fine anyways. [/rant][/spoiler]

Honestly, the best abilities you get are for killing. But then the game has the Mercy challenge built in, giving you a VERY low xp bonus at the end if you do not kill anyone. And I mean really LOW. No real incentive other than self satisfaction.

AI is the usual, sort of dumb, but sometimes sort of runs right at you from miles away even without sight (finding you in whatever spot you hid even if he should have no idea you are even in the building) - with the numbers they are present on the maps, it can be challenging. Again, we did a non-lethal playthrough, getting Mercy gold for most maps (except first I think) so it was way more challenging than killing everyone.

And yes, We. The game has Co-op.

The second player enters the game as a "perfect clone", costs no amber but it takes half your current life. So you can keep summoning him even if you have borderline zero health, no problem. We did play without using health potions so 1-hit and you are dead. 
You would think that coop should have made things easier - but unless I wanted to sacrifice myself or kill people, I could barely cause any distraction to help my partner. You would think twice the players, twice the amber but it was still not enough to do anything truly useful for the whole team. We mostly used invisibility when we got bored of a room full of guards and that was it. Of course if you don't mind dying a lot you can use yourself as a clone and respawn at your partner's location (for half his health). There were numerous times when one of us was staying behind in a safe location to act as a save/respawn point basically.
Oh yea, be careful. You don't really want to load saves in coop. The client only saves progress at certain locations and they messed something up so during a load I lost most of my stuff I got from previous map. As in it recognized that I spend hundreds of xp on multiple skills but not what skills so I lost my points but lost the skills I paid for. 
Other than that, there are issues with weird animations in some cases, usually when you jump from a hanging/climbing spot to another. We did see guards getting stuck too that caused problems (given they were stuck in the only path you could go).

Overall
The whole game feels "okay". Sort of like they had some ideas but never really polished them. They gave you some obvious paths, a ton of guards and some abilities but then rendered those abilities borderline useless or rarely usable at all (distraction items, clones, invisibility). It feels like the maps and guards are set up as if they planned to make those abilities and distraction items etc. way more useful and effective. It feels as if there was a very important meeting where they decided how things will go and they forgot to invite half the dev team. 

Maybe they planned to do more. It certainly feels like they stopped halfway. [spoiler]You can even get a nice cloak that eliminates mana/amber drain from invisibility as long as you stand still. On the last actual map, basically before the bossfight where you have no use for it. You cannot change equipment before the map ends, yep.[/spoiler]

It's an okay game, but a tad overpriced IMHO so buy it when on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101064513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1503039398}
review:
I expected much from this game. I did like the first one even though it had a ton of issues, I expected most of them to be fixed with this sequel. I was very very wrong. NO SPOILERS.

This game keeps most of the issues from the first game, the AI has been slightly improved but it's the same robotic monotonous and artificial feeling as in Styx 1, which is a very big deal becuase there's another HUGE problem with this game, the level design. A big improvement from the previous game is that there's a lot more visual variety this time around, from giant zeppelins, to fishing villages and elf ruins, a lot LOT more variety that keeps the exploration interesting. The levels are huge too and really feel like real places, I've been extremely impressed by it, each level just feels so good to look at in the beginning: "Look how beautiful and packed this place I'm about to explore is" I thought at the start of every level. However, a couple levels repeat in the latter chapters, as if they wanted to finish the game at once.

And the levels themselves, are all the same, more or less corridor but mostly very open labyrinthic levels that feel like real places, as I said. But there always are the same holes with the same hooks to hold on, the same rooms with the same wardrove, the same box, the same food to poison, so even though there's a big visual variety throughout the levels, they ALL play EXACTLY the same, which is a real shame, because that playstyle is not too interesting, the way to beat a challenge is always the same, whether that's with the hooks on the wall, a tunnel beneath the floor or entering the building from a window on the ceiling, over and over, which gets very tiresome after the first couple chapters.

Another thing to point out is that the skills are absolutely pointless for the reasons stated above, you can beat everything in the game SO easily without using ANY skills at all, that it's just ridiculous, most of the time you won't even use barrels and stuff to throw over someone or to distract, even that is not even necessary, so when you realize this, the only reward you get from exploring the levels is your own satisfaction and some pretty views.

The enemy variety is the same as in Styx 1, but with one new enemy that starts to detect you if your distance to him is lower than X, even through walls, because they can "smell" you, so it works exactly like a radar. Except that enemy, everything else is the same.

Your tasks each mission have been improved and made more interesting, but beneath the surface, it's always "Go to A, now go to B", and the game plays exactly the same on your way to both A and B.

The story is interesting, it does have a very VERY interesting and foreshadowed plottwist which I think was absolutely genius and I really really liked it. However, it has the least satisfactory ending I have seen in a long time, you can really see how the developers just wanted to be done with the game. The ending doesn't even have an explanation, it sets up for a future expansion or game, but it's not like you can already understand the ending, it has no explanation, the developers will come up with an explanation when they release their next adventure with Styx. So overall, it has a better tempo than the first Styx since it gives some new interesting plot detail every mission, but the first Styx story was much better and cohesive as a whole, with an absolutely brilliant plottwist, definitely one of my favorite plottwists ever.

So this game is NOT a good game, it's a decent game, but it's not bad by any ANY means, it can be very enjoyable in fact, and while I would've given a positive review to the first game, which was objectively worse in nearly every way, and that game could not even be enjoyable at all, I can't give a positive review to this one. It feels like the developers didn't want to fix all the issues their first game had, or at least the most important ones that would make Styx a GREAT stealth game, but no. I will gladly buy the next Styx though, I've got faith on them after all.

TLDR: Fine game, not many improvements from the previous one, lazy developers. All the abilities are absolutely useless thanks to the terrible (but very beautiful) level design, thus making all exploration pointless. Buy it at half the price, neither the game nor the developers deserve the full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039358493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2356, 'last_played': 1686767424}
review: Styx: Shards of Darkness на первый взгляд мало чем отличается от Styx: Master of Shadows, но главное, как это обычно бывает, кроется в мелочах. Подача сюжета стала заметно лучше. Характер самого Стикса изменился, он стал более дерзким. Добавили "пробивание четвертой стены", чего в первой части не наблюдалось. Очень сильно изменилось дерево навыков, в котором самой полезной, пожалуй, является ветка "восприятие". Самой же бесполезной считаю ветку "клонировние", особенно возможность перерождения на месте клона. Кроме того убрали возможность "минировать" клонами сундуки и шкафы, которой я в первой части пользовался довольно часто. Еще завезли парочку боссов, но они, в отличии от финала Master of Shadows, не кажутся чужеродными. Что касается сложности игры, то ощущениям первая и вторая часть в этом плане на одном уровне. В обоих частях мы по несколько раз за игру посещали одни и те же локации, но я не считаю это недостатком. Дизайн уровней в Shards of Darkness так же шикарен, как и в Master of Shadows. Многоуровневые локации с множеством путей достигнуть одной точки, то что нужно для игры в жанре Стелс. Поэтому вернуться в знакомую локацию с новым заданием всегда приятно. В итоге имеем игру в которой упор сделан именно на скрытное прохождение. Любителям жанра однозначно нужно брать. Если вам понравилась Master of Shadows, однозначно понравится и Shards of Darkness. Если сомневаетесь в покупке из-за высокой цены, у Shards of Darkness в Steam имеется демоверсия, которая даст возможность оценить основную механику игры.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006544250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1502842455}
review:
I was a fan of Styx: Master of Shadows and Styx:Shards of Darkness was an improvement upon the original in terms of gameplay but lacking in terms of its story.

The game is a great as a stealth game, with players able to go through an entire level without eliminating any one whilst also given the option to be a green midget reaper slicing the life out of several fantasy races. The gameplay was great, the dialogue was humourous and Styx's powers outstanding, able to manipulate any situation to your advantage. There were however, downsides.

Random boss battles that throw stealth out of the window, the random glitches that happen when you load a game forcing you to restart zones sometimes and sadly, which I would say was the worst part, the story was not as grand as the prequel.

Styx: Master of Shadows was a decent game but had a story so phenomenal that it alone was the reason I bought this game. Sadly Shards of Darkness does not possess the same twist and turns and ongoing storylines, it feels more like fragmented pieces that suddenly disappears and becomes meaningless much like some of the characters but it does have some highlight moments here and there.

Styx Shards of Darkness is a great stealth game with a disappointing plotline in comparison to its prequel.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198184395153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1345, 'last_played': 1503577505}
review:
日本語化ありがとうございます。
楽しくプレイしています。
サイドクエストもあるし、ノーキルプレイ、逆に全滅プレイなどでリプレイ性も高いですね。
ストーリーも徐々に判明していくのでゲームを進めていくのが楽しいです。

良い所
・とにかく楽しい。死んでも楽しい。何回もリトライしちゃいます。
・グラフィックも綺麗です。
・難易度設定によるサポートの有無が嬉しいです。
・人によると思いますが結構簡単です。謎解きもステルスも何度は低めのゲームだと思います。
・ゲームデザインの旨さというのでしょうか？前半のマップの再利用があります。道順としては逆をたどる形になっていたりします。また状況の変化により同じマップでも敵キャラの警戒度が上がっているために難易度が上がっていたりします。しかし抜け道などがある程度わかっているので程よい難易度に感じます。

悪い所
・これは本当になんとかしてほしいのですが、起動が異様に遅いです。また１回目のロードが遅いです。非常に残念ですね。
・あえてあげるとすればロープアクションが難しいですね。

author: {'steamid': '76561198048003180', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1561943560}
review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness is a game with an annoying reference spouting, 4th wall breaking, drug(amber) abusing goblin trying to get his fix. Strangely I kind of like Styx despite these traits, he's callous, rude, and at times can be funny. The game is lacking heavily in story and has pacing issues that make many of its action scenes comical. The game's ending is an anticlimactic cliff hanagar that anyone could have seen coming, and raises more questions on the point of the entire end sequence than anything else.

The gameplay of Styx: SD is good and bad. Stealth play feels great and guards aren't nearly as blind as they are in most games. You have a good amount of abilities at your disposal which support stealth and combat players well. Combat is fairly simple with attacks, counter attacks, and a short dodge roll. I did not use this much as I went for a pacifist playthrough, but did try a little initially and found everything except the dodge to work fine. Boss fights are really lame puzzle solving missions with platforming that has instant death drops from generic laser beams. Platforming is a coin flip on wether or not you will reach your target, or get launched sideways and makes the game annoying at times. The levels are designed relatively well, but they have platforming violent crammed into them by adding these strange wall sconce/hooks everywhere for styx to climb on and it really does break immersion in a way that screams "VIDEO GAMES!"

Story is far from this game's strong suit, to the point of me making this game's review negative suprisingly. Characters just seem to disappear and are never seen from or heard from again. Character interactions are meaningless as everyone just kind of does thier own thing and leaves after your done needing thier help. Spoiler time :D [spoiler]Helledryn gets captured, you save Helledryn, you never see her again. The head of the elves just leaves after her plot fails. Djarak tries to just leave twice and Styx's smuggler friend boaty mc boat face guy just disappears.[/spoiler] The final boss fight is so damn insulting and akward, it feels worse than original bossfights in Deus Ex: Human Revolution. You basicly have to hide from a golem that instant kills you as the game uses unclear hiiding spots, and badly wants you to use powers. [spoiler]The game also just ends after this fight with Styx pointing his crossbow at Djarak in an awful cliff hangar.[/spoiler]

I enjoyed the game but it began to get repitious fast, there's no pay off at the end, and it game is short if you don't suck like I do . _.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009785842', 'num_games_owned': 1275, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 6696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5969, 'last_played': 1502627958}
review:
It's a good sequel to a good game, play Styx: Master of Shadows first if you haven't, it is a far better way to get into these games than jumping into part 2 of a story. Comparing the 2 is like comparing 2 fresh apples, just fucking eat them.

This is not assasins creed, nor is it fucking infamous or prototype. You are a goblin, not the horse from skyrim, you can't run directly up a cliff face.

Not much else to say other than the coop being a waste of resources better put into... anything else. Please stop tacking coop onto singleplayer games, its a bad habit the industry has gotten itself into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126497441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 2747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2747, 'last_played': 1503254851}
review:
萌贱哥布林喜欢说下流脏话还有各种吐槽！
当然包括某个 [spoiler]绿帽情杀[/spoiler]故事
都深深吸引住了我。


先说本文重点

硬！核！暗！杀！


难度设定
面面兼顾的难度设定，有人会说这个游戏的主角太脆了，我不觉得。
你们想想例如大家都玩过的耻辱1，（2代有防御飞射物的格挡技能就不谈了）最高难度你被打上一枪或者砍上一刀，运气好（0成长满血情况）打成血皮，但是大部分时间都是一枪就被打爆的。
同时由于替身技能的存在，所以大部分的时间，其实更依赖rakash探路，rakash替死。一切冒险行为最好rakash先试试。跳远距离摸不透？rakash跳！怕拉阳台推悬崖杀人声音？rakash推！还没走过的路，而且视野不好难以规划，rakash来开路！而且rakash在敌人眼前死亡还能消除威胁状态，好用得很。

多周目不可以穿难度，这个设定很好。大师难度就是强行要你改掉哥布林难度的一切坏习惯，而且不给你哥布林通关的神装，重新思考用一个新的角度去玩这个游戏。你需要考察好路线，花时间观摩敌人路径。想办法迂回进入，再次提醒玩家，潜行游戏不可以鲁莽，起码最高难度不允许。轻度玩家能确实通过大师难度变成了一个重度玩家，同时也不会太苛求你----因为一般来说选大师难度的玩家都可以在序章结束以后点出克隆重生的技能，某种程度来说这技能也算是存档技了。
现在拥有高难度的游戏不多了，大家留神可以发现，现在的游戏越来越简单，styx一直以来坚持的难度追求是弥足珍贵的。

敌人分布
这一点，就谈分布的话。个人觉得还需要多用心，敌人虽然算比较多，但是也有很多容易孤立然后逐个击破的状况。（所以融化酸液的意义实在不大，哪怕重甲不可搬运。大部分时候一个大关都用不到一瓶。）

小地图
对，没有小地图！没有！ 别想！更别说小范围敌人的确切位置标识！连一代那张抽象得要死的大地图都不给你！！但是有句公道话我要说，起码这一代的盗贼金币位置，地方比起一代算是很好找了。（其实就是降低了一些不必要的难度）


正因为styx的招牌就在于硬核潜行，它的太多太多优点需要玩家去发现。特别是关卡难度的协调性，我相信是下了功夫的。（当然，它还能做得更好）


公用槽点
高难度里超级反哥布林的投技击杀以及低难度困难的格挡反杀（简陋到爆的战斗系统）。很多人会揪着这点来吐槽，但是........这真的不算啥问题，诸位如果游戏经历足够长的话，这些独一无二的反人类的地方，偏偏就是这个游戏最大的特色，市面上许许多多游戏会因为被玩家投诉太多这种那种“反人类”的设定，而“平衡”掉难度的游戏，基本都变味了。
而且这游戏被发现，处于战斗状态的情况之下，避免被秒的手段也是有的。（大哥啊，你的弩箭打轻甲不论对方移动还是你在乱动，你一按下Q就是一击爆头，人家巡逻路径你偷窥得清清楚楚，哪怕你闹得天翻地覆都好，等个几分钟他们都忘了你来过了。你就是主角来的啊！你是去屠杀他们的啊！给他们点作为“敌人”的尊严吧）

对于很多人诟病的回头路地图重复利用，我觉得已经成了styx的游戏血统，如同分身克隆一样，招牌特性以后我估计也不会改了。关于这一点，好与坏见仁见智。我不赞赏这个设计，但是也不排斥。



那么我们说说缺点吧

ai智力问题，AI有时会出现仇恨奇高的bug（红仇恨太多），敌人一旦拉钟，特别还有平民的时候，会容易狂拉仇恨，红仇恨不断传播扩散，拉一大波怪不说而且你仇恨消除不掉（因为一旦敌人规模大了你不能保证每个敌人都能目睹你死亡 。仇恨清了一部分又重新通过传染全红）幸好的是，styx重来不是只有一条路能到目的地。

常常会出现的路径bug。
cyanide的路径工程师还要多加努力啊。
说到路径bug，就还有触发类的bug，严重起来的话，可能会导致你某种意外击杀的姿势无法实现（当然可以读更前的档解决，但是master的话，save yourself了.......[spoiler]对我说的就是绿帽情杀那事！[/spoiler])

偶尔出现的诡异跳跃碰撞判定bug，嗯
虽然bug这个东西什么游戏都会有，但是。精益求精总是我们玩家大老爷和开发商小孙崽都追求的事对不。

说到bug
小提示，某个喝醉酒的船长
[spoiler] 属于“死物”， [/spoiler]他是不会死的。所以...........




剧情这一点，你不是我说我都有点怀疑编剧是一边看肥皂剧一边用左手写的，但是嘛，这重要吗？？反正只要口碑好，哪怕是生化危机那种剧情一样是赚大钱的不是吗？（！？）
剧情这一点毕竟众口难调那我们摆开一边不谈剧情，起码我们小小哥布林的表情还是充满了细节的，嘴角轻微的上扬，苦恼的神态，不耐烦的表情。【配合styx的个性简直可以说是栩栩如生】
就这一点，我就觉得比很多面无表情念经一般的某些油戏，要好多了。高兴？ 苦着脸笑，平静？黑着脸看你。 难过？ 表情毫无变化。

个人色彩我愿意为这个评上一个高分，虽然它还是有不少的缺点，但是它绝对很有特色。
这个游戏的基因决定了它不是被大众热捧的游戏。但是同时，我相信喜欢它的粉丝还是很难动摇的。
7.5 它的一切都还不错，但是它的一切都有进步潜力。虽然说你会觉得这不是代表之作，但是绝对值得为它的未来抱有期待。

author: {'steamid': '76561197991077329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 932, 'last_played': 1499186087}
review:
[h1] ENG[/h1]
TL;DR/Actual review:
This game has horrible controls, unbelievably bad storyline script and acting, a charming hero, good sense of humour (specified) and detailed levels. If you have a friend to play with, are a fan of pure stealth, not afraid to die to BS reasons a lot and watch the loading screen for 70% of the playtime and like 4th wall jokes, pick it up on sale for 75% off or less. The review below is mostly for entertainment purposes, as we couldn’t find enough in the actual game.

Played through the game with my friend. Before that I played Of Orcs And Men, but couldn’t suffer it to the end. So what can this game offer? As it turns out: a lot! Here is why I consider it genius:
1)	Story. So what’s so good about? Well, to start with, you play not as some cliché primate like a human, but as an exotic creature – a goblin! Seriously, which of the recent titles lets you experience something like this? Skyrim? Fantasy heroes are all the same, and to make matters worse – often mute. How could you realise the scale of your task to save the world with such a hero?! But not in this game! Here, the “hero” will gladly tell everyone, including the player, what he thinks about you (butthurt warning!). And regarding the saving – all you save in this game, is your own arsе, and that, just to make it richer. And regarding plot twists – they are here and they are great. The hero knows exactly what will happen (he read the script, as he tells you many times), and makes full use of that knowledge to prank the suckers before delivering incredible one-liners than make Commander Shepherd jealous. Models, textures, etc. are top notch. And animations – a shining example of animator craftsmanship, something developers of Mass Effect Andromeda should learn from. Just missing VR mode for full immersion
2)	Level design is on the high mark (literally). Depending on where Styx’s adventure takes him, you’ll traverse everything from high mountains, to deepest shit dungeons. You’ll also raid an air caravan. In any case, the levels are very vertical by design and that’s a good thing – because flying down is faster than running around corridors, and you’ll fall fly down a lot. And you can scream more badass one-liners while you fall, which you’ll have plenty of chances to experience if you don’t master this game’s 100% skill-based and responsive controls. Every resource you need is always present when you want it. I wanted to follow Styx’s advice and thank the level designer, but when I arrived at the given address, I only saw a police line and the officer told me there was a violent murder here a few days ago. Strange…
3)	Gameplay. When you play Shards of Darkness, you sometimes feel like a Gopnik, squatting around in your Adidas-made robes, robbing suckers elfs of their valuables. Enemies will not tolerate such lack of class and stature, and will rather successfully break your face upon visual contact. The only way to prevent that is to attack them from behind, though that won’t work on armoured foes. Against those you can use acid darts or drop some heavy object hanging above by cutting the rope. Also enemies are perceptive and will generally find you everywhere, even though walls and seemingly solid objects. Especially dwarves – those can sniff you out from a mile away. All you can do is to vomit into soup and other food, that being the most reliable way of getting rid of any enemy. Tasting such a delicacy instantly fells even the mightiest foes. Styx’s rich inner world is simply too much to handle for the fragile nature of the other, lesser, races.

[h1] RU[/h1]
Короткая версия для тех, кто не хочет вчитываться:
В этой игре вы встретите ужасное управление, невероятно плохие сюжетную линию, сценарий и повествование. Хороший (не для всех) юмор, и детализированные уровни. Если у вас есть друг, явл. поклонником жанра скрытого прохождения и не боящийся умереть от всякой фигни, смотря на экран загрузки 70% времени, а также любящий шутки про 4-ую стену, то берите эту игру как мин. со скидкой 75%.  Обзор написан развлечения ради, т.к. мы не нашли его в достаточном количестве.

Я прошел игру вместе с другом. До этого играл в Of Orcs And Men, но так её и не осилил. Что же может предложить эта игра? Оказывается, оч. многое! И сейчас я распишу почему эта игра гениальна:
1)	Сюжет. Что в нём такого, спросите вы? Да хотя бы то, что вам приходится играть не за какого-то примата - человека, а за экзотическую зверушку – гоблина! Серьёзно, в каких последних ролевых играх вам приходилось играть за нечто оригинальное? В Скайриме? В фэнтези нет никакой фантазии среди главных героев, а ещё часть из них немые. Как тут проникнуться спасением мира?! Но только не в этой игре, тут «герой» с удовольствием выскажет всё что о вас он думает (возможен батхёрт). К слову, спасать вам простоит собственную ж**у, и то ради обогащения оной. С завитками сюжета тут тоже порядок. Герой просчитывает всё на много ходов вперёд (он много раз читал сценарий, о чём с удовольствием рассказывает) и хорошо окучивает лохов, так что никогда не знаешь, куда произойдёт очередной поворот сюжета. А ещё присутствует эльф-оборотень! Такое последний раз я видел в Dragon Age. Модели, текстуры и т.д.  – всё на высоте. А анимации – просто образец для создателей МЭ:Андромеда. Для полного погружения, пожалуй, не хватает только VR шлемов.
2)	Дизайн уровней выполнен на высоте (буквально). Смотря куда идёт Стикс вам придётся побывать в горах или же спускаться ниже плинтуса, в подземелье. В том числе есть набег на «воздушный караван» (в вашем лице). В любые случаи уровень будет вертикально ориентирован. И это хорошо, ведь лететь вниз всяко быстрее, чем бежать по коридору. Плюс можно сказать классную фразу пока летишь. А летать придётся часто, если не понять управление.  Всё что надо для жизни лежит там, где должно. Я хотел воспользоваться советом Стикса и пойти поблагодарить дизайнера уровней, но по адресу я встретил полицейского, который рассказала мне, что тут произошло жестокое убийство несколько дней назад. Странно.
3)	Если говорить о геймплее, то иногда возникает чувство, что играешь за какого-то гопника: пол уровня проводишь на корточках, отжимая у лохов эльфов нужные вещи. Враги же, завидев, такой уровень бескультурья смело бегут набивать Стиксу рожу, причём довольно успешно. Единственный способ справиться с ними – атаковать сзади, хотя против бронированных врагов поможет только кислотный душ или десятитонный колокол, не забудьте только приманить поближе. Враги же личности глазастые и легко найдут вас в любом укромном месте. Особенно гномы – эти учуют вас за версту. Единственное, что вам остаётся, так это плеваться в супчики и еду. Вкусив такой продукт, враги сразу дохнут. Ну не выдерживает тонкая эльфийская и не только натура богатого мира Стикса.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016884143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2665, 'last_played': 1496031924}
review:
There is a lot of good things in this game, and I am torn between a positive and negative review for it. 

Pros: The game is beautiful to look at, and it focuses almost exclusively on stealth. There are multiple ways to kill opponents, and as the game progresses, a higher percentage of enemies cannot be killed except by setting traps for them. There is an interesting skill tree in which most of the powers have a use and change the way you play. Most other games tend to have a lot of skills that are only useful in specific situations that might rarely ever occur, and feel like they are there to just pad out the skill tree. With Styx, this is not the case at all, and since  you can unlearn skills and use those points to learn others at the start of every level (and sometimes at points during the level), this allows you to try the entire set and pick the playstyle that suits you. The stealth feels very rewarding when you pull it off, as you are up against hordes of enemies as the game progresses, and learning their patrol patterns and finding the perfect moment to slip by feels exhilarating. Since you are powerless to fight back against some enemies, and will be killed very quickly by most of them, there is an immense feeling of accomplishment when you do manage to weave between enemies and get by unoticed. 

Cons: The biggest problem I have with this game, and the main reason why I decided to not reccomend it,  is the fact that this game decides to make you backtrack every single level you play through for the latter half of the game. You play through five different unique looking levels, and then play those exact same levels all over again with different enemies and a different starting location and different objectives. Playing one level over again is tolerable, but playing all five over again is just infurating. Instead of seeing something new, you see the same exact levels you spent an hour or more in exploring every nook and cranny for another mission. The levels are large, but not so large that it does not take away from the experience. It becomes painfully obvious that this was done to cut corners once you realize that the remainder of the game just involves repeating the same levels. Another problem is that the game feels artificial. The game world does not feel real in any way, since traps are placed conveniently for you over the heads of enemies, barrels inexplicably loaded with acid and perched on the edge of a balcony right where there happens to be a gap in the railing, above a group of enemies. Instead of feeling natural, it just becomes a game of identifying where the developers placed the traps they expect you to use. That really takes away from the feeling of achievement, and ruins the immersion to a great deal. The voice acting is perhaps the worst I have ever seen in a game, with characters all sounding like they have just swallowed a bottle full of oxycontin. They are flat, lifeless, and just painful to listen to.  The story, if it could be called one, is weak and more of an afterthought than anything. There is a plot, and you are after some shards, but the game never takes time to flesh out its world, and each faction you meet is an unknown except for the little bits of exposition you are subjected to in the aforementioned voice acting.

Conclusion: Buy this game if you love a stealth title and care more for the gameplay than the story, or better yet, only care abou the gameplay, and do not mind having only five or so distinct levels to play through, and are ok with replaying those same levels for the second half of the game. It has a lot of flaws, but it is an entertaining  couple of hours until it gets repetitive.  Even at its normal price, I would hesitate to purchase this game again, and instead wait until it costs much less.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974987616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1403, 'last_played': 1500845666}
review:
This is a solid stealth game with only a few small issues.

In comparison to the previous game, Styx: Master of Shadows, overall I would say it was a step backwards, which is unfortunate, but it's still a solid game.

Gameplay:
Sneak, kill, or misdirect to get your tasks complete.  It's fun.
Jumping to and from ropes felt weird, it was less of an issue by the time I finished it, but it was quite annoying at the beginning.

Level Design:
You get a lot more paths to help you get around, but the levels don't feel quite as "grand" as they did in the previous game.  The levels are big, but they feel enclosed and I never stopped or went out of my way to just look at the scenery like I did in Master of Shadows.


There are two things that I must rant about though:

1.  The final boss battle... When you die (and you will), you get loaded back into the hideout and you have to reselect the level and load back in  Once you get to the first checkpoint, you will load back in at that point and its a non-issue, but it was needlessly tiresome.
2.  the ending... just... why?  It definatley left a lot to be desired.

review:
If you're a fan of the hardcore stealth genre, you know we hardly get any games at all. That being said, I generally take what I can get because developers rarely make these types of games anymore. I'd say this is an above average hardcore stealth game. Large environments to roam around in, plenty of guards to avoid, and lots of options to approach the objective. It has some issues, namely the AI is 'good enough' and the 'ledge grab' issues are still present. They have slightly improved the 'ledge grab' issues but they are not completely resolved. Highly recommend if you're a fan of the genre though.

If you haven't played the first game, I'd highly recommend you try that first. It's much cheaper and pretty much the same. Still not sure? Try the demo and see what you think!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962311919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 10729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3143, 'last_played': 1637745318}
review:
The virtue of Styx and games of it's ilk are in giving you a big map with lots of people to kill/sneak past and lots of toys with which to do this. It's a puzzle game when you strip it back to it's bare bones.

The trouble with the original and more so in the sequel is what they add to the mix to keep that interesting. Although I'd say the format is good enough on it's own.

Boss fights in a stealth game are astoundingly irritating, the game has trained me to sneak and now I'm having to dodge monster boulders whilst climbing ledges? Who thought that was a good idea? In fact climbing itself is still a pain, the 3rd person perspective means you can't see where you are supposed to be jumping too next or how far away a rope or a ledge might be, it's just death and frustration. They've added crafting which is just a waste of time and also frustrating as you are always having to pick up ingredients or never having the right ones. But crafting does allow more variety in gameplay so that I could let pass. 

Although the stories are good enough, better than some (Dishonored) the script is appalingly bad and just exposes the lack of class and taste that could raise it up and give the franchise far more respect. I just grind my teeth every time they make a joke or reference, even the first game was written better. The humor was within the world whereas here every gag is at the expense of immersion, it's as if they just don't care about creating a convincing setting for the game.

Right this second I'm on the line on a recommendation for this one, there are so many things against it, worst of all was the ending which was boss fight and then credits without even an attempt to finish the story. But the game has it's moments, the stealth is sound and the puzzle maps are great (even if the actual puzzle mission was a miserable experience) and I'm itching to get back into the game and play it through in a no kill run but the boss maps and the elf initiation map are genuinely putting me off bothering.

The one thing that's going to edge me into a rec is the co-op mode, which is great fun. At least then you can moan with each other about the game's many failings and vent a little. A stealth game is pretty rare these days and stealth co-op just takes me back to playing Thievery UT, so for that I'll reluctantly give this one a thumbs up.

I'm optimistic for the next one, I just hope they play to the game's virtues rather than feeling like they have to add the moronic tropes Shards is plagued with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049654013', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 11464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7326, 'last_played': 1501210762}
review:
Really poor transition from Master of Shadows. I finished the game only because of how much I loved the first, but it never got more rewarding. The addition of ropes was hardly the massive new dynamic they seemed to have expected (you still can't stick the dagger in banners and using that to slide down distances), the boss fights are atrocious arcade-game breaks from the reason you purchased the game and functionally the exact same boss fight with a different skin, the dwarf enemies smelling your location wasn't compelling or difficult to get around but instead just odd and a clear attempt at trying to make them in some way different (whereas the thing that made the elf enemies different and unique from the previous title--being unable to kill them from the ground due to the height difference--has been removed). Armored enemies are everywhere, giving you less opportunity to be a murderous Goblin killing about everything in your path, and the level design in general is far worse than the previous title.

There's also no night vision unlike in the first, which constantly has you stumbling about and trying to figure out if you can make it through a particular passage, which was probably my most constant annoyance. The idea of a sheath was a bad one, it got rid of the silhouette of the skulking Goblin we know and love, the cover option to slide around walls is almost constantly broken by random flavor objects in the scenery, and the weapon crafting system is a bust, feeling like a tedious version of restocking that made no sense (he turns Iron Ore into darts in moments), and the decision to get rid of throwing knives for darts was really poor as well. Glitches happened just frequently enough to make them obvious, including the final cut scene of the game being ruined by my character falling through the floor (still don't know what happened).

The scenery and environments are beautiful but there aren't many so they quickly become stale. In addition to being too dark to really appreciate with the previously mentioned lack of night vision. Also, the character dialogue is much, much worse, with Styx himself being the worst offender. The constant fourth wall breaks tear you out of the game constantly, and the steady stream of modern pop-culture references are too-oft repeated, especially when they weren't funny in the first place (there is a crystalline resource in the game that you break to harvest, there's about one a level, and every single time he'll say after busting one "Not breaking this would be bad"). The game feels like Styx went from an interesting perfect capture of a grimy, murderous, sociopathic Goblin to a cheap Deadpool knockoff that's done poorly.

The game is playable, and not so bad that you'll want to quit playing it partway through if you're committed to learning the story and finishing it (you'll have no reason to otherwise, I often found myself wanting to Google the total number of missions to figure out how much more I had to do, rather than exploring every nook and cranny to get the most playtime out of the game), but it's so lackluster in design that it almost feels like the game was worked on by an entirely different team. Don't buy this unless you're a big fan of the first one, and even then get it on sale.

Edit: Most of my hours came from having this game on while I was at work. I did not get 200 hours of playtime out of this game and again the playtime I did get out of it was a drag.

review:
Styx ist ein Auftragsdieb in einer runter gekommenen Welt ! 

Er hält nicht viel aus ,weshalb schleichen und meucheln im dunkeln angesagt ist ! 

Das Setting passt gut zusammen und das spielen macht auch Spass !

Viele verschiedene Tunnel und Wege führen zum Ziel !



Dennoch zieht Styx mich nicht so wirklich zu sich zurück...
man kennt schon die ganze Spielmechanik, es gibt nichts neues !

Es wirkt auch alles sehr einfach und man macht immer nur das gleiche !
(Überblick verschaffen, Alarm deaktivieren, Fackeln löschen, Gegner meucheln und in Kisten/Schränken verstecken)

Wer damit klar kommt hat ein Cooles Sneakgame für zwischendurch !

author: {'steamid': '76561198019496345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 769, 'last_played': 1576040052}
review:
Pros:
Great stealth game - anyone complaining about the combat is missing the point
Option for no alert and no kill runs in pretty much every level
Lots of verticality to the levels, and lots of exploring is encouraged
Interesting story, though nothing groundbreaking
Funny protagonist who breaks the fourth wall fairly often
Co-op (I haven't gotten to actually try it, but I love that they added the option)
You can go back and re-play earlier levels with new upgrades (you can even change your skill tree at will)
A variety of enemies who can detect you in different ways

Cons:
I get some D3D error fairly often, and the game CTDs - 2019 update: the issue seems resolved
Pre-order DLC
The final level breaks from the spirit of the game and has really messed up save timing

Nit-picking Gripes:
Many of the upgrade perks only benefit assassination (even the "stealth" tree) when I like to play no kill
Limited number of save slots for some reason (cloud sync reasons?)
Too many "find all the X" side missions in the levels. There are already coins to hunt in every level.

review: Styx is what I look for in a stealth game. Large open-ended levels, various secondary mission objectives, cool powers that let you solve situations in different ways, and an interesting setting. Styx may seem a bit ridiculous at times, but I still love his character. It makes me care a bit about what I'm doing rather than just admiring the mechanics of the game. Shards of Darkness improved on a lot of things. Enemy designs never seemed unbalanced. Abilities helped emphasized how you wanted to play. And I wanted to complete all the secondary objectives. Gotta get me that quartz. I'd definitely recommend this if you are a fan of stealth games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068047040', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1845, 'last_played': 1690885697}
review:
This is a casual jump&run stealth game that you will probably enjoy - especially if you are a stealth fan ... up until you hit one boss level in the middle of the game: the grinding begins - You can't save and you are cursed to start the level over and over and over and over again ;-( ...the riddles in the game are nice and managable but this level is all about banging your head against a door until it breaks - stupid and monotonous. Same with the end-boss level - stupid grinding and the end is even more abrupt than that of 'Deus Ex Mankind Devided' - I had to check YouTube if by some glitch I had jumped several levels to the end screen ... Do you recommend this game? I dont know - probably yes: its like having had a great vacation and at the airport on the way back your bodily openings are thoroughly inspected by customs. Styx 1 I liked much better - even though it has 
 simpler graphics and maps. To sum it up: Casual playing with enemies moving on rail-tracks until you hit an insanely difficult and monotonous boss-level ... and after that its back to casual again - doing the same thing over and over again - I played Dishonored 2 before playing this game and that was infinitely better in 'stealth and story' - maybe thats why I am biased

author: {'steamid': '76561198049625916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1318, 'last_played': 1562441839}
review:
Great Stealth game.

If you like sneaking around, completing objectives without being seen and/or kiling anyone, this game will fill those needs. (Achievements for "Ghost" (not spotted/no alarms) and "Mercy" (no kills) ) - the things I really want to be possible in a stealth game. 

I played through it in 2-3 Days (on Vacation, so I didn't do much else ;) ) on Normal difficulty.
The AI/Enemys are easily avoidable if you're patient and don't do anything stupid like running around well lit areas and jumping in front of them - I will surely play again on a harder level, probably try to kill all enemies without setting off alarms. 

It was a moderate challenge (normal difficulty) - but very fun.

Story is cool, there are some refferences to the first game (Styx: Master of Shadows), but it isn't required to play/understand this one. 
Styx is very snarky, almost too much for my taste..seems like the target audience is late-teen boys, some jokes are seem to be trying so hard to be edgy and not givin' a heck.
But if you can get over that, which isn't realy hard, you'll enjoy this game. 

The Levels have multiple ways to go about them, and there are usually secondary objectives (that are unfortunately not always tied into the cutscenes, so you have to check your mission objectives panel to see what you need to do). 

Visually very pleasing, also I experienced no glitches or bugs/crashes. 

If you like stealth games and sneaking, buy. If you're not sure, wait for a sale or try the Demo if it's still available.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016429897', 'num_games_owned': 827, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1499653755}
review:
great game, great story, great sequel.
overall, this was a pretty good follow-up to Styx's misadventures, with a good cast of characters.
the end didn't answer much about what happens to Styx or the people he meets, but i suppose they're saving that for another game?
the gameplay was similar to Master of Shadows, but also unique with the addition of more abilities like invisibility and cocoon-throwing (which spawns the Clone at the area of the thrown cocoon), which blending item-crafting and abilities.
i see a lot of room for improvement with the equipment, you can get a Cloak of Invisibility (which is perfect for my playstyle), but never got to equip it before i finished the story. Styx had a lot of character time in this game, and even in the death screen.
LOTS of fourth-wall breaking, like more than I personally liked, but it suits the game. 
LOTS of references to things, the typical pop-culture references, but also homages to the genre of stealth.
the sidequests made me detour from the main story to steal a few emblems, or get a pure Quartz (which you need to unlock the ultimate ability in each ability tree, and you choose 1 OF 2 abilities that cater to a certain playstyle).
for example, the "Kill" abilities split in 2 directions, assassinations and fighting; the ultimate ability makes you choose between an assassination ability, or an ability to help you fight.
a fun game, you don't even need to play the first to understand what happens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062781295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 942, 'last_played': 1635586861}
review:
Gioco assolutamente consigliato agli amanti della saga (ed, in particolare, al protagonista) e a chi apprezza un buon stealth. 

Appena ho sentito dell'uscita di questo titolo l'ho preacquistato in copia fisica, quindi parlerò da semi-amante della serie. Dico semi semplicemente perchè mi rendo conto che non è tutto oro e ha sicuramente i suoi difetti.

Il gioco, sia dal punto di vista tecnico che narrativo, mi è parso molto semplice, ma anche molto ben fatto. Il comparto grafico è dicreto, nulla di mostruoso ma di sicuro ben fatto. Ho apprezzato in particolare la gestione di luci ed ombre, che in un gioco del genere non poteva essere lasciata al caso. Degno di nota anche il level design e la struttura delle mappe, molto grandi e che permettono di affrontare le missioni nel modo che più si preferisce, totalmente furtivo o facendo stragi di nemici. Tra l'altro mi è sembrato ottimizzato anche molto bene, dato che non sono quasi mai sceso sotto i 60 fps pur tenendo tutte le impostazioni al massimo e senza surriscaldare minimamente il pc (sempre tenuto le ventole al minimo). Ho notato solo alcuni glitch e bug grafici (classiche texture non caricate, per esempio), ma molto raramente e che non hanno pregiudicato la partita.
Per quanto riguarda l'audio non c'è molto da dire, è ovviamente fondamentale se si vuole affrontare una mappa furtivamente in quanto ci permette di distinguere bene i passi e i rumori dei nemici. La colonna sonora, viceversa, mi è sembrata quasi assente o, comunque, per nulla fastidiosa o insistente, nonostante quei pochi pezzi percepibili in alcune aree siano molto carini e azzeccati. 
Ho trovato la trama abbastanza carina anche se un pò semplice, ma di sicuro ben sviluppata. In ogni missione è presente anche una piccola missione secondaria che permetterà di approfondire leggermente il mondo di gioco e di raccogliere esperienza extra. Una cosa che mi ha fatto storcere un po' il naso è la caratterizzazione dei due personaggi secondari e il loro rapporto col protagonista. Senza fare spoiler, l'ho trovato leggermente forzato e poco credibile. Inoltre non ho particolarmente apprezzato la scena finale (proprio come sviluppo della trama), ma questi credo siano gusti.
Il gameplay è molto simile al primo titolo della serie: si tratta di raggiungere il proprio obiettivo scegliendo fra le varie possibilità offerte dalla mappa. Personalmente credo che, per godere appieno del titolo, sia quasi indispensabile giocarlo il più possibile furtivamente, evitando di far scattare allarmi o di uccidere nemici. Questo stimolerà il giocatore a trovare e provare un sacco di strategie insolite e divertenti per finire la quest. 
Ovviamente però, il più grande pregio di questo gioco è costituito dal protagonista. Styx, infatti, è un personaggio incredibilmente carismatico, che ci terrà compagnia con le sue frasi e i suoi commenti durante tutto il gioco. Cosa molto carina, quando si morirà potrà apparire un video di Styx che se la prenderà con il giocatore deridendolo e commentando la scarsa capacità di progredire nel gioco. Sono rari i giochi che fanno davvero ridere e divertire in questo modo.

Ma come già detto, anche questo titolo ha i suoi difetti. Il più grosso, purtroppo, è la ripetitività. Dopo alcune ore, infatti, ci renderemo conto che il gioco è sostanzialmente sempre uguale. Cambieranno le situazioni, le mappe (anche se non sono molte e spesso ritorneremo più volte nelle stesse) e gli obiettivi, ma le cose da fare saranno sempre le stesse. Quindi non aspettatevi un gioco particolarmente stimolante e che vi terrà attaccati allo schermo ore ed ore. Anzi, rischierà di farvi annoiare dopo un po'. Devo ammettere che anch'io, poco dopo la metà, ho pensato di abbandonarlo. Ma per ovvi motivi non l'ho fatto. Fortunatamente non dura molto, circa 15 ore (nel mio caso e senza far scattare allarmi, senza uccidere nemici e raccogliendo più gettoni possibili), ma è possibile finirlo anche in meno tempo.

In sintesi è un titolo davvero divertente per le prime ore, che però diventa presto ripetitivo. Quindi è da consigliare sicuramente a chi ama la saga e il protagonista o a chi cerca un titolo leggero ma che offre comunque un buon grado di sfida (giocatelo a difficoltà difficile, mi raccomando!). A tal proposito occhio al prezzo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022219953', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2096, 'last_played': 1499457273}
review:
PRO
- Gameplay intuitivo e solido
- Meccaniche stealth e platforming ben bilanciate e amalgamate
- Sistema di crafting ed equip ridotto all'osso, ma anch'esso molto ben bilanciato rispetto alle necessità del gameplay e 
   del level design
- Leveling system piacevole anche se ho trovato poco utili alcune delle abilità ai fini del gameplay (come il ramo del corpo a corpo)
- Level design divertente in termini di struttura
- Audio nella media
- Grafica nella media
- Ottima caratterizzazione del protagonista...

CONTRO
- ....peccato sia l'unico personaggio in game studiato per bene
- storia fiacca, poco mordente, scorre con pochissime emozioni
- Level design carente in termini di fantasia e quantità. Le zone sono molto carine e ben rese, ma come nel primo capitolo, sono poche, e il player viene portato avanti e indietro sempre nelle stesse zone fino alla fine del gioco. Questa carenza di ambienti contribuisce alla perdita di patos della trama

Tutto sommato, se siete fan del genere stealth e vi va di farvi due risate con styx, prendetelo, soprattutto se in offerta. Questo gioco ha tante qualità che riusciranno a farvi passare qualche decina di ore di divertimento e leggerezza, nonostante una storyline banale e fiacca

the stealth genre is slowly but surely dying and the styx series had the opportunity to take over that niche, nobody was catering to. instead the devs decided to blow their budget on things the community didn't ask for and which to this day don't function very well.

review:
This game is great.
It feels like a love note to the old school stealth games, with a positive modern touch.
It adds new mechanics and improves the old from the first game, but it isn't always consistent. Sometimes a guard will see you if you're behind a more see-through object like a cage, and sometimes they won't. This isn't detrimental in the slightest, though.
The only other complaints I have aren't even about the gameplay, and serve as a minor annoyance in this gem of a game. One of which is that Styx likes to break the 4th wall and talk to the player sometimes. A tiny bit annoying, but I tolerated it, he's fun to listen to.

Sort of a spoiler: The ending is a little dissapointing, espscially when compared to the first one, and I seriously hope they patch in another one or make a DLC to add a little closure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040341887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1245, 'last_played': 1499443754}
review:
小兵居然会抬头！
一代很多点到为止的元素二代都给做大了，比如一代故意跳楼会fckyou，二代直接做了一堆过场。用克隆推硫酸罐砸死自己，他会跟我说“你拿脚打游戏是没有成就的”
尿素瓶浇过的官二代居然有戏份
无敌怪不能禽抱了
不过整个角色都变了，二代故事没有一代那样有个明确坚定的目的。感觉就是故事结束后主角开心快活的旅游blog
环境设计也跟1代有气氛上的区别
一代虽然没有飞艇环境，但是陆地环境除了空岛城堡，就是随脚天坑的下水道，这种设计大开大合，但都不会给玩家脚踏实地的感觉，很符合我个人对steampunk那类环境的概念。
而二代，怎么说，毕竟故事上讲飞天大陆被nakash搞炸了，关卡设计上也可以看得出长高度差以及天坑满布，还有许多绝景攀岩超高可攀爬大铁门之类的，甚至还有劫持飞艇的关卡。我可以理解到制作人对陆地/海洋的故事背景造成的相对一代的环境改变的弥补，但是这到底是弥补，直接玩二代或许会觉得到位，但玩过一代再来，那么大一座山，哪怕你爬在绝壁上，你终究还是脚踏实地的，不会有一代环境造成的危机感或者说爽感。

author: {'steamid': '76561198090685775', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1501557663}
review:
Depois de jogar Styx Master of Shadows, só tenho a dizer uma coisa depois de jogar Shards of Darkness: Melhor evolução que ja vi em um jogo

TODOS os problemas de controles foram resolvidos e é muito gostoso de jogar, você tem total controle de tudo. O unico pontinho negativo é que você não pode controlar o tamanho do pulo pelo tempo que segura o botão, por exemplo, se você der um toque no X (Pulo) ele vai fazer o pulo alto sem diferença. Isso não atrapalha no gameplay, mas é uma coisinha que poderiam arrumar num patch, os controles são 9/10, mas com esse negócio do pulo seria 10/10, como falei, os controles são muito gostosos

Os graficos estão lindos, o Styx e personagens secundarios estão muito bem feitos. O mapa também está bonito, não é um jogo leve, mesmo meu PC sendo um I5 com GTX1050ti, tive que reduzir alguns graficos para rodar em 60FPS, mas mesmo assim tava bonito

A história não é tão épica quanto a do Master of Shadows (primeiro jogo), mas é aceitavel, os personagens são muito bem escritos e divertidos, e a história é boa (Ficou aberto para uma continuação que espero ansioso, essa saga só vai melhorar a qualidade) 

As habilidades estão perfeitas, a skill tree está ótima, sempre me senti no controle dos meus poderes, muito bom, eu realmente me sentia o "Mestre das Sombras"

O bom é que em nenhum momento o jogo me jogou em uma situação em que eu ficasse bravo e falasse "Isso é injusto!" ou "Isso não foi pensado direito", tudo no jogo foi feito pra você usar o ambiente, itens ou habilidades para você passar, sempre foi um desafio justo

Eu sou amante de Stealth e me deixa muito feliz ver uma série crescendo tanto, me atrevo a dizer que esse vai ser o novo "Assassins Creed" (que cai entre nós, nunca foi 100% focado em stealth)

O co-op é só um bonus, consegui zerar o jogo sem e vou tentar jogar com um amigo ver como é

---Resumo (TL;DR)
Ver a evolução do Master of Shadows pra Shard of Darkness só me faz ver como é uma saga com potencial incrivel. O jogo tem graficos lindos, com ótimos controles e jogabilidade muito boa e 100% stealth (você não pode ligar o "foda-se" e lutar com todo mundo), a história é boa, não é incrivel, mas sinto que eles querem começar a trabalhar com algo maior no futuro, e esse é o inicio

Recomendo demais esse jogo

author: {'steamid': '76561197973969116', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1499281918}
review:
Before I bought it,  I thought it looked interesting but hadn't played previous title in the series, (I am a fan of stealth games)
I was pleasently suprised by how good it was and refreshing compared to most other stealth games with a really interesting main character you play as.

Every mission gives you almost unlimited ways to aproach it,  and different enemies and landscapes made it feel less repetative aswell since they offered different challanges like ex. Dwarfs that don't rely as much on view as they do on their smell, and can notice your presence by that but will still need to activly find you through sight still,  or small insect monsters in certain parts that are more or less blind and can't smell you either BUT are super sensitive to sound compared to most humanoid opponents.


If I should make one or 2 small complaints about the game it would be it was fairly short still for a single player campaign only game,    I don't have a problem with a game that focuses alot of multiplayer aspect aswell to be shorter like 10-15 hours long single player,  but if a game that only focus on single player is shorter 20 hours of gameplay when incorporating the side quests per mission that is,  then I'm a  bit disapointed, basically it was a bit short in my honest opinion,  I did finnish it in like 12-13 hours or so doing all the secondary quets and focusing on collecting alot of tokens too.

the other small negative side would be the ending,  it felt very emty,   it was more of a "To be Continued" thing.. and while parts of the story was concluded I suppose we never really got to feel like it at all,  BUT that can still be turned around to even be an possitive side if they plan on releasing DLC expantions for this game with more missions,  if they do they this would no longer be a problem I suppose.

overall the game was really made well and met most of my expectations and more I highly recomend this game to any one who likes stealth games or even those who havn't tried a good stealth game too as it's a fairly good one to start with.

review:
Styx: Shards of Darkness est le premier Styx au quelle j'ai l'occasion de jouer.
Un jeux extrement drôle du au Petit Goblin qui est le protagoniste qui nous insulte a chaque fois que nous le tuons par inadevertance. Les missions sont pour moi un peu répétitive mais si a chaque fois il y'a differente possibilité de le finir. Un durée de vie correcte. Je salue le studio pour l'emplois du moteur Unreal Engine 4 qui apporte des graphisme de très bonne qualité. Une optimisation au petit ognion qui nous permet de jouer avec des images par secondes très éléver malgres la qualité des graphisme. Des collectibles qui font office de remplissage initule au jeux.
9 Mission vous sont proposer dans cette aventure compter environ 1 heure par mission voir un peu plus si vous ne savais plus ou aller ou vous ne savez pas jouer discret, ce qui peut être problématique dans une jeux Stealth..
Je le recommande, c'est une agréable surprise que je vous conseil de faire.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979875574', 'num_games_owned': 2113, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1768, 'last_played': 1499100566}
review:
Highly underrated game right there.  

Styx is the sequel to the excellent "Styx, Master of Shadows", which itself is a prequel to "Orcs and Men", and this title here is a prequel as well.  You basically play a very old goblin named Styx with an addiction to Amber, which is basically mana in this game.  While the first game happened in a large tower, you get to travel a lot here and the level design is far better than the first game.  Every map feel alive with people doing their things and guards patrolling, chatting, eating, even sleeping.

You get to meet several characters and all are interesting, especially the title character himself.  He breaks the fourth wall a great deal, references other games in a tongue in cheek manner and every death is followed by a quick animation of the goblin insulting you in one manner or the other.  He seems well aware he is in a video game, especially during these animations, or with frequent comments like "There's a lot of stuff to find, almost like someone wants me to look all over the level" or one of my favorites, at the beginning of a certain mission "It's another of these missions where if I get spotted, it's game over...  capiche?".  There's another character, Helledryn, who's a good example of a strong female done right, the relationship with Styx -almost- gets close and they're pretty funny together.  

The music, like the first game is top notch and is very unique.  The voice acting is much better than the first game too and different races have their distinctive accents..  elves have a whispy, hissing voice, dwarves belch and carry a scottish brogue and orcs of course are grunting and coarse.  

Graphics are another improvement over the first game and levels all have a very distinct feeling to them.  Sadly, the game does repeat levels like in the original title but it's not as bad as the first title where you'd see all levels at least twice and one three times but it's still a bit annoying, especially with how different levels feel.  Storywise it does make sense and they do change enemies and positions but it's still a bit "meh" when you see a familiar level loading.

Like in the first game, people will complain about the combat as it feels stiff and unnatural and the solution is the same as in the original :  Play the game on the difficulty level the devs intended.  It's called "goblin" for a reason.  Combat becomes non existent as whoever gets close enough to you kills you in one shot.  You can of course still kill people with your dagger but an alerted guard or monster that spots you will kill you instantly and it's back to the game over screen with a goblin yelling at you.  I'm not even sure why devs thought that including combat was a good thing in the first place, you're playing a weak, little, evil green guy, not Sam Fisher.

There's a solid replay value too, as you get four optional tokens in a mission, each granting some skill points.  Swiftness for finishing a level under X minutes, Ghost for not being spotted even once, Mercy for not killing anyone (except monsters and targets) and Thief, for finding all ten collectibles in a map.  Contrary to the first game, you can get your "See collectibles" power pretty early so you won't be scratching your head trying to find them.  They,re also all in "natural" places unlike the first game so as long as you check every room in a level you'll probably find them all without a FAQ.

Pros :
- Fun story
- Great characters
- Sweet music
- Good level design
- Finding creative ways to kill people is hilarious
- Styx is basically the goblin version of Deadpool

Cons :
- Repeating levels

Maybe :
- Combat.  Seriously, ignore the complains, grab this title and just play on Goblin.  It's the way it's meant to be played in the first place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029446556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1413, 'last_played': 1499207308}
review:
Let me introduce the Dark Souls of the Stealth genre. 

After playing Styx: Masters of Shadows, seeing this game come on sale was an insta-buy. I've been playing for about two hours now, and I am already more in love than I was before. So lets jump right into the positives, with a comprehensive pro/con list in the end.

Voice Acting: From its predecessor, the voice acting has already majorly improved. Styx is more vocal, more witty and clever, and just an all around lovable protagonist for a game such as this. His demeanor is that of Dennis Leary, and he keeps you smiling with his foul-mouthed quips as the game progresses. His references to other stealth titles such as Dishonored and Assassin's Creed are also not as ham-fisted as other games, and are likewise not so "On-the-nose", such as Duke Nukem. Whenever Styx breaks the fourth wall, usually only in short phrases upon death in which he criticises the player, it feels apropriate and comical, and since this is saved only for your untimely demise, it doesn't awkwardly disconnect you from the gameplay. 

Sound: The sound design doesn't match up to triple A titles, but this should be expected from an indie developer with a lower budget. All the sounds feel right, but the volume is a bit off. As an example, walking in a room even while crouched with other people nearby can sound almost like a busy New York sidewalk, sometimes making it a bit harder to focus. All around, the sound is much nicer and more crisp, settling into the world nicely. Along with this, this game has a lovely, fitting soundtrack which keeps you on edge and helps draw you into the world, something the previous game lacked. 

A.I.: The enemies in this game are not as easily fooled as those in Skyrim, Assassin's Creed, or even Dishonored. Should you bump a chair, it will fall to the ground, clattering loudly. In other titles I have openly found myself smashing against a physics object such as this, seeing it fly towards a guard, and saying aloud, in a mocking tone, "Oh, well I guess thats just fine then." However, in this game, the enemies will be alerted to the noise, and should they be repeatedly tipped off, they will draw arms and scour the area for you. 

Combat: This game is no walk in the park in which you can draw a sword and go about your mission in a fight-club manner. There isn't any karate-film mentality, that is, the mentality of one person coming to attack you at a time whilst the others stand idly by, waiting their turn (Looking at you, Ubisoft). No, the enemies swarm you and seek your blood. No chance for survival in anything more than two on one combat. You're allowed no breathing room once the fight begins. You're a goblin, small, fast, and mean, but strongly lacking the combat abilities of say, an orc. You rely on stealth and trickery, and the combat reflects this by giving you only the ability to parry an enemy, stunning them and leaving you either a chance to flee, or cut their throat. You are not strong, and you're aware of it. 

Stealth: This is the centric formula for this game, and if you're not good at it, don't buy. Simple as that. 

Graphics: The world is beautiful, well-designed, and open for your exploring purposes.

Movement, and the World: Styx's top speed is much higher than before, allowing swift escapes if need be, and quick maneuvers allow the ability to survive much better than before. Parkour in this game requires skill, precision, and timing, whereas other titles involving this aspect are usually either too clunky, or too simple. In AC, I never really felt like I was DOING anything to EARN this "climbing to the tallest building" thing. Likewise, random boards and poorly-built walls aren't your method of movement. Climbing and traversing an area feels fitting, as though it were really just pure skill that allows you to move through this area. 

The gameplay is solid, the world is gorgeous, and the dialogue is phenomenal. Now, this review is already long enough, so for the negatives, I'll leave that comprehensive chart.

Pros:
-Parkour is responsive and skill-based
-Stealth is intricate and awards/kills feel earned
-World is open and fun to explore
-Side quests
-Progression through skill trees

Cons:
-Progression requires high skill (i.e. Earning of medals, doing side quests) to achieve more skills
-Sound design is a bit flat, everything is roughly the same volume
-Classic glitch from the original game: enemies getting stuck on terrain whilst patrolling
-Difficulty (Although this is, in my opinion, a GOOD thing, some people dislike games that aren't instantly gratifying or have a high learning curve)

Overall, I'd easily give this Indie GOTY, and a solid 9.5/10

Buy it while its on sale. The inclusion of multiplayer offers hours of countless fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989045257', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1809, 'last_played': 1498922485}
review:
Si vous avez aimé le 1... vous n'aimerez pas le 2. D'un gameplay d'infiltration plutôt sympa, avec un personnage principal à l'humour assez "piquant", on passe à un jeu au gameplay plutôt raté, entrecoupant missions où si on se fait voir 1 fois, c'est la fin du niveau (pourquoi avoir autant d'option pour parer ou s'enfuir, si cela ne sert à rien ?) et missions avec des boss à la Shadow of Colossus.... Je n'ai rien contre cela, mais cela n'a à mon sens rien à faire dans Styx, pourquoi pas une course de véhicules pendant qu'on y est ?!

Quand à l'humour du 1, cela se limite à des référence à d'autres jeux (Assassin's Screed) ou des films (Le Seigneur des Anneaux)... tellement original ! Les seuls réflexions "drôles" apparaissent lorsque l'ont meurt, mais, au bout de la 30ème fois, même cela devient lassant...

Les point forts:
- Enfin un bouton pour choisir si Styx doit s'accrocher sur un rebord ou non (point pénible du 1er opus)
- Nouvelles possibilités d'armement (alchimie) et d'équipement (quelques dagues aux effets variés), malheureusement pas assez exploités/exploitable (voir description des niveaux plus haut)
- Très bonne direction artistique, les graphismes et la bande son sont superbes

Les points faibles:
- Si comme moi vous pensiez jouer en coop tranquilles, oubliez l'affaire: le jeu passe en mode difficile automatiquement, il devient impossible de parer les attaques des gardes, et de plus, chaque fois qu'un allié meurt, le faire réapparaître consomme la moitié de la vie restantte de l'autre. Bilan: personne n'a jamais de vie, et impossible de parer les attaques --> repéré = tué. Joie.
- Qui a eu l'idée (mauvaise) d'introduire des boss et des missions où se faire repérer signe instantanément la fin de la mission (encore, UNE mission spécifique j'aurai pu comprendre) ?

Bref, si vous voulez découvrir la licence Styx, régalez-vous avec le 1er opus, et si vous voulez jouer en coop, prenez un autre jeu !

author: {'steamid': '76561198095285675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1542760678}
review:
Styx is Deadpool now. I love it. If you're one of those grumpy people who don't like less than perfect humor, you might not like dying. If anything, it will condition you to die less so you don't have to have Styx lecture you about pizza. 

In my opinion, a game doesn't have to have a good story if it has good, challenging gameplay. It pays homage to older stealth games where you can't just go rambo and fight your way through a level. You gotta sneak! It is a stealth game, after all. Completionists like myself will have a field day with this game, (or hate it because there's so much to complete) and fans of sneaky beaky games like Dishonored or Thief will enjoy themselves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103419687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1087, 'last_played': 1505408938}
review:
전작은 하지 않았지만 순수한 잠입 액션 게임의 느낌이 들어서 구매. 
잠입의 순수함이 있는 게임이다. 
화끈한 액션을 원한다면 맞지 않을 것. 

다만 전투 플레이가 난이도는 둘째치고 점수나 메달 등의 점수에 도움이 전혀 안 되기 때문에 전투 스킬을 찍을 메리트 자체가 느껴지지 않았다. 

스플린터셀 : 블랙리스트는 어설트 스타일 골드 따기 위해서는 막장 전투 플레이도 한 번쯤은 할 메리트가 있는데 스틱스는 막장 학살 플레이에 대한 메리트가 이렇게도 플레이 할 수 있다는 자기 만족에 그치는 점이 아쉬움. 

Mercy의 반대급부가 되는 스코어가 따로 있었으면 그것도 괜찮았을 것 같다.



공식 한글화는 안 됐지만 한글 패치는 잘 작동하고 한글화의 수준이 높으니 스토리 이해도 접근이 쉬운편. 

다만 후속작의 떡밥인지 모르겠으나 약간 김 빠지는 결말이라 마지막 인상이 좀 헐겁다는 아쉬움.

review: Very hardcore stealth game with amazing humor and a very uniqe and inventive coop system. You die very easily and there is no real combat, so it demands you be extremely stealthy and cautious, like if a guard detects the smallest sign of you he will be hunting you down with high quality AI and once he finds you you are basically dead. The coop is so much fun in this, you spawn in through eachother by the act of throwing up amber, and it only makes you lose when both players die, so the host can spawn back in through the clone, also the respawn time is only 10 seconds. It is very fun so far, the difficulty makes it quite frustrating, but it is a super unique stealth game with many great gameplay mechanics and very satisfying coop. I'll give it a 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994190576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1829, 'last_played': 1498650357}
review:
This is a great game if you like a fairly hardcore stealth, i.e. if you get seen 9 times out of ten you die. The Styx character is funny and sets this game apart from the other good stealth games around. The storyline is good, the scenery is excellent and allows various paths to be taken, and there are loads of opportunities to kill bad guys in amusing ways. 

It is pretty hard, I played on normal difficulty and died a lot so I would recommend saving at regualr intervals. There are a couple of things that could be improved.

1. There is no brightness adjustment in the game, I found some areas too dark to see anything.

2. The most annoying flaw is the hit and miss ability to grab ledges. Sometimes Styx will grab them, sometimes not, which led to more than a few unnecessary deaths. I still haven't found a reliable way to walk out of a window and have Styx grab the ledge as he falls which can be very frustrating.

Other than that it's a great game and recommended.
