author: {'steamid': '76561198009521433', 'num_games_owned': 751, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1240, 'last_played': 1656713823}
review:
[b]Styx Shards of Darkness[/b] ist ein Schleichspiel der alten Schule, in dem man
sich den Lösungsweg selbst erarbeiten muss und dadurch in der eigenen Handlung viele Freiheiten geboten bekommt.Viele Situationen werden in bester [b]Trial-and-Error-Manier[/b] [i]gelöst[/i].

Die seichte und nicht wirklich mitreisende 0815 Story plätschert in ihren [b]8 (9) Kapiteln[/b] vor sich hin, und kann deshalb auch getrost ignoriert werden. Sie wird hauptsächlich in schön animierten, vorgerenderten Cutscenes erzählt und birgt durch die frechen Sprüche von Styx eine gewisse Spur an Komik.
So kommentiert der grüne Held des Spiels viele Situationen ingame und auch beim eigenen Ableben bekommt man ähnlich wie in den Batmanspielen einen lustigen Spruch um die Ohren gepfeffert. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=954395407

Die Steuerung benötigt zu Beginn etwas Eingewöhnung und sorgt auch noch nach vorangeschrittener Spielzeit immer mal wieder für Situationen, in denen man ungewollt von der Wand abspringt oder einen Vorsprung nicht zu fassen bekommt. Das kann zu einigen frustrierenden Momenten führen, die aber dank der, von mir häufig genutzen, [b]Schnellspeicherfunktion[/b], an Frustpotential verlieren.

Die Aufgaben bestehen meist daraus, [b]Dinge zu stehlen oder Personen zu töten. Hin und wieder will aber auch ein kleineres Rätsel geknackt werden[/b], was das ganze Spielgeschehen deutlich auflockert.
In der Regel haben die Kapitel auch [b]optionale Quests[/b], die bei erfolgreichem Abschluss die verdienten Erfahrungspunkte am Ende in die Höhe treiben.
Diese gewonnenen Punkte kann man entweder nach Abschluss des Levels oder aber im Level, an den spärlich verteilten Werkbänken, in Verbesserung des spitzohrigen Diebes investieren.
Dort wiederum kann man auch eine Fähigkeit freischalten, die ermöglicht, dass Ganze auch jederzeit über das Menü zu tun. Dafür wiederum muss man dann allerdings die entsprechende Kleidung tragen, die sowohl einen Vorteil als auch einen Nachteil mit sich bringt.

Im Spiel gibt es unterschiedliche aber nicht viele verschiedene Kleidungsstücke und Dolche, die man sich über den Talentbaum freischalten muss. Zusätzlich gibt es einen DLC, [i]welcher viel zu teuer ist[/i], der ein weiteres Kostüm sowie einen Dolch freischaltet.
Die verschiedenen Items haben sowohl Vor- als auch Nachteile, die aber leider in allen Fällen sich gegenseitig aufheben, sodass ich das Ende des Spiels mit der Standardkleidung, dem Standarddolch erreicht habe. Grund hierfür war, dass diese keine Vor- aber eben dadurch auch keine gravierenden Nachteile besitzen.

An einer anderen Sorte Werkbank, die sich immer in Reichweite der "Skill-Werkbank" befindet, kann man sich Hilfsmittel herstellen, die ein abwechslungsreiches Vorgehen ermöglichen und dadurch auch die  Abenteuer bzw. Raubzüge erleichtern.
So kann man unter anderem einen Klon an den unterschiedlichsten Stellen spawnen lassen und dessen Körper im Anschluss kontrollieren. Ebenso kann man ihn auch zum Ablenken der Gegner nutzen und durch einen weiteren Tastendruck sogar seine aktuelle Postion aufgeben und an die Stelle des Klons treten. 
Des weiteren kann man [b]Fallen, Heil-/Manatränke, Dietriche oder Wurfmesser und vieles mehr[/b] herstellen. Auch kann man auf seine Reise kleine Säure Behälter mit sich führen, die tote Wachen im Handumdrehen verschwinden lassen, sodass sie von ihren Kollegen nicht gefunden werden können.

Wie man eine Mission abschließt und wie man von A nach B kommt ist in einem gewissem Rahmen einem selbst überlassen.
In der Regel gilt aber, dass man versuchen sollte den direkten Kontakt mit den Wachen zu vermeiden. 
Kommt es doch zu einer Handgreiflichen Auseinandersetzung, in welcher die Wache alles dran setzten wird euch das Lebenslicht auszupusten, gibt es Möglichkeiten aus dieser unangenehmen Situation zu entfliehen.
So kann man mit seinem Dolche zwar [b]keinen[/b] Schwertkampf führen, jedoch mit dem richtigen Timing den Schlag des Gegner parieren und zum Konter ausholen.

Scheitert man oder ist der Gegner zu stark, von diesen gibt es unterschiedliche Versionen, kann man sich für einen Moment unsichtbar machen und aus der Situation entkommen.
Die Unsichtbarkeit hält nur so lange, der „Goldharzkräftebalken“ (Mana) gefüllt ist und lässt sich durch Einnahme von Tränken verlängern.
Sollte man keine Tränke haben oder der Weg bis zur rettenden Mauer zu weit weg sein, kann man sich auch im nächst besten Fass oder Truhe verstecken.
Doch Vorsicht, die Wachen sind klug und untersuchen die Umgebung. So schauen sie in eben jenen Verstecken ebenfalls nach und zerren euch gegebenen Falls ans Tageslicht, um euch dort das schelmische Grinsen aus der grünen Visage zu boxen.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=958333450

Ist die Flucht gelungen, kann man mit Styx, der Altair und Co in fast nichts nachsteht (Kapuze inklusive) in alter Assassins-Creed-Manier an der Wand hochklettern und sich in der Vertikalen, weiter fortbewegen. Außerdem gibt es auch noch Seile an denen geschwungen werden kann und kleine dunkle Schächte durch die man an entlegenste Winkel kommt.

Die recht großen Level sind offen gestaltet und wunderschön designend. Mit einigen Gebieten feiert man im Laufe des Spiels ein Wiedersehen.
Allgemein ist die Grafik völlig in Ordnung, die Unreal Engine 4 entfaltet zwar nicht ihr volles Potential ist aber allemal schön anzusehen.

Nach 16h hat man das Spiel dann beendet und kann die abgeschlossenen Level nach Bedarf wiederholen um in allen Disziplinen eine Goldwertung zu holen.

Ich hatte mit dem Spiel nach kurzer Eingewöhnungsphase großen Spaß und war sehr gut unterhalten.
Wer die früheren [b]Splinter Cell Teile[/b] gespielt und geliebt hat und auch mal gerne eine Situation auf unterschiedliche Art und Weißen angeht bis er ans Ziel kommt, ist mit [b]Styx Shards of Darkness[/b] gut bedient.

 
[h1]Pro:[/h1]

 + Optik
+ Gameplay (nach Eingewöhnung) geht gut von der Hand
+ offene Herangehensweise
+ gute Spielzeit
+ abwechslungsreiche Level (einige Rätsel)


[h1]Con:[/h1]

- unsauberes Klettern an manchen Stellen
- Ressourcen Knappheit
- schon recht schwer bereits auf normaler Schwierigkeit
- Wenig Auswahl bei der Kleidung (Standard die beste)

review: 2 часть шикарного и атмосферного стелса не опозорила честь предшественника, хотя бы тот же кооп, 1 гоблин может вырезать здание набитое стражей, а 2 гоблина еще и обчистят сокровищницу, стадия планирования прохождения уровня теперь необходима как воздух, враги стали умнее, обзавелись слухом и глазами, уровни стали интерактивнее, с коопом это просто экстаз для любителей стелса, крафт остался, но теперь от вещей есть толк, возможность частичной костимизации милого гоблина для игры с параметрами типо: убитый враг растворяется, но при этом нет возможности убить жертву тихо, сюжет самый воровской, как всегда проблемы появляются по пути решения их самих же, требования к умению игрока тоже возросло и надо быть внмательнее не повторяйте моей ошибки, перепутал рычаг от двери, с рычагом вызова охраны(ну бред же), как итог, нас с напарником по темному делу, зажали на балконе, где мы 5 минут насиловали искусственный интеллект, в скайпе же был угар, было весело, ветка прокачки навыков стала разнообразнее из-за перекретсной прокачки навыков и как вишенка на торте сам гоблин, он настолько крут, что без труда ломает 4 стену, после смерти, он рассказывает горе стеллсеру как и куда ему нужно идти, юмор черный как ступни орка. Итог: игра не растеряла тех преимуществ, что были в первом Стиксе, в основном доработка и наладка старого, подтянули графику, гемплей, сюжет интереснее, есть новшества в виде кооператива, внимание к деталям несомненно плюс к новой части.

review:
1. 전작을 플레이해보지 않고 처음 접하는 스틱스
2. 잠입게임으로는 최고봉이었음, 다양한 침입경로 재밌었음
3. 처음에는 자동저장만 사용하다가, 어느 순간부터 길하나만 지나가도 저장을 누르는 나를 발견
4. 점수때문에 전투를 하지 않게 됨, 전투관련 업그레이드가 무슨 의미가 있나 싶었음
5. 마지막 보스전으로 게임이 끝날 줄 몰랐음. 
    나름 스토리 재밌게 즐기고 있었는데 미드 시즌하나가 끝난 기분.
6. 결론적으로 누군가 스틱스에 대해서 물어본다면 누구라도 추천해줄만한 게임.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058706396', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1498005050}
review:
This game was an amazing successor to the first. Stealth was great, the new options to get around were alright, The optional missions were fun, and it cut off the annoying things from the first game *COUGH* Querberus escort *COUGH*. Story was a bit short compared to Master of Shadows but all good. The Enemies were intresting, especially the Dwarves and their annoying smell detection that was a pain. The cheesy death lines were funny in the beginning, but they went dry fast after the 4th time I hear him talk about ordering pizza. All in all, the Goods heavily outweigh the bads.

GG

author: {'steamid': '76561197998282606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1688247639}
review:
You can tell it's a little on the "budget" side of things, especially as far as voice acting for NPCs, some animations and cutscenes are concerned, but it's a really fun game overall. Plus it's not like they are selling it for 60 euros plus 40 euro season pass. A few points real quick:

- It's pure stealth, you can't go postal like in, say, Dishonored, and the combat mechanic is so simplified I just quickloaded the second I got detected every time
- The second half recycles previous levels, which is a little underwhelming, BUT:
- The levels themselves are so utterly dense and rich with opportunities and different approaches that part of me was actually happy to return as I had a feeling I saw only like 10% of them first time round.
- The levels themselves are visually awesome, from a design perspective.
- The main character is basically a goblin Deadpool, shattering the 4th wall every chance he gets. You'll either love it or hate it.

Stealth fans will get their itch scratched by this, go get it so we'll hopefully get an even more refined 3rd game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198008923893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1497381044}
review:
Malgré beaucoup de morts à cause des contrôles parfois capricieux, je recomande fortement ce jeu.

Comparant le jeu à Assassin's Creed, Styx est moins répétitif car il demande plus de skill, offre plus de liberté dans le choix des routes, demande plus d'observation et est beaucoup moins linéaire. Styx est surement un peu plus court, les objectifs secondaire et essayer d'obtenir toutes les medailles d'or ralonge considerablement le temps de jeu.


Fini en difficulté Gobelin (plus haute difficulté avant le mode sans sauvegarde qui était juste trop rageant pour une première partie à cause des points négatifs), j'ai beaucoup aimé l'infiltration, la traque de cibles mais surtout de ne tuer personne et ne pas déclancher d'alarme. La nonchalance de Styx est marrante sans être too much. Les jetons de voleurs est une excellente idée pour les gens souhaitant finir le jeu à 100%, je m'y essayerais probablement un de ces jours.
Je regrette les contrôles plutôt capricieux, la géométrie dans les murs qui transform trop souvent un saut en suicide en nous repoussant et le fait que tous les cristaux étaient protégés par une IA completement bugué qui faisait du surplace (au final un challenge interessant).

L'histoire est peut être trop simple, je dois avouer que je m'en suis vite désinteressé lorsque j'ai réalisé sa simplicité, pour mieux me concentrer sur le gameplay.

Au final, encore un bon jeu par les gars de Cyanide.
Peut être un poil trop cher pour le temps de jeu offert à mon goût, mais dans tous les cas un achat (en promotion) que je ne regrette pas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101280448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1642198104}
review:
Styx is a rare breed for stealth games, it offers a challenge in a genre that has dumbed down for the mainstream. From Thief to Metal Gear Solid, third-person stealth games have become less challenging to cater to everyone, and the AI has decreased in quality. 

Along comes Styx, a fantasy stealth adventure that offers a challenge. You will find no scripted events, boring tailgating missions or magic concealment bushes here. The enemy detection and AI in this game are excellent, guards will search and scour an area if they detect the slightest sound or see a figure lurking in the shadows. The stealth AI reminds me of the early Metal Gear Solid titles where you must use the environment to conceal yourself, hiding bodies and extinguishing sources of light as you sneak. 

The parkour requires timing and precision, people writing negative reviews are used to the Assassin's Creed style of parkour which offers no real challenge except the press of a simple button.

There are weaker parts of Styx, the voice acting and sound can leave something to desire but this is to be expected from a smaller low budget title. Ubisoft and other big budget developers could learn from Styx. Overall, Styx is not a game of the year production but if you are looking for a challenging and stealth adventure reminiscent of stealth games from the past, you can't go wrong with Styx: Shards of Darkness.

review:
Purchased solely for Co-op, and I have only played as the client.
Game is fairly buggy when not hosting - Jumping between platforms or handholds often bugs out with the animation, but puts you on the correct handhold afterwards. Can be very jarring though. Enemies will often turn randomly, glitching up on top of boxes.

It's definitely playable co-op, even through the bugs. I just wish I could throw pocket sand at my friend.

review:

The mechanics are better, grafics, enemies, crafting and level design, but somehow it felt really easy and quick. 

The point is, the game is great, but is not as good as the last one. I recomend it if u are a great fan of stealth games. If you are new to this franchise, I sugest buy the first one and wait this other game here to go in sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205623964', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4796, 'last_played': 1498487077}
review: I enjoyed the game so much. One amazing thing is that you can redistribute skill points whenever you want at the end of each mission and sometime even in the middle of them if you find a "skill table" giving each run an unique approach. The biggest downside of the game is basically that it finish xD, and sadly is too short imo, i made the platinum in a couple of days. Also i didn't find the story so fascinating the reasons who push Styx is just greediness and altough is logical with his personality is not so attractive for a player. The rest is just amazing, poor combat system is meaningless since is created for stealth and in higher difficulty you are even forbidden to parry. Not Being Detected, is just a priority and is fine like that. Save often, learn the locations and then try it in Master difficult where you are forbidden to parry AND save. I REALLY hope that there will be a Styx number 3, 4, 5 and so on forever :))﻿

author: {'steamid': '76561198062674571', 'num_games_owned': 5359, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 1054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1497634200}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p4bFx1_M0GM
Po wydarzeniach z Master of Shadows tytułowy goblin osiedlił się w Thoben, potocznie zwanym miastem złodziei, gdzie trudni się jako jeden z nich. Kradnie dla siebie i, oczywiście nie za darmo, dla innych. Kiedy jedno z tego typu zleceń komplikuje się i niemalże kończy śmiercią Styxa, postanawia on odpłacić się swemu niedoszłemu zabójcy. Podążając za zemstą, dociera do zamieszkiwanego przez Mroczne Elfy Korangaru, gdzie odkrywa przerażający spisek, któremu chcąc nie chcąc, będzie musiał zapobiec. Opowieść jest ogólnie całkiem dobrze napisana i interesująca. Zawodzi jedynie jej nagle urwane zakończenie. W grze można natknąć się na parę nawiązań do Master of Shadows, jednak stanowią one raczej miłe urozmaicenie dla tych, którzy grali w pierwszego Styxa, aniżeli istotny element tutejszej historii.

Najmocniejszym elementem strony fabularnej produkcji jest barwny protagonista. Styxa polubiłem już podczas grania w pierwszą z poświęconych mu gier, jednak to za sprawą Shards of Darkness stał się on jedną z moich ulubionych growych postaci. Goblin co chwilę raczy nas spostrzeżeniami na temat innych bohaterów, otoczenia, a, gdy umrze, nawet tego jak gramy. Styksowe teksty często są obraźliwe, jednak ciężko odmówić im trafności oraz poczucia humoru, a słuchając ich, nie sposób się nie uśmiechnąć. Zielony w swoich wypowiedziach często nawiązuje też do innych gier czy filmów, co tylko dodaje im smaku.

Gra podzielona została na 9 misji, które rozgrywają się na osobnych, rozbudowanych poziomach i pozostawiają nam dużo swobody w tym, jak je przejdziemy. Wprawdzie jest to nieco inny rodzaj swobody niż np. w takim Dishonored, które równie dobrze mogliśmy traktować jak grę akcji. Styx to skradanka pełną gębą, chociaż i tak stwarza graczowi spore pole do popisu. Samo skradanie bazuje na niezłym modelu wspinaczki i działającym systemie osłon, oraz szerokim wachlarzu umiejętności bohatera. Goblin to urodzony zabójca. Wprawnie eliminuje wrogów, czy to sztyletem, czy za pomocą pułapek. Aczkolwiek grę da się też przejść praktycznie bez przelewania krwi strażników. Nie brakuje tu narzędzi ułatwiających ciche przemykanie między nimi, poczynając od szklanych przedmiotów rzucanych dla odwrócenia ich uwagi, poprzez piaskowe kule do gaszenia pochodni i kończąc na żywicznej magii, pozwalającej Styxowi stawać się niewidzialnym oraz tworzyć swoje nieco wybrakowane klony, by następnie zmusić je do wykonania brudnej roboty. 

Wzorem pierwszej części, możemy rozwijać drzewko umiejętności protagonisty i tym samym nauczyć go m. in. cichszego poruszania się, wyczuwania istotnych przedmiotów czy paru nowych sztuczek związanych z mocą żywicy. Co ciekawe, zakupione ulepszenia da się pomiędzy misjami zwracać za pełną ich wartość. Jeśli więc dany styl gry przestanie nam odpowiadać, bez większych przeszkód możemy się przekwalifikować na inny.

Nie można nie wspomnieć także o wyśmienitych projektach lokacji, które naprawdę robią wrażenie otwartością. Są rozległe, i to zarówno w poziomie jak i pionie. Praktycznie do każdego budynku czy pomieszczenia do się wejść, i to na wiele sposobów, przez okno, ukryte przejście, dziurę w ścianie lub dachu albo drzwiami. Co prawda da się dostrzec w grze pewną liniowość, ostatecznie i tak odwiedzamy kolejne wyznaczone punkty na mapie, lecz ścieżek pomiędzy nimi jest tak dużo, że absolutnie nie czujemy się prowadzeni za rękę.

Co więcej, prawie w każdym pomieszczeniu możemy coś znaleźć. Przeważnie tym czymś są jedynie surowce potrzebne do wytwarzania mikstur leczniczych oraz innych przedmiotów zużywalnych. Jednak w grze nie brakuje również nieźle wykonanych zadań pobocznych, z których część musimy sami aktywować, np. podsłuchując rozmowę innych postaci. Za ich wykonywanie otrzymujemy głównie punkty umiejętności, choć w kilku przypadkach możemy zostać nagrodzeni nową bronią lub strojem dla Styxa. Alternatywnych elementów wyposażenia jest zaledwie kilka i ciężko powiedzieć, że są one jednoznacznie lepsze od podstawowego rynsztunku. Zwiększają jedne atrybuty bohatera kosztem obniżenia innych. Ale odpowiednio dobrane do stylu gry potrafią być użyteczne. 

Gra wydała mi się nieco prostsza od pierwszej części goblińskiej sagi. W Master of Shadows co chwilę brakowało żywicznej many i momentami musiałem kombinować, jak odwrócić uwagę strażników, by przekraść się między nimi bez korzystania z niewidzialności. Tutaj dzięki craftingowi nie trzeba się aż tak martwić o zapas żywicy, a liczniejsze alternatywne ścieżki ułatwiają omijanie przeciwników. Zaś walka wręcz, wprawdzie dalej nie pozwalająca na zbyt wiele, nie blokuje jak w jedynce kamery na najbliższym wrogu i daje możliwość ucieczki. I przyznam, że taki stan rzeczy mi odpowiada. Pozwala graczowi na nieco śmielsze oraz swobodniejsze działanie, a przy tym nie czyni gry zbyt prostą. Ciągle całkiem łatwo tu umrzeć, nie zachowując należytej ostrożności, a częste save'owanie jest na porządku dziennym.

Tytuł jest też krótszy od prequelu, co już mi się tak nie podoba. Grałem na normalu, bez pośpiechu, eksplorując lokacje, i na ukończenie wszystkich poziomów potrzebowałem dwunastu godzin. To nie jest mało, zwłaszcza że możemy powtarzać misje oraz zdobywać specjalne odznaki m. in. za przechodzenie ich w wyznaczonym czasie lub bez wywołania alarmu. Tylko w pierwszego Styxa przy takim samym podejściu grałem półtora raza tyle, więc czuję pewien niedosyt. Szczególnie, że w drugiej połowie gry fabuła wysyła nas do odwiedzonych już wcześniej lokacji. I fakt, skradanie działa na nich cały czas tak samo dobrze, a niektóre z nich potrafią nawet zaskoczyć paroma nowymi miejscówkami, ale niedosyt pozostaje.

Co gorsza, backtracking nie jest jedynym mankamentem, który tytuł odziedziczył po swoim poprzedniku. Wciąż da się tu napotkać pomniejsze niedoróbki mechaniczne. Styxowi zdarza się skoczyć nie tam, gdzie powinien, a kamera potrafi uciec na bok, podczas poruszania się po krawędzi. I nadal brakuje mi jakichś zależności między różnymi rodzajami NPC-ów. Jednym z nich są krasnoludy potrafiące wyczuć woń zielonoskórego, nie widząc go. Tylko dlaczego umieją to zrobić w pomieszczeniu wypełnionym innymi goblinami, które powinny chyba maskować zapach bohatera? Innym razem napotkamy grzyby wybuchające, gdy się do nich zbliżymy, które na postacie niezależne już nie reagują. Tak właściwie są to jedynie szczegóły niewpływające na gameplay, ale powodują poczucie niesprawiedliwości i wrażenie, że cały świat jest przeciwko graczowi.

Dzięki wyższemu budżetowi wiele zyskała oprawa wizualna tytułu. Pod tym względem prezentuje się on o niebo lepiej niż pierwszy Styx i w końcu wygląda jak gra współczesna. Przywodząca na myśl tolkienowskie klimaty szata graficzna jest naprawdę ładna, chociaż do poziomu produkcji AAA wyraźnie brakuje.

Na koniec kilka słów kooperacji. Całą styksową kampanię możemy przechodzić w dwie osoby, co jest miłą atrakcją, ale niczym więcej. Mamy do czynienia z produkcją typowo singlową, nie stworzoną z myślą o współpracy. Niezależnie czy działamy sami, czy z kimś, gra się w to z grubsza tak samo. Co więcej mówimy o skradance, dwa gobliny to dwa razy większe szanse na wykrycie. Nie twierdzę, że w Styxa nie warto grać w coopie. Jakbym miał z kim, to pewnie sam bym go tak przechodził, bo to zawsze dodatkowa dawka wrażeń. Ale nie jest to tryb, dla którego warto by było kupić ten tytuł.

Podsumowując, Styx: Shards of Darkness to lepsza i ładniejsza wersja skradanki w goblińskim wydaniu. Ty samym jest to jedna z najciekawszych gier tego typu, jakie ukazały na przestrzeni ostatnich lat. Szeroki wachlarz umiejętności Styxa i rozbudowane poziomy sprawiają, że skradanie jest tu bardzo kompleksowe, a dodatkowo charakteru nadaje mu świetnie zarysowany protagonista. Szkoda tylko, że produkcja jest wyraźnie krótsza od pierwowzoru, a także powiela jego błędy, takie jak backtracking i pomniejsze niedoróbki. Niemniej jednak z czystym sumieniem mogę ten tytuł polecić wszystkim amatorom gatunku.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991323744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1465, 'last_played': 1498365627}
review:
Styx is a fairly interesting stealth game. It has flaws but overall it is quite fun. Lets start with the bad, because that list is short. 

Cons:

1) Vision in this game is weird. Although most of the time you won't notice it, there are times when you'll think to yourself "this guy has to be blind not to see me" and this isn't fixed by upping the difficulty. Vision cones are tiny and short, so styx can move around fairly easy. If you extended and widened these cones proper then the game would be impossible. Styx doesn't have the tools to move around if humans/elves could see normal. This is a hiccup that you have to accept, to be honest. 

2) The storyline is loose. Styx takes a job for 10 viles of amber, but gets caught out by a shapeshifting elf and decides to hunt down this elf and kill him. Later you work with that elf so.. well I'll be honest, im half way through and it really feels like the narrative is following the premise that styx is rolling with the punches and instead of just cutting his losses and going home, he keeps doubling down and pushing further. This is fine, but the dialog doesn't REALLY support this. A lot of what you do as you play is by virtue alone and Styx isn't exactly a "steve rogers" kind of character. All in all, this feels like less of an epic tale and more of just another day for Styx. Although that sentiment is debatible it is the best I can come up with. Just like the previous con, you kind of have to learn to live with it. It's a detail that is easy to forget by most so, take it as you will. 

3) The load screen after you die (aka, the 4th wall break) gets very old very fast. Not much more to say about that. If you don't die you never see it. 

Now for the good stuff. 

PROS:

1) Styx as a character is very compelling in this sequel. Although the character is presented really well in the first title, you really get to know Styx deeper in this game. He is kind of an addict, it feels like. At least that is what feels like his primary motivation. He takes the 1st mission because he wants more amber and is offered a decent sized stash. He then finds Quartz (a more powerful substance) and after seeing it in action is instantly dedicated to hoarding it. This reminds me of a drug user who goes from coke to meth. Styx chaces a high in a way that is less self destructive than a real life drug addict, but in a way that clearly shows his priority. Styx is like a Dragon lusting for gold. He doesn't need it but is more than content to dedicating all of his time amassing a mountain of the stuff and sitting on top of it. That is a fairly interesting motivator for such an anti-hero type character. Like I said, Styx is no Captain America and doesn't do good for the sake of good itself. He does it because it gets him amber, but more importantly, kind of stumbles into doing good while trying to get the amber. Some characters are clumbsy and ruin everything they touch, Styx seems to very accidentially be a hero while lusting for Amber/quartz. It is a fun trait. 

2) Controls in this game feel pretty damn good. On a few times have I jumped to a ledge and somehow missed the jump and fell to my death. 99% of the time the character performs how I expect him to. This is critical when you are dealing with a game that has a ton of platforming and ledge jumping. MANY of games mess this stuff up and for the most part styx nails it. 

3) Lore in this game is really quite intriguing. In this world there are essentially 3 intelligent races: Humans, Elves & Dwarves. All goblins are crappy clones of Styx from the first game and they are kind of everywhere causing havok. This means no goblin society of goblin women/families. Just stupid clones of styx causing havok all over. The Humans, elves and dwarves are actually all working together to somehow stop the "green plague" of goblins running around stealing and destroying stuff. Styx himself doesn't give a shit about his clones...well ok he gives one or two shits, but no more than that! 

4) Enemies in this game are well diversed. As far as a stealth game goes this title hits upon the 3 senses that you can use to detect Styx. Humans/elves have good vision but are essentially nose blind. Roabies are these huge roach type bugs that are completely blind but have extremely good hearing. And lastly dwarves have decent sight but extremely good senses of smell. How this breaks down is easy: A human/elf needs to face you to detect you. A Roabie needs you to make noise within it's radius to detect you and lastly Dwarves just need to be close enough to you regardless of anything else to be able to smell you. This means you can move faster past human/elves. You need to move extremely slow near Roabies and you just need to stay away from Dwarves. This is more than other stealth games offer and it implemented fairly solid. 

5) Styx has an extremely extensive toolkit for dealing with threats. If you want to kill enemies you have tons of traps, weapons, poisons/acids to deal with them. If you wish to not kill anything yourself the game also gives you a ton of options to achieve this, even in missions where you are SUPPOSED to kill someone. The game will give you a (more complex) route to get someone else to kill the target so there is no blood on your hands. This is pretty damn satisfying if you ask me. It allows you to play the game AT LEAST twice with a full kill and no kill playthrough. 

6) Levels in this game nearly always have a dozen different paths you can follow to reach the end. You can go high, go low or anyplace inbetween. The game leaves you with enough options that when you play through it seems to just flow. You only notice that the way you've been going isn't the only way when you reach a spot that is just too tricky to pass so you backtrack a little and lo and behold...there is a completely different route you didn't notice before. Sometimes you'll be amazed at how much easier the game is if you take time to really look around and find the easiest path, but you usually go with what feels best in the moment. 

7) Without going into too much detail (this is already fairly long of a review) this sequel takes a lot of the things from the original game that worked and left them unchanged. It then took a lot of things that didn't work and improved them. This game feels really good to play and the only thing that bums me out is the game tells me my progress % for each save so I know i've only got 30% left to go. Its a bummer because you want it to go on forever. That said at the time of this review I'm only half way through the game and I've already sunk in at least 20-30 hours. Im not rushing but I am moving swiftly through the maps too. Game just has a lot of content. 

I could probably go on more but I'll leave this as is. As a stealth game goes Styx presents the genre well, even if having a few flaws here and there. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes stealth games. Most importantly though.. don't start with this title. Play the first game and then play this. This game really feels like a continuation to the original game and frankly may not make complete sense if you didn't play the first. Graphics in the first game are still really tolerable compared to modern games so it is worth a play through. Play them both, they are both great games.

edit:

I just finished the game and I have 1 complaint. The ending leaves you wanting. The final boss battle is challenging and you are finally given the opportunity to get your last shard of pure quartz to obtain your "ultimate" ability... but you can't activate the ability until after the fight in which...the game is over. So you collect these pure quartz just to be able to go back and replay it all? Come on... this needs some DLC so you can actually use this stuff that you've been working to unlock. Or you should be able to complete this ultimate ability BEFORE the final fight.

That said, all in all it was still a damn good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028379601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 980, 'last_played': 1497557889}
review:
When you thought stealth games genre has died out and the best gaming industry can do is medicore casual "hiding" games ending in bloodbath after 2nd failed try, Cyanide Studio manages to stay true to classic stealth shenanigans.

Mechanic is simple and effective, strict but fair. No bugs here- no spotting through walls or 6th sense. Although dwarfs can sniff you in later levels it is designed in much better way than elven smell in the prequel. You also get a light and sound markers giving you feedback on your exposition and noise making allowing in much better view of your exposition.

You have much more skills at your disposal accompanied with more gadgets to help you lurk around allowing you to adjust your gameplay to your likings. You can lay waste to many enemies in various different ways as long as you remain undetected. When your cover is blown you have little means of fighting back and the best chance is to run so no superhero endless parry nonsense here.

Styx is egoistical and cynical and is not short in cracking wise. He has good amount of humor and swears are in perfect amount. I really detest recent trends of determining coolness of the character by putting as many curses as possible in one line.

Level design is literally mind-blowing. One level alone has more revisit value than most of the whole games of competitors. Also bigger budget is showing and all short backs of the prequel are polished and improved. Climbing is repaired, no clinks, no bugs. Really solid performance.

It is the best stealth focused game right now not because it lacks competition (although it does) but it is a piece of solid work with good focus and involving game-flow with no annoying technical cracks that usually these games suffer from.

P.S. Hideout theme from Master of Shadows has a comeback so now you have to buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147633197', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1840, 'last_played': 1561881418}
review:
Wow!. Warnung vorweg, wer nicht an einen Stealth Spiel interessiert ist und lieber alle Wachen niedermetztelt, soll sich ein anderes Spiel suchen. Styx: SoD ist wie der Vorgänger ein reines Schleich Spiel.

Jetzt zum eigentlichen Review
Styx schleicht sich diesmal durch die Dunkelelfenstadt Korrangar und Umgebung. Dunkel ist dabei wahrscheinlich auf das Leveldesign zurückzuführen, den helle, lichtdurchflutete, offene Szenarien wie in Akanash gibt es in SoD nicht.(Ok, die Flugschiffe und Wildoran kommen ziemlich nahe, dafür fehlt mir dann die vertikale Richtung etwas). Die Level wurde allerdings mit viel Liebe um Detail entworfen und die Möglichkeiten , sie zu bewältigen sind geradezu unbegrenzt. DIe Story ist linear, ein Punkt für zur nächsten und letztendlich zum (mal wieder) offenen Ende.

Wie im Vorgänger ist Styx ein kompletter Versager im Kampf. Unser zynischer Goblinfreund tötet Gegner lieber aus dem Hinterhatlt oder mit Fallen. Das ist aber sogar förderlich, weil man dazu zu mehr Aufmerksamkeit gezwungen wird. Die Möglichkeit, wie in anderen "Stealth" Spielen, einfach sämtliche Wachen eine Levels umzulegen, bloss weil man erwischt wurde, fällt damit weg. Dafür hat Styx mehrere Fähigkeiten, wie Unsichtbarkeit oder die Möglichkeit einen Klon zu erschaffen. Beides steht nicht unbegrenzt zur Verfügung, kann aber, wenn gezielt eingesetzt, einem das ganze deutlich erleichtern.

Wie sein Vorgänger Master of Shadows, ist SoD ein ziemlich unterbewertetes Spiel. Wer Splinter Cell. Hitman und Thief mag, wird mit diesem Spiel auf jeden Fall seine Freunde haben (Ausser, man hat einen lauten Spielstill, in diesem Fall kann ich nur eins sagen: "Raus aus meinem Review") Styx bringt mich mit seinen Kommentar im Grunde immer zum Lachen und die Atmosphäre des Spiel ist einfach wunderbar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104031648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1502062559}
review: An excellent stealth game, supposedly similar to its predecessor Master of Shadows (which I never played), but also to the Thief series in dynamics in my opinion. Quite a challenge, but rewarding, relying entirely on staying hidden through various innovative techniques such as producing a dispensable clone diversion and (temporary) invisibility by consuming amber, the addictive substance at the centre of gameplay. The game is full of hilarious references and very British wise-cracks, puzzle solving and numerous reloads once being spotted in my own vain attempt to get gold insignias on every mission (you are rewarded for swiftness, mercy and staying hidden). The only negative is that these reloads can be far too frequent, and sometimes are seemingly not through my own fault as a jump which seems to be going to a rock actually leads you flying off into nothingness. I also strongly suggest you turn off the death cut-scene line ASAP. This did not detract from the immersion of gameplay for me however, and as a fan of the stealth genre, but one who is reluctant to spend money on games, I fully recommend Styx as your thieving alter-ego. At least get the free demo and give it a try; that's what I did and it sold me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042467215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1497267457}
review:
6/10 Styx: Shards of Darkness is a game that is good and bad at the same time. This review will be spoiler free. I have not played the first game so i'm only basing my review on what i saw on the two and will not be comparing it with the first instalment. 

Pro:
Nice stealth mechanics (obvious for a stealth game) i love that you can see how hidden you are on the knife. You can hide in all sorts of places. I played my playthrough on hard cause we thought normal might be too easy and oh boy was it hard.  the main character is amasing you will love him and his jokes some are really clever and some are so edgy and bad you will love it. Animation are good but not great the game runs fine and the graphics are neat. Co-op works great and the level design look amasing with a lot of different routes you can take. however even though I LOVE the game it's not perfect. There's a skill tree that makes the game easier by getting skills these skill points are well balanced so you dont get everything at once or after 3-4 missions i like the pace.

Con: 
There are only about 13 types of enemies including non-humanoids. Also the ai is not great sometimes gaurds would just not de agro on us and keep resseting to max awareness for no reason ringing the alarm over and over and not calming down like they should. We did stumble on a few glitches like the restarting on the other side of a locked door that you had to open and not being to open it again. objectives being killed but not counting and general buggyness. MAJOR complaint is that the enemies are just way too much! You can get medals for not killing any one but on some levels it's just no option to kill any way because then 30+ get aggrod in a small area also they make it really hard to kill any one placing gaurds in heavy armour you can't kill or enemies that can ''smell'' you through walls wich makes the stealth aspect kinda pointless because you can't kill any one or hide. This might just be because i played on hard. Hiding is useless when the gaurds are searching they will just b-line towards you and the check the hiding space your in. Also the parkour is sup-par it doesn't always do what you want it to do like grabind a wall when you want to run. MANA or in this case your amber is way too low. you can get skills that help you but you can barely use any of your skills much or craft gear since the reagents are plenty full in the beginning of the game but get rarer as time goes by.

CONCLUTION: Styx: Shards of Darkness
Is a good but not great game if they change the amount of amber you have earlier on it might be more fun and reduce the amount of gaurds and unkillable gaurds it would work. The story is good nothing really special some fun characters. I would give this game a 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198062210310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 888, 'last_played': 1583789956}
review: Styx is simply a hidden gem. I've had a tremendous amount of fun with Styx Master of Shadows so I bought this one as well. In my opinion a lot of issues have been addressed from the first game and Styx Shards of Darkness is a great improvement. There's something so special and unique about how this game feels. I can play for hours and it does not get boring. Good story, amazing graphics and environment and a demanding stealth game overall. Of course there are still minor issues that need fixes or things that could be improved but I believe this game is so underrated. And I can always go back and re-play missions and I can still find different ways to do them each time. If you're looking for an action-stealth game or stuff like Assassin's Creed, then this game is not for you. However, if you are patient, like exploring and being sneaky, then I definitely recommend it. It's worth it.

review:
Styx ist ein echt cooles Spiel. Es ist Spielerisch eine Mischung aus Thief, Hitman und den Schleichpassagen von Shadow of Mordor. Grafisch sieht das Spiel einfach erste Sahne aus und sein Vorgänger glänzte bereits mit einer guten Story. Es erwarten einen eine menge Nebenquest und Upgrademöglichkeiten für den eigenen Charakter. Die Atmosphäre von Shadow of Mordor beschreibt dieses viel bietende Spiel meiner Meinung nach am bestenl.
Am besten selber reinschauen und sich ein eigenes Bild machen.

review: Styx himself can be a bit of an annoying character at times mainly because his wise cracking comments are hit or miss. That aside the gameplay is rock solid and extremly fun if your a fan of stealth games, apprectiate how it does not forgive your mistakes and you feel like it's your fault and not a relult of some glitch or unfair AI. The quick save feature is a lifesaver and saves a heck of alot of trouble. The levels themselves are expertly crafted with so much freedom in how you want to tackle the objectives. I do wish there was more enemy variety but to me that's not that big a deal considering how excellent the gameplay is. 9/10 in my book. Can't wait for the next game considering Cyanide studios has proven their ability to refine their stealth forumla, in the way of keeping good mechanics while evolving and trying something new where it counts/fits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072048439', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1498756672}
review:
Здраствуй «гамер» увидел красивые картинки и кучу отзывов положительных о 2 части, не покупай ее за 2000,купи по скидону, ведь вторая часть вышла пресной и слишком легкой.
-Игре не хватает регионального скидона, раньше у 1 части он был.
-В 1 части Нас мотивировали  достижениями (Во время задания не должно быть обнаружено ни одного трупа, Убить не менее двух врагов, уронив на них люстру, и т.д.) теперь мотивации х*уль, достижения не интересные.
-В первой части монетки(для ранга Вор) раньше были так запрятаны, на краю карты, часто в гнезде птицы, в канализации, в «жопе мира», искать их было сложно и интересно, а когда проходил целый час или 2 часа «твоей тупости», ты лез на ютюб смотреть, где сука, она лежит. Теперь они раскиданы везде, на самом видном месте, упростили эту часть гемплея 8(
-В первом стиксе, эльфы чуяли на расстоянии, подойти было нельзя, всех приходилось обходить, а убивать нужно было внезапно и быстро, теперь походу Стикс вывалялся в коровьем дерьме, эльфы его не чуют, ходи где хочу, убивай кого хочешь.
Но чуют гномы! Но ты выпил нанотехнологичныйэлексир и вуаля, гномье обаянье скатилось к х*уям.
-Раньше на начальных этапах в первой части, бутылка с кислотой была на вес золота, в любой момент нпс мог войти в комнату, теперь тебе доступны целый бочки с кислотой, свистнул 2 раза, подманил 2-3 стражников, скинул на них бочку, ни трупом не следов. Все просто(изи катка)
-НПС слепые


Единственное, что сделали сложнее - «шанс блока» теперь он доступен на первых двух сложностях, на остальных, нпс тебя сразу убивают с 1 удара, раньше на самой высокой сложности можно было поставить блок и с помощью ловких пальцев убить «палача». 
Заключение злоключение: Вытягивает эту тонну говна, только ХАРИЗМА Стикса ибо она еб*ена медь, непробиваема как бетонная плита. Покупать только фанам. Но я «лайкну» игру за первую часть, да это посудно!

review:
游戏打折！买买买！
安装完了，好兴奋，进游戏！哎哟不错哦，开始教学关。
教学关到一半，崩溃。
重新进游戏，嗯，按任意键那界面加载存档无限读硬盘。
开始尝试官方的解决方案。
检验游戏完整性，好的！无限读硬盘。
重装MICROSOFT DIRECTX，好的！无限读硬盘。
重装MICROSOFT VISUAL C ++，没问题！无限读硬盘。
进入兼容模式用管理员模式访问，没问题！无限读硬盘。
更新最新的显卡驱动（我的是N卡），小意思！加载存档界面崩溃。
1234再来一次！加载存档界面崩溃。
加载存档界面崩溃。
加载存档界面崩溃。
我有一句MMP不知当讲不当讲，我是很喜欢潜行类游戏，这游戏也是观望了很久看到今天打折了果断入手的，你就这样对待我的一片真心？
游戏时间1.4小时，有超过1.3小时是在重复尝试解决办法。
游戏是好游戏，可惜不能玩，已经申请退款。

author: {'steamid': '76561198098051447', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1497014545}
review:
>Saw that it was on sale
>Notices there's a demo available
>Download the Demo and play it
>Absolutely start loving the game, didn't know this game was so much fun.
>Instantly bought the game for €24,- on sale
>Now addicted to the game

Now for the real criticism/review:
The game is build on the UE4 engine, so the lighting is already very good.
Sometimes you will notice some low res textures, but atleast the game is optimised and doesn't run poorly.
Some animation are a bit funky too, like rope climbing...... But since the main character you're playing is already a small goblin that talks funny, it's not a complete turn off and sort of makes it funny.

It's a game that highly focusses on stealth, the combat in it is ofcourse pretty bad due to the fact that there is none. If you're detected you can parry an attack which stunns the attacker for a moment, giving you the opportunity to kill them.
However since the AI is not so stupid, they will probably have heard it an about two more guys will come at you killing you. you also die in about two hits, so you really want to avoid combat.
Which is good because it pushes you to really be stealthy, and when you fuck up it's best to just reload a previous save.

The maps are very open and diverse with lots of patrolling enemies and ''loot'' scattered around. There are also side missions that you can do, doing these will give you extra points. And with those points you are able to upgrade your skills with. 
The skills are not only upgrades to your already existing abilities (which are cloning yourself and invisibility), but also gives you new ways to go about your playstyle.
For example a skill that let's you craft new items, execute enemies in new ways, ability to craft on the fly etc.
There are about 5 skill trees if i'm not mistaken, and at the end of each skill tree there's a special skill which requires ''Pure quartz"to unlock, which are ofcourse more rare than your regular skill points.

Since this is my first Styx game i'm not that very interested in the story and the story isn't all too interesting here either. But the main character is not a stupid character but actually quite clever and smart, which makes dialogue and cutscenes more interesting and fun to watch/hear.

So what will you do mostly in this game:
Climb walls like some assassin mofo,
Kill lots of people or kill no one,
Finish missions to gain points and unlock new skills,
Collect crafting materials and craft items/gadgets,
You will also reload previous save files a lot....


In all seriousness i give this game a 7,5/10

The gameplay is solid and fun, it has everything a stealth game needs.
The game knows it's own identity and the devs never stray away from the core of the game or the identity of the game.
Meaning there's no middle-ground but just a solid stealth experience.
There is replay value to keep you going, and the game will give you a challenge early on (haven't finished it yet so can't tell about end-game stuff).
The game lacks a bit in terms of some art categories, like some low quality textures, or the lip-sync of styx is sometimes a bit non-existent.
Sometimes the patrolling guards are a bit off course aswell, making them do weird stuff when turning or bumping into other meshes.
Haven't encountered any bugs yet and runs great on my PC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014832940', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1802, 'last_played': 1705900786}
review: Styx is a goblin. He's a no good, foul mouthed thief who only cares about two things: Treasure, and that precious, precious amber. Styx has so deal with dwarves, elves, humans, giant insects, and the occasional troll in pursuit of his interests. The game is a stealth action/infiltration game where you go sneaking around knifing humans, strangling elves, and stealing gold and other artifacts. You can vomit up a pile of flesh that turns into a clone of yourself that you can control. You can hide under tables, in closets, in baskets, and everywhere else a creature your size can fit. I was a big fan of the original Styx:Master of Shadows game, and stealth action games in general. I loved how Styx could basically go everywhere and do a lot of special magic, and in this latest installment, they improved this great formula by introducing a skill tree system. The cut scenes in the original were done using animated painted textures, and in this game, the cut scenes are either realtime or pre-rendered. I would have been happy with either, and they lend to the great storytelling in the Styx universe.  The story has you infiltrating huge sandbox environments. The sound and music was top notch. The voice acting was very well done as well. Whenever you die, Styx taunts you with these witty insults like "I won't tell anyone if you turn the difficulty down!" or my personal favorite, "Be skilled, or not be skilled. That is the question. and fuck you is the answer!" This is a game that despite not taking itself seriously, is a game worthy of triple A status! After I was burned by pre-ordering Aliens: Colonial Marines, I vowed never to pre-order a videogame again until after reviews came out. Now granted, that was a different game company, but it goes to show you that one aweful game can shit up the pool enough to sour a person's taste for games. Styx: Shards of Darkness restored my faith in game developers in general, and I can say that if this franchise makes it to Styx 3, I will definitely be pre-ordering it.  I would definitely recommend this game to any fans of third person games, or stealth action games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025798175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1496434414}
review:
Ein gutes Spiel für alle hardcore Stealth Fans, die auch bei der 1000 Wache noch brav abwarten können, um im perfekten Moment vorbeizuhuschen und dazu am besten jeden Level mehrmals für Highscores spielen.
Wer allerdings spielerische Varianz sucht, oder gerne mal die Geduld verliert, wird hier nicht lange Spaß haben.

Mir war es am Ende einfach zu monoton, im Prinzip bin ich die ganze Zeit durch dunkle Korridore (in durchaus hübschen Leveln) geschlichen und geklettert und habe alle paar Meter schnellgespeichert, oder es recht schnell bereut wenn nicht.
Die Skills könnten für dringend nötige Abwechslung sorgen, wären sie nicht so teuer und damit zu wertvoll, um sie bei jedem beliebigen Gegner zu verschleudern. So stellt sich schnell die alte RPG-Krankheit ein und anstatt zu experimentieren, hortet man krampfhaft die wertvollen Ressourcen.
Gepaart mit einigen frustigen Stellen, hat die ewige Schleichtretmühle den Spielspaß immer mehr untergraben, als nicht-diehard Fan des Genres bietet mir Styx insgesamt einfach zu wenig, um mich wirklich abzuholen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989746934', 'num_games_owned': 476, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1495645638}
review:
Un jeu sympathique mais qui souffre de 2 énormes soucis
- Les contrôles sont d'une imprécision digne du livre des records, que ça soit au clavier ou à la manette, ça gâche complètement le plaisir de jeu.
- Passé les 2 1er niveaux on s’ennuie sévère, il devrait y avoir des alternatives à l'infiltration comme le fait Dishonored. La on fait juste la même chose encore et encore jusqu'a la fin, les "combats" de boss sont risibles tant il sont nuls et sans intérêt.

et un moins critique :
- L'absence de doublage FR alors que le jeu est développé par un studio [b]FRANCAIS[/b] !!!

Bref, un jeu moyen qui essai de surfer sur la vague mourante du succès du précédent opus, lui même tentant de glaner l'aura de l'éxcellent [b]Of Orcs and Men[/b] qui lui au moins le bon goût d'être doublé en français !!

Ceux qui ont aimés master of Shadows apprécieront surement celui la mais ses défauts, datant du précédent opus, sont moins pardonnable cette fois-ci, je ne peut décemment pas recommander ce jeu sans faire preuve de mauvaise fois...

author: {'steamid': '76561197991808695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1188, 'last_played': 1496632504}
review:
I think I like the first one better.  It was easier to get spotted, but they also didnt notice you as quickly, if that makes sense?  So you were more on edge as you slinked around the map, while here... it feels like the NPC's are completely incompetent, which is quite immersion breaking, when your dealing with ELVES, elves are not stupid and obvlivious... but all in all, its pretty, its more of Styx... even though they decided to go for a whole Deadpool tweak to his personality which feels as disingenious as it sounds... it comes across as cute or funny as many times as it does idiotic and painful... its still not enough to make me hate the story, which so far has been great.  Some minor complaints about Styx's motivation in the early game being pretty garbage, and a missed opertunity to form any real character building between him and the big giant strong chick (Which at this point is mandatory in games?)  but alas...

Still a good game, though not quite as good as the first.

review:
Phenomenal sequel that improves upon the already great first game in nearly every way.  Controls are tighter, new abilities and gadgets are fun and useful, the story is stronger, and the levels are just as gorgeous and dense as ever.  Enemy AI suffers from the occasional pathing hiccup while patrolling but that's only a minor setback.  

This is a stealth game built for stealth fans, can't recommend it hard enough!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995165612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1498345947}
review:
I bought this game for its co-op and because I played and really enjoyed the previous title. This review is from the point of view of player 2.

It lags to the point where it becomes very hard to play. It loses your progress which then makes it very difficult to re-synchronize with your co-op-mate. The game menus are horribly designed. Player 2 often can't see objectives on the HUD for whatever reason. There's the occasional visual glitch with NPCs shown stuck between floors (though nothing of the sort is displayed on player 1's view). The story isn't as good as its predecessor's (at least up to the point where I could stomach playing it - right after it randomly lost my profile). Also the skill trees are bad in this game.

Lastly, Styx is really annoying in this game. In the previous game he was comedic and the humor was very dark. In this game they're just trying too hard. It's disappointing. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198017500036', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3351, 'last_played': 1639065271}
review:
[h1]Vorwort[/h1]
Habe das Spiel mit einem Kollegen komplett im Multiplayer und danach die einzelnen Missionen nachträglich alleine durchgespielt. Alle 38 Achievements gehören mir und somit bin ich zu 100%. Ich hatte für knappe 30€ also 55 Stunden Spielspaß.

[h1]Pros/Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*] Multiplayer; durch das Klonen war es eine gute Erweiterung, dass Styx endlich einen eigenen [i]intelligenten Klon[/i] erstellen kann, der von einem Mitspieler gemimt wird.
[*] einige Einblick in andere Rassen; nun gibt es auch Dunkelelfen und Zwerge!
[*] Bugs; ja, denn diese sind hier meistens eher lustig. Ich hatte keine wirklich störende Glitches oder Bugs, sondern eher die lustigen. Bei der letzten Mission fehlte einmal ein gewisser Sichtradius und einmal fehlten alle Missionsanzeigen, was aber beim Neuladen wieder verschwand
[*] Wiederverwertung von Levels; an sich finde ich es immer gut, wenn man bekannte Orte mal wieder besucht, um nicht einfach ein Level nach dem anderen vorgetischt zu bekommen. Jedoch hat es auch seine Con-Seite.
[*] Fähigkeiten und Ausrüstung; die Fähigkeiten sind sehr cool und es macht Spaß, einige Kombinationen ausprobieren. Zum Beispiel Unsichtbarkeitsmantel, Heranspringen und Goldharzdolch, schon kann man Massen an ungerüsteten Gegnern niedermähen ohne entdeckt zu werden; oder Rauchiger Tod und Suizidklon, einfach mit dem Klon hinrennen, anspringen, explodieren und alle Zeugen als Styx im Rauch umbringen.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*] Spielstandauswahl beim Multiplayer; bis heute nicht verstanden. Es werden zig Spielstände angezeigt, aber man weiß nie, was für Werte der Goblin im Spielstand hat. Hier wäre eine Ansicht mit den Fähigkeitenbäumen und dem Inventar sehr, sehr hilfreich.
[*] Halbierte Lebenspunkte im Multiplayer; die Mechanik verstand ich nur bedingt, warum ein [i]intelligenter Klon[/i] die Hälfte an Lebenspunkten kostet. Lebenspunkte sind eh nicht wirklich sinnvoll, da ein Schwertschlag recht viel abzieht.
[*] viele "unsterbliche" Gegner; Höhlentrolle oder Gepanzerte, zum Schluss hin findet man viele Gegner, die man entweder nur mit der Umgebung oder Fallen töten kann. Hier fiehlt mir die Möglichkeit, sie irgendwie zu schwächen und dann mit dem Dolch umzubringen.
[*] undekorative Rakash; in einigen Levels findet man seine dummen Brüder, die aber nur für wenig zu gebrauchen sind. Ein wenig mehr Zweck wäre hier hübsch gewesen. Sei es für die "olfaktorische Tarnung" oder für einen kurzen Aufstand in einem Bereich.
[*] Wiederverwertung von Levels; leider gibt es bis auf die Missionen und Gegner keine Unterschiede. Einige andere zusätzliche Abschnitte zum bekannten Level wäre nett. Oder optische Veränderungen.
[*] Preis/Leistung; für den Preis kann man echt nicht meckern.
[/list]

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Gutes Stealthgame für den Preis; sehr spaßig im Multiplayer. Würde mich auf einen weiteren Teil freuen!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970439781', 'num_games_owned': 693, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 2191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1998, 'last_played': 1509279431}
review:
In case you didn't realise, Styx: Shards of Darkness is a stealth game. 

You have to be prepared to die often and you may find yourself saving your position a lot, which you can thankfully do with a single click of the controller. The maps are all multi-layered and crisscrossed with secret passages and places to climb up or drop down. You rely on your ability to read the environment and predict where enemies will be so you can avoid being detected, whether by sight, sound or smell. Combat is all about asassination rather than brute force.

The controls of Styx let it down slightly. There are many occasions where your character jumps for a ledge or attempts to swing on a rope and ends up falling to his death. It isn't so much that the leaps you perform are impossible. It's more that it is sometimes difficult to orient yourself correctly in three dimensions to perform these manouevers. It's not game-breakingly bad, just something you will notice at times.

Overall, I absolutely love this game for its atmosphere, its humour, and the tight gameplay. However, it is very similar to Styx: Master of Shadows, so I would recommend you start there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055937074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1507, 'last_played': 1495638616}
review:
They did it again. If you like the first game, you'll certainly appreciate this. Styx is a great character, and a perfect fit for the type of game, and fantasy world he exists in. The story this time around is not quite as good, but it's serviceable. More importantly, as a stealth game, Styx: Shards of Darkness never tries to appeal to anyone who doesn't want to sneak around assassinating people and stealing goodies. Too many games these days try to be all things to all people.; it's the design philosophy that killed the Splinter Cell franchise, and plagues the supposed Thief spiritual successor Dishonored. in Styx: SoD you get to play a really good stealth game, and that's all. It's a well structured experience without features that undermine each other. You will be challenged in ways the game designers intended, not in ways you had to manufacture because the devs decided freedom was more important than actually making a game.

Big recommendation from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190583586', 'num_games_owned': 1136, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1432, 'last_played': 1496711907}
review:
Styx Shard of Darkness (which I will refer to as SoD in the review) is the 2nd installment, the sequel from MoD the first game. And just like Master of Shadow, SoD excels in stealth mechanic. The big map with different enemies and hidden passages make this game challenging and enjoyable. 

Graphic & optimization:
Quite big improvement in this part, graphic is sharper and smoother, the lightning is as good as perfect, I love the sun light in this game. And I had 0 problems while playing from start to finish. Got 60 fps all the way on max setting with my 1070 and i5-6600k.

Story:
Personally, I prefer MoD story than SoD, the story in SoD is average, its about Styx made a deal with the leader of the Goblin hunter mercenary to steal a scepter from a rogue elf, and the rogue elf need that scepter to release his race to freedom. No twist like the prequel.

Gameplay:
Play this game on highest difficulty if you like challenge or if you're a masochist, can damn hell its hard, especially on the later chapters where dwarves are more common. The gameplay mechanic is similar to MoD with some upgrades like more skill sets such as clones (has some new skills), alchemy(crafting), perception (Styx's senses), stealh and combat. I love it there is an item called odorless potion which hides your smell for a period of time, this is very useful when there are lots of dwarves, cause they can smell you. Just like in MoD, the elves can smell you, but there is no potion or a way to repel that, I had to rush everytime where the elves were around. This is a plus, more balance. Besides main mission, there are  several side objectives you have to complete, and by finishing missions (both main and secondary), getting shadow, mercy, swift, and thief medals, you are awarded with skill points (SP) at the end of every chapter. Also, there are lots of materials spread all over the map for you to collect for crafting potions, lockpicks, etc, so exploration is mandatory if you want to survive on higher difficulty. 

Sound & Music:
Voice acting besides Styx are average at best, and Styx's is okayish. The dialogue can be cringy sometimes, especially on the game over screen, so cringy that it made me laugh sometimes. And the music, nothing memorable, but at some parts of the game, it really adds immersion. Conclusion, sound and music works as they are suppose to be, but nothing special.

I dont review the co-op part of the game, cause I play the single player only. TL;DR below is the pro/con list
Pros:
- Huge maps with hidden passages and materials, exploration is needed if you want to have easier time especially in higher difficulty
- Good optimization
- Co-op campaign
- More skill and traps, more varieties in killing those blasted dwarves, pompous elves and filthy humans. 
- Easy to 100%, using collectibles guide it will take 15-20 hours, without guide 30-50 hours 

Cons:
- The stealth skill tree makes the game easier, if you want challenge, either dont invest in that skill or just learn the first skill
- Cringy dialogue and average voice acting (its not a big deal though)
- Average story

Styx Shard of Darkness is a good game with some unpolish dialogue and story, I recommend to wait for sale unless you are a Styx fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001151045', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1201, 'last_played': 1490864967}
review:
I love Styx, ever since he was first introduced in Of Orcs And Men. So I was happy they announced a sequel to the first solo game of his; Master of Shadows. This time Styx has a few more tricks up his sleeves, and the stakes are just as high. I won't go into the story, which is decent but won't be giving you the feels any time soon. It's the hardcore stealth gameplay and the character that drives it. Since I'm a bit lazy I'll just go into a pair of positive and negative lists.

PRO:
+ Beautiful game, architecture, lighting. A few weak textures here and there, but you find those in every game.
+ The new crafting system is simple, it doesn't feel intrusive in any way, like you have to go out of your way to work with it.
+ Animations, especially on Styx, are crisp.
+ Music captures the atmosphere of the areas and situations. I did not at any time feel that I wanted to listen to something else.
+ Sound in general is good, even with my crappy headphones I could hear the footsteps of guards from their direction.
+ Voice acting good, the guards and such are a bit repetitive but what'cha gonna' do?
+ Constant FPS, never had stutters. Didn't run hot on my R9 290, max settings.
+ Level design was amazing, with so many options to get to the places you need to get to. Tons of verticality that's missing from other games (Styx is sure to mention the convenient handholds though).

CON:
- Control can be awkward sometimes, especially if your in a spot where you can't rotate the camera well like some higher corners.
- When you die Styx puts you down in a 4th wall breaking moment. I skipped these as quick as possible, and I'm glad they're skippable because in Batman you can't and it's irritating as hell.
- Some jokes fall flat, or feel out of place. Pop culture references, etc.

I didn't play multiplayer because I have no friends, so I have no gripes on that side of the game. Though I hear a lot of the bugs or problems that plagued people were fixed.

All in all great game. If you absolutely loath stealth games give it a pass, otherwise I would say give it a shot. It's not as forgiving of a stealth game as say Splinter Cell, Hitman, or Deus Ex. I find that a good challenge though, because in those other games when I screw up I end up murdering a hundred people and calling it a day. Here I need to actually process and thing of my steps rather than going Leroy Jenkins.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122166296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1494777821}
review:
Styx : Shards of Darkness est une très belle surprise. Cyanide a profité des solides bases du premier volet pour les perfectionner et proposer des mécaniques de jeu bien huilées. Malgré une IA encore un peu perfectible et quelques défauts de surface, la production du studio français peut se targuer de proposer une très belle expérience dans un univers particulièrement attrayant. Styx Shards of Darkness se loge aux côtés des références des jeux d’infiltration et il sera vraiment dommage de passer à côté.


Très nette progression au niveau des graphismes
Univers toujours aussi attrayant
Un véritable jeu d'infiltration, bien ficelé
Travail soigné au niveau de la verticalité qui donne de sacrées sensations
Niveaux ouverts et qui donnent envie d'être parcourus
Beaucoup de possibilités et de fabrication d'accessoires
Une amélioration technique générale et des temps de chargement amoindris...
POINTS NÉGATIFS
... mais toujours aussi présents
Bande-son un peu en retrait
Quelques animations rigides
IA encore perfectible
Pas de véritable prise de risque

Plus d'infos : http://www.actugaming.net/test-styx-shards-of-darkness-retour-convaincant-de-gobelin-83542/

author: {'steamid': '76561198035182410', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 372, 'playtime_forever': 1424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1496147129}
review:
The first thing you do is turn off death animations cause the 4th wall breaking gragbage jokes are unbearble.

2nd thing is you curse minecraft for introducing Crafting into every single game. Even Dishonored 2 had that stupid bonecharm craft system for no reason. 

3rd you die 10 times because for some reason Styx stops crouching after he picked up a body and moved it so you have to remember to chrouch again manually. And don't get me started on the stupid way you have to access potions. 

The list goes on a bit. Basically this game has a lot of minor stupid design flaws in it that keeps it from being a perfect game. Then again Styx 1 had MAJOR design flaws that also hindred the games epicness. 
The best improvement is the level design. In the first game you had basically 4 level that were reused for 8 missions. Now you have like 6. They still reuse levels a bit which is a shame but ok.

The AI is not as good as in the first game. They walk into walls a lot and don't check under tables even if they saw you in the area. So you better play on hardest difficulty to compensate. 

The story is as good as the first one and gameplay wise styx stays one of the best stealth games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010976189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1494785389}
review: This game is completely insane. I've never played the first game of the series, but it wasn't a problem after all. Styx moves are smooth and the gameplay it's perfect. The several kinds of enemies that you will find will make the experience even better, they all behave differently and have their own keen senses, that make you think better before doing anything. While I am writing this review I am at the very last mission and all that I can say about the history is that is very nice. Nothing exceptional, but the main character simply completes the history. There are many references in Styx dialogues, and he is the first game character that actually made me laugh while playing. I have enjoyed every bit of the game, totally worth the money. I strongly recommend the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141129230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1494735836}
review:
This game was a little bit of a love hate relationship for me. I played it directly after beating the first game, which I enjoyed a great deal. The difference in pretty much everything from graphics and animations, to level design and skills was very much appreciated. The game was priced perfectly to show that this isn't a triple A game, and that is apparent in things like dialogue, VO, and amount of varied levels. To clarify on the last one, towards the end of the game you start going back through levels that you had previously been through, except you come into the level from a different point and have different objectives. This was something they did in the first game, and while it isn't the biggest deal in the world, it really detracts from what you're doing in my opinion. Up to the point where you start repeating levels each one was highly enjoyable and I was pretty impressed at what they were doing, only to be dissapointed a little that they repeated the same style from the first game. 

As for gameplay this game is meant to be played from the shadows. Trying to go into combat with enemies is pointles and you can't even do it on the higher difficulties so the game really tries to focus on the stealth aspects and boy does it get it right. You're given a few more tools from the first one which is nice, but I was still suprised that there weren't any non-lethal ways to take someone out, you can immobilize them for a few seconds, but not knock them out which is strange. Another pretty big gripe I had mid-late game was the fact that 85% of all the enemies were wearing armor, which meant you couldn't kill them by just going up to them and driving a dagger in their back. I can understand increasing the amount of armored units to make it more difficult to navigate the level, but when the vast majority of them have it, it becomes a little annoying for those of us who want to murder everyone. They should have included a dagger that peirced armor, or had a skill that let you kill them in order to bypass this.

Story-wise it was alright, I was pretty interested in the beginning, but towards the end it got kind of got muddled and the ending was pretty sub par. But I still reccomend this game for those who love stealth games or even the first one, they really did do a good job of making a worthy sequel that shows actual progress. I'm looking forward to see the next one they make because there's so much more that styx has to tell. Can't wait!

author: {'steamid': '76561198377115597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1970, 'last_played': 1538886937}
review:
Styx Shards of Darkness improves on just about everything from Master of Shadows. Only thing that would still be a problrem is the combat but if you are interested in Styx in any way this isn't a problem. Just like a lot of reviews say this is definitely a "stealth purists" type of game. Some moments you get into are pretty heart pumping, reminiscent of Thief. The plot is straightforward and somewhat simple, some revelations were pretty interesting. The visuals are much more eye popping, more color. 

Some slight "eh"s lie in the later portions as you go back to some levels but they replace enemies and it still makes them interesting. There some challenges here and there that can increase your hours, I'll be going back to them after trying to master some levels. Also the dialouge from Styx can be hit or miss. You can turn off his game over screens though. 

Overall it's a great improvement from MoS and I recommend this if you just like a good stealth game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970469287', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1494692172}
review:
Game is beautiful, level design is very good, but ... way too hard. As a big game consumer since 1988, I really like challenging hardness, but good hardness. Styx 2 offers a clumsy, buggy, unpredictable hardness, that sucks the fun out of all the efforts you're building. 

Enemies teleporting through textures, others suddenly doing a 180° turn on you under a millisecond, unkillable hordes of foes the more you progress... in a word, there's absolutely no room for error. I would have wholeheartedly forgiven this intolerance if the mechanics were not such a technical mess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007475187', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5052, 'last_played': 1600803759}
review:
Now I'm not going to give a overly long winded review talking about every little tiny bit of the game, I'm just going to give a rundown of the mainly pros and cons. This game was a lot of fun. It's definitely an improvment in many ways from Master of Shadows, but there were a few minor problems to the game.

 I will say this however. This is a great steath game, screw stupid overly hyped and dumbed down "stealth" games like Dishonored where the stealth is more of a tacked on side thing that doesn't even hold a candle to the non stealth options. The Styx games do stealth right. They make you feel like a sneaky ninja rather than yet another stupidly overpowered Rambo wearing an all black outfit.

Check out ACG's and Rageaholic's video reviews of both Styx games. But I think that Rageaholic puts it in the best terms.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UMb9IHao_Sw

But I'll just get to the pros and cons now

Pros
It sticks it's stealth roots all the way through.
The crafting system is a decent addition to the game.
The revamped skill trees add a lot to the game.
The levels are a lot more varied and offer a ton of routes and ways to get around.
The daggers and outfits you actually give different bonuses.

Cons
The ammount of crafting tables that are spread across the levels kind of lessen the specialness of crafting. It's not as fun when you can just run into the next room over and craft something.

Some of the craftable items don't have the same feel as the items as in Master of Shadows. This is mainly because the Iron Darts don't have the same feel as the Throwing Knives.

There are too many armored enemies in the roughly second half of the game. I can understand the challenge they offer, but when all but a couple of enemies are fully armored, that's when it becomes a problem.

The daggers you get or craft should be switched. Ok spoiler alert, you get a dagger called the Tapered Dagger in a level in the game, it makes your kills more quiet. Now you  can craft through the skill tree another dagger called the Ambered Dagger, it gives you amber back for every kill. It really should've been reversed wit the two of them.

But overall, the game is fun and a good squeal to Master of Shadows and a great stealth game.

review: Styx:Shards of darkness est un très bon jeu entre plateforme et infiltration.Cet opus est une suite du premier episode,bien que  plus courte.La difficulté ici se montre plus progressive la tension montant ainsi crescendo.Plateforme de par ses boss à devoir vaincre,le reste du jeu lui reste dans la veine de l'infiltration et de l'exploration pour tout ramasser et découvrir(quêtes secondaires,trésors,...).Certains niveaux vous permettront de prendre des décisions qui changeront un brin l'histoire sans pour autant altérer la chronologie des niveaux.Une fois fini il reste le plaisir de le rejouer en tuant tout le monde ou au contraire ne tuant personne,ramasser tout les trésors et autres objectifs secondaires.Il m'aura fallu un peut moins de 35 heures pour le finir en niveau Gobelin,offre un bon défi avec une chouette ambiance et un gameplay qui tient aussi à la dose d'humour dont est farci le jeu.Un très bon moment de détente en compagnie de Styx,un gobelin facétieux et à la langue bien pendue.
